PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 August, on motion by Senator Alston:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. When this debate was interrupted I was talking about other consequences—the displacement of development plans in relation to the IMF in favour of corporate plans. I gave the example of India in 1964‐65 where a famine was used by the United States and the World Bank to impose liberalisation of investment terms in the Indian fertiliser industry as a condition of providing food aid.

SPEECH.PARA: The outcome—and the very thing that India had tried to avoid through its regulations—was that, rather than its using available Indian machinery and technology, all the equipment was imported by the United States firms that bought out the Indian ones. Rather than its using plentiful, Indian‐produced, naphtha as a feed stock, liquid ammonia was imported. Such situations create debt and an ongoing dependence on imports. The IMF SAP loans have institutionalised these kinds of arrangements.

The new arrangements for borrowing were presented in the context of the Mexican currency collapse. It is worth pointing out that this collapse occurred despite stringent austerity measures, of the sort demanded by IMF, being in place for several years. It is clear that economic fundamentalist policy does not prevent such events. It is further worth noting that the main beneficiaries were the banks, whose loans would continue to be serviced—that is, the servicing of loans became a priority and human needs fell far down the list.

BREAK.PARA: In the Mexican case, the IMF paid $1.3 billion, other governments paid $2 billion and the banks put up $5 billion in involuntary loans of the kind that we are involved in now—and which we will be—without having to refer to parliament. In that case, public money made up 40 per cent of the total package and the banks contributed 60 per cent. But 80 per cent of Mexico's debt is to the banks, so the result was a direct transfer of money from the international public to private banks. In a real sense this is the same as that joke I told in the previous debate: the so‐called `aid to developing nations in financial difficulty' is actually money going to banks that would otherwise be financially disadvantaged—so it is really no joke at all.

The original loans which caused the debt problems were generally made to developing countries with the intention that they would use them to buy goods produced by the developing world. The irony is that the debt crisis was an outcome of the energy crisis in 1974 when the economy of the north was stalled and banks were awash with petrodollars deposited by the oil states. Lending to the south was a cheap way to kick‐start the northern economy—so the main benefits were to the north.

It might have been a neat Keynesian policy if the loans had not been made at very low but variable rates which rapidly climbed, adding billions to southern debt as the north got back to its feet on the back of southern demand and wanted the money for its own investment regime. The image of the north standing on the bent back of the south is fairly appropriate.

The IMF loans perpetuate the debt and poverty problem rather than alleviating it. The loans are good for northern banks, good for transnational investors, good for exporters to the south, but do little for the people of the recipient nations. The evidence of this, in relation to both Latin America and Africa, is extensive and damning. The evidence from India generally supports a very pessimistic view of the Bretton Woods trio.

Closer to home, we have the evidence of the structural adjustment programs in Papua New Guinea. Structural adjustment programs have been imposed on Papua New Guinea since 1989. While the World Bank sometimes supports structural adjustment programs, making them conditions of its loans, it is generally following the lead of the International Monetary Fund. The latest structural adjustment program was signed in August 1995 and will see a direct contribution from Australia of over $65 million.

The structural adjustment program in Papua New Guinea was imposed without consultation with the community and is heavily opposed by that community, primarily through the efforts of the National Coalition for Socio‐Economic Justice. The coalition represents trade unions, churches, students, women's groups and other community groups. It recognises that efforts must be made to resolve the financial crisis in Papua New Guinea. It does not believe the structural adjustment program will be of any substantial benefit—it will certainly be of substantial harm.

Items particularly opposed by the National Coalition for Socio‐Economic Justice include the repeal of the Minimum Wages Act. Here you have a bank telling a sovereign country what to do with its industrial relations and the welfare of its people. Other items include the abolition of price control for basic foodstuffs: some deregulated food prices have gone up by 200 per cent. Other items are increased fees for health care and repeal of the regulation under the Investment Promotion Authority, IPA, which advises on whether investments and investors are acceptable—based on financial, police and intelligence reports. The major issues here are corruption and gross abuses of the law, which are endemic in poorly developed nations. You have a situation where Australia becomes complicit in forcing sometimes very poor investment acceptance.

Another item is retrenchments of government employees, including teachers. We have raised the issue of Australian aid programs providing teachers at a time when Papua New Guinea teachers are being sacked as part of the economic austerity program. We are potentially running in two directions at the same time. Another item is the privatisation of state‐owned enterprises: while ideologically consistent with our government's position on its own enterprises, it is not necessarily in the interests of those in Papua New Guinea and is almost certainly against the will of the population.

So where goes economic sovereignty? In terms of the real outcomes, I think it is morally and ethically bankrupt for Australia to be pushing that as part of its aid program. The above items are the sorts of things traditionally associated with structural adjustment program loans: coercive impositions on neo-colonial nations. They are the sorts of issues which have attracted widespread criticisms of structural adjustment programs in the International Monetary Fund and their support by the World Bank.

The national coalition met with the World Bank in October 1995 and the bank agreed that the only way the structural adjustment program will work is if community groups and NGOs are consulted. Though two years have passed, they have not been consulted. The criticism is not just from community groups; it is dominant at the highest level in various fora in the United Nations. Isn't it amazing? If there is any international fora that currently has some level of democracy, it is probably the United Nations, but when we come to decisions we are prepared to ignore them and money rules, okay, even if it is dumb money—dumb conditions and dumb money.

It is the recommendations of the United Nations inquiries that we are asking government to use as a guideline on which activities and loans of the IMF are acceptable. This is not the same as imposing Australia's values on other countries; it is saying that the values that have been agreed upon by various slow and tortuous processes within the United Nations ought to be at least considered, and this not an unreasonable time to consider them.

What we are asking for here is some recognition of the kinds of reports that everyone knows the name of and that everyone gives lip service to—the Brandt reports, the Brundtland report and the Turk report. We all talk as if everyone accepts the Brundtland report, the report which put the term `sustain able development' on the verbal map, yet few have actually read the report and fewer still support the recommendations. The report highlights the fact that poverty is inextricably linked to environmentally destructive behaviour. It also reinforces the finding of the Brandt reports that most development, so-called, results in greater, not less, poverty and inequity, both between nations and within them.

Structural adjustment programs are not an answer. Mexico was heavily involved in imposing austerity regimes for several years prior to the collapse of their economy and it did nothing to prevent it. Many feel that it exacerbated it. The state following the purest form of structural adjustment was Romania under Ceaucescu—with massive exploitation of resources and people, destruction of social support and the community and ruthless pursuit of export dollars, all enforced by military and death squads. This is the direction that the International Monetary Fund pushes other nations. Under such circumstances it is positively immoral to support them.

If you were to do an in‐depth study around the world of the level of internal conflict and disruption of ethnic wars of serious bloodshed—whether it be in Africa, South America or Europe—you would probably find a very strong connection between structural adjustment programs and economic fundamentalism and the impact on communities and the level of scapegoatism that sometimes comes out in highly violent outcomes. Yet what is Australia's position? They say, `Let's look at putting troops in. Let's look at arming in this region for future developments. Let's not look at what causes internal or even regional wars. Let's look at continuing doing things we are doing and close our eyes to what may be in the end very obvious connections between what we are doing economically and what happens in terms of countries and what happens between groups within communities when things are tough.'
In my opinion, it is unethical and immoral to support this bill. The Greens' position has been made very clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak to the International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997 . I am following on from some of the comments made by my colleague Senator Bourne. The Democrats support the concept that growth should be sustainable, equitable and just. Therefore, we will be supporting the amendments put forward by Senator Margetts, which are directed at taking into account factors far broader than the financial straitjackets of financially powerful nations. I want to reiterate these concerns and also highlight in particular the position of young people as elements of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: For many of the world's young people, the realisation of economic, social and cultural rights are very distant and, in fact, becoming increasingly distant. Approximately one billion people live in absolute poverty and around 180 million young people suffer from serious malnutrition. The trend is for these numbers to increase. They represent personal, family and community tragedies.

Institutions such as the IMF have a world focus with an infrastructure which can be directed towards realising economic, social and cultural rights. The structural adjustment packages did include a social safety net in an attempt to offset the adverse effects of adjustment and give these packages a human face. These measures were welcome but they did not recognise the influence of international trade and financial concerns on domestic policy and the detrimental effect on basic human rights and, specifically, economic, cultural and social rights.

Further, the IMF is driven by economic theory rather than the real experience of humans, politicians, communities and economies. As Senator Bourne said earlier in this debate, this money requires privatisation, tax reductions and the lifting of restrictions on the supply of offshore currency. I am concerned about these issues in Australia but I am particularly concerned about imposing these issues on other nations.

The economic meddling of today has a significant impact on the lives of young people, both now and, of course, in the future. The 180 million young people suffering from malnutrition are not to be ignored. Our social structures need to be changed to address this injustice and we need to include these people in our economic horizons. For this reason, I do support the inclusion of social justice criteria in loaning money. The criteria are directed towards an approach consistent with Australia's commitment to the International Bill of Human Rights, the Tokyo Declaration of the World Commission on Environment and Development and the Final Report on the Realisation of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.

Balancing our obligations under these international agreements and the positive outcomes from loaning money to nations has great potential for a fairer and more just world. I therefore commend the amendments before us to the chamber as a recognition of social justice for the future of young people around the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me start by thanking other speakers for their contributions to this debate on the International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997 and recording my appreciation for the substantial majority of non-government senators who are likely to support this important bill. This bill, as has been stated, enables Australia to adhere to the International Monetary Fund's new arrangements to borrow and it will simplify the framework for Australia's financial transactions with the IMF. The new arrangements to borrow, the so-called NAB, will double the IMF's capacity to borrow, forestall or cope with an impairment of the international monetary system or to deal with an exceptional situation that poses a threat to the stability of that system. The NAB will therefore enhance the IMF's ability to safeguard the international monetary system.

SPEECH.PARA: Participants in the NAB will meet once a year to review and discuss macro-economic and financial market developments, especially those that could have an impact on the stability of the international financial system. This is potentially an important new forum for consideration of these issues.

The bill introduces a simplified framework for the conduct and recording of Australia's regular financial transactions with the IMF. Under the new framework, these transactions will be conducted in a more transparent and cost-efficient manner. The amendments proposed in the bill will have no impact on Commonwealth budget outlays or on the budget balance.

Senator Sherry, in an otherwise useful speech on this bill, made some comments about the spring meeting. I have some information that can shed some light on that. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, will chair the first meeting in his position as governor—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has resigned, has he? Welcome news! Thank you very much.

—All you had to do is ask. He is not resigning. Unbelievable! I do not think you understand how these things work, Senator Sherry. You are no Young Turk, Senator Sherry. With your experience, you should have been able to understand this. I want you to know that my office is always open to assist you with these technical questions. I assume that Senator Sherry thinks it is appropriate for the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia to represent the nation at these sorts of meetings. I mention that because some who may read Senator Sherry's speech may not appreciate the mechanics of how these things work.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there is general goodwill towards this bill, and I do not propose to disturb that goodwill in this chamber. I thank senators for their comments. There are some other remarks to be made, particularly relating to amendments that Senator Margetts has put forward. The government will not be supporting those amendments, but I shall make some comments on those when they are moved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 27), after section 8B, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 8C Treasurer to have regard to social justice criteria

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Treasurer must not make a decision:

PARA.TAB: (a) to borrow amounts pursuant to subsection 6(1); or
(b) to execute and issue securities pursuant to subsection 7(1); or
(c) to direct that an amount be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund pursuant to section 8A or 8B;
for the purposes of enabling Australia to make resources available to the Fund, unless the Treasurer is satisfied that the activities of the Fund, including the terms of the loans it makes:
(d) are consistent with:

TAB.TAB: (i) the obligations of recipient nations under the International Bill of Human Rights, with particular regard to the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights; and
(ii) principles 2, 3, 6 and 7 of the Tokyo Declaration of the World Commission on Environment and Development, dated 27 February 1987; and

(iii) the recommendations of the Special Rapporteur to the United Nations Economic and Social Council in Paragraph 64 of the Final Report on the Realisation of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (E/CN.Sub.2/1992/16); and

PARA.TAB: (e) take into account the issues raised by the Special Rapporteur to the United Nations Economic and Social Council in Paragraph 64 of the document referred to in subparagraph (d)(iii); and
(f) will increase social justice, and broad redistribution of economic resources on a more equitable basis within nations that are recipients of loans from the Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The issues to be taken into account under paragraph (1)(e) are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the impact of the adjustment process on national sovereignty; and
(b) the issue of popular participation in the development of adjustment programs, and how most effectively to subject adjustment packages to public scrutiny prior to their implementation; and
(c) integrating human rights yardsticks into any equation measuring the levels of achievement of adjustment programs; and
(d) exploring viable alternatives to the adjustment process; and
(e) the relationship between conditionalities and internal human rights obligations; and
(f) precise measures to be employed to protect all social groups from the negative impact of adjustment, with a view to expanding existing measures of protection such as social safety nets; and
(g) means of rectifying existing contradictions between the adjustment process and the goal of the institutions which promote adjustment; and
(h) the human rights effects of liberalising economies, free trade and the internationalisation of the world economy; and
(i) ways and means of ensuring that the rhetoric about protecting the poor, utilising social safety nets and other additions to the adjustment package have a positive material impact; and
(j) ways to ensure that the existing policy contradictions within both the World Bank and the Fund are rectified in the true interests of promoting economic, social and cultural rights.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) In taking account of the issues listed in subsection (2), the Treasurer is also to have regard to the recommendations and cautions of:

PARA.TAB: (a) the reports of the Independent Commission on International Development Issues, chaired by Willy Brandt, published in 1980, entitled North/South : A Programme for Survival , and in 1983, entitled Common Crisis: North/South: Cooperation for World Recovery ; and
(b) the report of the World Committee on Environment and Development, chaired by Gro Harlem Brundtland, published in 1987, entitled Our Common Future ; and
(c) the Final Report of the Special Rapporteur Danilo Trk, to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, on the Realisation of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (E/CN.Sub.2/1992/16); and
(d) the criteria on social justice and the environment developed by the World Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is a reflection of the often dismal record of the International Monetary Fund, or IMF, in its loan policy. After World War II the Bretton Woods triplet—that is, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and GATT—were created to rebuild the European economy and prevent the exploitation of the situation by private sector speculators. It is really interesting that it has done exactly the opposite. In over 50 years it has turned right around. How damaging the failure to rebuild and regulate was seen in the aftermath of World War I. As a second objective, the idealism of the allies against fascism translated into a desire for decolonisation, and the United Nations was born. The IMF, World Bank and GATT were to equally apply to the emerging colonies.

But the decolonisation of the nations subsequently defined as the `south' was followed by efforts to assist these nations who had been heavily exploited. We then had the infamous `development decade', which brought wealth to transnational corporations involved in `development' plans but did little for the people of the nations who were supposed to benefit. Meanwhile, the non-aligned group of developing countries, the Group of 77, were formed to fight what they called `economic colonialism', and this was followed by the debt crisis of the late 1970s. Various international organisations based in the United Nations began to look at the failure of classical development models. The United Nations Economic and Social Council and the United Nations Committee for Trade and Development were the most significant.

With the debt crisis, caused by the lack of aid and aggressive marketing of cheap but variable‐interest loans in the `south', the United Nations established the Independent Commission on International Development Issues, under the chair of Willy Brandt. My amendment ties Australia's contributions to the International Monetary Fund to the recommendations of that report, published as North-south: a program for survival, and the subsequent report three years later, published as Common crisis: north-south: cooperation for world recovery.

The Brandt commission was established at the start of 1978 and made its first report in 1980 and its second in 1983. The first report includes a specific chapter on the world monetary order and two on development finance as well as general treatment of investment, international organisations and the action of transnational corporations. The commission has been widely recognised as the pivotal work on development in relation to the alleviation of poverty.

Some of the recommendations most pertinent to International Monetary Fund loans include: a call for legislation either coordinated laterally by the recipient nations and donor nations or internationally to regulate transnational corporation activities in matters such as ethical behaviour and the disclosure of information. Does this sound familiar? We are actually having our regulations systematically pulled out because they are considered to be anti-competitive. And disclosure of information, how often have we heard commercial-in-confidence talked about with regard to having anything to do with government and business these days?

The report supports industry policy in the south to develop technological production. It supports preferential trading agreements between southern nations, which incidentally were the mechanisms Europe used in its own postwar economic reconstruction. It calls for an international trade agency that includes UNCTAD and a stabilisation of commodity prices at a remunerative level as a matter of urgency.

The report does not seek to promote trade barriers but asks that trade be established on a fair rather than exploitative basis. That is not radical. It does not say that structural adjustment should not occur but says:

The adjustment process of developing countries should be placed in the context of maintaining long-term economic and social development. The IMF should avoid inappropriate or excessive regulation of their economies . . .
Exactly what they are not doing today and exactly what Australia is participating in doing. It goes on:
The participation of developing countries in the staffing, management and decision‐making of the IMF should be enlarged.
Guess what is not happening? It continues:

There must be a substantial increase in the transfer of resources to developing countries in order to finance projects and programmes to alleviate poverty and to expand food production, especially in the least developed countries.
The resume of principle proposals in the second report include the following:
IMF—Changes in conditionality:

‐ The IMF's conditionality to be made more appropriate to the situation of the borrower . . . In particular low income countries with limited access to market borrowing, heavy dependence on official agencies for balance of payments support, and restricted capacity for rapid economic transformation, should have far greater availability of low conditionality finance . . .
‐ Countries to be encouraged by the enlarged availability of low conditionality credits to come to the IMF at an early stage of anticipated crisis.

‐ Greater attention to be paid to supply, relative to demand conditions, so that payment deficits are corrected by an appropriate mix of policies, with less exclusive concentration on demand constraints . . .

‐ The IMF in framing its programmes to give greater weight to output, growth, employment and income‐distribution considerations, relative to its past emphasis on the control of inflation and payments deficits, and to obey more fully its own guidelines of 1979 which call for paying due regard to the domestic, social and political objectives of member countries.

The Brandt report was not radical. It simply requires an awareness of or sympathy for the inclusion for the aspirations of the nations receiving IMF loans. Likewise, the Brundtland report, entitled Our common future , was not a radical report. In fact, if anything, it has been condemned by some environmentalists for its connection of development with environment and its call for increased growth as being something that is desirable. In my opinion, the substance of the Brundtland report is rarely tackled. While people concentrate on its support of growth they ignore the fact that it says:
Revived growth must be of a new kind in which sustainability, equity, social justice and security are firmly embedded as major social goals.
Perhaps that is considered to be an impediment to trade. It goes on:
A safe, environmentally sound energy pathway is an indispensable component of this.
What are we doing? We are giving coal as aid. It continues:

Education, communication and international co‐operation can all help to achieve those goals. Development planners should take account in their reckoning of national wealth not only of standard economic indicators, but also of the state of natural resources. Better income distribution, reduced vulnerability to natural disasters and technological risks, improved health, preservation of cultural heritage—all contribute to raising the equality of that growth.

The other mistake that is frequently made is that the definition of sustainable development in terms of intergenerational equity is allowed to eclipse the fact that the majority report deals with international equity and distributional equity within nations as primary issues to address and attain sustainable development.
The Turk report is the most specific report looking at details of the IMF and its structural adjustment programs. We have included the text of the issues which it says ought to be considered.

Such calls and acceptance are not unconditional—that is, the Brundtland report's call for growth within the acceptance of the structural adjustments found in all such reports. It should only occur in conjunction with major calls for reform. The basic point is that it is entirely irresponsible and immoral to support an agency that makes loans on the basis of imposing austerity on poor and desperate nations. Its completely inappropriate and contrary to the valid aspirations of these developing nations and to the principles and purposes for which aid is offered.

As a sidelight, I would like to point out that this International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill , announced last year, is the bill under which the Treasurer can appropriate money for the Thai rescue that was organised during the break. The Treasurer has already said that Australia will—not might or is considering—contribute some $1.36 billion. Currently—and he did not mention this—this will have to get some parliamentary approval. After the passage of this bill it will not. This bill authorises the Treasurer to contribute up to $1.5 billion—isn't that a convenient figure?—to any rescue package the IMF wants to organise and creates the approval in this bill. I have just mentioned the IMF, although it has stated aims, is quite happy to impose rescue packages which cause hardship and often internal disruptions within countries.

BREAK.PARA: In this respect, it is interesting to actually look at the Thai case. Nearly as soon as the rescue package was announced, commentators, including those in the major newspapers, pointed out that this was a rescue primarily of the transnational banks and the creditors whose goods were bought. They pointed out that it would have little effect on ordinary Thai people whether or not the rescue went ahead. They pointed out that the majority of the debt which resulted in the need for rescue was generated by consumption in the highest strata of Thai society. This highest strata generates people who are as rich as Alan Bond and Christopher Skase were. There is a huge vertical inequity in Thai society and the majority of people get a minimum wage of around $5 a day or less.

What the papers did not highlight is that transnational banks and financial investors often give loans for investment in areas where they have an interest, either as lenders to corporations producing goods and services or extracting natural resources as a financially related venture. They are therefore giving loans that serve their own interests. This situation was a prominent factor in the collapse of the Philippines economy and the banking sector itself has noted that a large part of that problem was the enthusiasm of the very young loan agents who went out promoting loans, particularly where the money would be spent on the products of associated or customer companies.

These are the kinds of things that created the debt problem in Thailand. It is therefore the transnational corporations, the transnational finance sector, Thai finance institutions and the upper classes of Thai society who will benefit from this rescue. Already in relation to the Thai rescue package I have heard that there will be restrictions on social spending by the Thai government. In other words, the Thai people will pay part of the cost of saving transnational and other wealthy interests by bailing out their bad investments. The other part of the rescue will be paid by taxpayers in Australia, Tokyo and other contributing nations.

The effect of my amendment, if carried, would not stop the Thai rescue package or Australia's involvement in it. The impact would be to assure that ordinary Thai people do not have this rescue taken out of their metaphorical hides. It will also stop IMF conditions put on Thailand to, for example, increase exploitation of Thai forest resources. It is all very well going to firms and saying, `You should manage your resources better.' We are actually part of a structural adjustment project and will probably be pointing to Thailand and saying, `What have you got to sell? Let us rip some more mining out of Mindanao, despite what the environmental and social impact will be. Let us pull out more of your forest and leave it degraded so that people do not have the means of meeting their own basic needs.' That is what we are looking at.

Thailand is of course one of the few South‐East Asian nations that actually banned commercial logging in native forests, although that does not seem to have affected or stopped the logging. I understand the last forest of a unique native pine was to be logged in 1993 and the logging of degraded forests in Lanna, the north‐east province of Thailand, has continued over the strong protest of local villagers who have an excellent program of full ecological rehabilitation of local forests. These villagers have at times been relocated at gunpoint and their villages destroyed to facilitate the rehabilitation and replacement of forests with Tasmanian blue gums for the Japanese pulp market. My amendment would at least not allow the weakening of forest protection or pressure for `more liberal' foreign investment in pulp production to be a requirement of an IMF structural adjustment program.

If, as the minister has suggested, the Treasurer is going to be in a position of leadership in this regard, all I can say is shame on him. If this is the price of feeding the ego of a minister of the government to look good and important on the international agenda while ripping up the basic social and environmental basis of countries in this region, then shame on him and shame on the government. Shame, and it should be recognised. The irony is that this was one of those bills that the government wanted to shove through in lunchtime in the last session. They wanted to shove it or cough it through in lunchtime in the last session as non-controversial. I am not the only person in Australia talking about this and it is one of those issues that talkback radio has had a lot to say about. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope those on talkback radio were perhaps more careful with their facts. In view of the amount of time spent on the currency swap with Thailand, it is worth putting on the record again that this currency swap will not draw on the budget and it is not part of Australia's aid program. The support will be provided through a foreign currency swap between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Bank of Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not support the amendments moved by the Greens. The countries that are members of the fund are not forced to draw from the fund. They do so at their own choice and this allows them to take into consideration any domestic considerations. The articles of agreement of the fund do not give it authority to get involved in domestic political decision and the fund does not. The purpose of the NAB is to protect and strengthen the international monetary system and Australia has a direct interest in doing so. We would not want to encumber that protection with unnecessary requirements such as these and it is important that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) be able to respond quickly. It is the nature of a crisis; you need to be able to respond quickly.

Through our executive director and the Treasurer's membership of the interim committee, the key ministerial group guiding the fund, Australia plays an important part in ensuring that the IMF operates in accordance with its articles of agreement. We will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Those people listening to the debate—and because this is not a broadcast day, it will not be until they have read it—will realise that the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) has not answered the major issues that I have mentioned. He said my information was not correct, but he has not actually refuted the information I have given. There fore, I would commend my amendment to the Senate and ask that people support fairness and equity.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be well be that it is voluntary for countries, but it now means that we do not have to come to the Senate for very large amounts of the money. With the passage of this bill, it now means that very large amounts of money—much larger than many of the programs that we deal with to the nth degree in Senate estimates—will go out of the purview of the political process in terms of accountability and scrutiny. This is not good enough and that is why we need to make sure that at least some efforts are made to look at the basis on which these loans are given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, precisely what powers does the parliament have to oversight the disbursement of Australian funds pursuant to the international monetary agreement?

SPEECH.PARA: There have been a number of matters raised by Senator Margetts. I have listened carefully to her speech and, quite frankly, in my view her speech raised matters which need to be argued by those who oppose what she is saying. On the face of it, what she is saying is perfectly reasonable, based on examples which she has given to the chamber not only in her speech in support of her amendment, but also in her speech in the second reading debate. There are quite a number of matters there which are of concern and must be of concern broadly. The minister has indicated in his response to Senator Margetts that she is wrong. But he has only suggested that the area she is wrong in is the fact that the transfer has taken place outside of the aid budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't even mention that.

—Exactly. As I said, I listened carefully to what she said and she did not even argue against that particular fact. She did of course have something to say about the vertical inequities that are not endemic but are currently a problem in Thailand. It is a very valid point. I ask the minister to advise the committee as to precisely how parliamentarians can have an input into this and the concerns that are expressed, and they are expressed by broad groups of people in our own country and in the recipient countries. How can we raise those concerns with governments in an effective manner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just take the first point in relation to the Thai currency swap. There has been very extensive debate in the parliament on that and I think there have been some questions asked in the other place in relation to that issue. The option is always available to people in this chamber, if they have concerns about that particular issue, to raise that matter. So, in that sense, the parliament is able to examine closely what the government has done.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other avenues which are available. The Treasurer's annual reports to parliament on Australia and the IMF also provide an opportunity for scrutiny and for debate. Senators and MPs have access to all public documents produced by the IMF, including its annual report. That can always lead to questions. Information on Australia's relationship with the IMF can be obtained through the estimates process, the legislation committees of the parliament. Questions can be raised and are raised in those fora.

The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has had an interest in the IMF. Senator Harradine, as a member of that committee, would be aware of that. In 1993 the joint standing committee prepared a report on Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. My advice is that the joint standing committee has met with the senior management of the IMF—I think the managing director in December 1996 and the first deputy managing director in February 1997. So there are plenty of areas where parliamentarians can raise issues in relation to Australia's relationship with the IMF. They can raise questions and seek answers through the joint standing committee, through the estimates process and through debates on annual reports. These are just some of the vehicles which are open to senators to obtain the information they wish on Australia's relationship with the IMF.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I asked the minister how parliament could effectively intervene in these areas. Yes, I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and so is Senator Margetts a member of the committee. She and I have raised questions over quite a number of years in respect of these particular matters. You mention the annual report. Perhaps I cannot, but others can make a great speech in this parliament on the report—
—For five minutes!

—Yes, that is right; for five minutes, as Senator Margetts says. There are opportunities to ask questions, that is very true, but there is nothing effective that can be done. We have the opportunity right here and now to do something effective about problems which we have seen and which really need to be addressed and, as Senator Margetts has said, that were addressed in the two major reports that everybody gives lip‐service to.

SPEECH.PARA: With this amendment we have an opportunity here and now. The minister has not gone to the specifics of this amendment, and the specifics are there before you. What is wrong with a provision which enables Australia to make resources available to the fund provided that they are consistent with the obligations of recipient nations under the International Bill of Human Rights, and particularly with regard to the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights?

What is wrong with principles 2, 3, 6 and 7 of the Tokyo Declaration of the World Commission on Environment and Development? I had a look at those. I suggest they are unexceptionable and would be supported, as would the other matters that are contained in the 8C amendment and the provision in (f), that the Treasurer should be satisfied that the action taken:
(f) will increase social justice, and broad redistribution of economic resources on a more equitable basis within nations that are recipients of loans from the Fund.

What is wrong with that? I would like to hear from the minister as to what is the objection to that. There are further issues to be taken account of in subparagraph (ii). I will not read them, because I can see the numbers as can anybody else around the place.

I raise this matter here and now because we have an opportunity. Senator Margetts has given us that opportunity. I believe we should address the issues that she has raised specifically in this amendment and ask ourselves: what is wrong with this amendment? Please tell me. In my view, both the government and the opposition ought to tell us what is wrong with it. In the absence of that advice, I feel quite strongly disposed to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take the time of the chamber unnecessarily. After looking through the amendment moved by Senator Margetts, Labor certainly shares her concern, the concern of Senator Harradine and, I am sure, the concern of the government about the consequences to the environment of international economic development and guidance that occurs with respect to the International Monetary Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: We are certainly concerned about minimum wages and conditions under a variety of labour arrangements in a considerable number of countries around the world. We are certainly concerned about issues relating to social justice and the broad distribution of economic resources, and we are certainly concerned about human rights.

There is a variety of ways of addressing the concerns of the Senate and, I am sure, all members in both chambers. There is a variety of other international agreements and treaties and other international organisations that can deal with the specific issues that are the subject of Senator Margetts's amendment. Labor believes that it is appropriate to deal with the issues that have been outlined in the context of quite specific legislation that may come before this parliament on other occasions.

There is a range of treaties, arrangements, negotiations and agreements that other ministers representing our country are involved in. For example, with respect to minimum wages and conditions in labour arrangements, we believe that the International Labour Organisation has an important role to play. I am not particularly pleased with the government's attitude to the International Labour Organisation but, putting aside that issue, we believe it is an example of the numerous ways in which the very important agenda on these issues can be progressed. In the context of the international monetary agreement that we are considering here today, we do not believe that this is the appropriate place for this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry said that there are a variety of fora in which to deal with these issues. I would say that there is a variety of ways for turning your back on these issues, and this is one of the most prominent ways to do it, not just here but in other places. There are ways within other fora. Anybody who has heard of or been to the United Nations knows how difficult it is to reach an agreement of consensus on any issues at the United Nations. There is a level of input, debate and compromise that goes on, and the statements that come out of that forum—which is still democratic—are reached in a very complex and intricate way.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Sherry is saying and, in effect, what the minister is saying is that we are not going to take any of these issues seriously. When it comes to implementation—and this is all it is—the international fora are saying `If it is going to help countries, aid should be done in a certain way to take certain things into consideration.' We have looked at all of this. It is not Australia putting its values on other people; it is the international community saying this is the way things should happen. What Senator Sherry and the government are saying is, `But when push comes to shove, we are going to turn our back on all of those debates and provide a large amount of autonomy to those organisations which are doing the exact opposite of what we said is desirable.'

So we are not only not being prescriptive, we are actually going in the totally opposite direction. We are walking with our eyes open into potential Bougainville copper mines of the future in the Philippines. We are walking with our eyes open to Australia, without parliamentary approval having to be given—there might be the odd five‐minute debate on a report—allowing massive deforestation. We are walking with our eyes open to creating situations where entire communities of thousands of people at a time may be left without the means of meeting their own basic needs. This is what we are doing. We are not saying it should be looked at in another forum—this is actually the implementation.

When was the last time we dealt with a piece of legislation saying this is how we as a parliament implement human rights in other countries? We do not. We do not deal with general legislation issues about human rights internationally. That is not what we do. What we deal with is the massive use of money which has an impact on the economy, on the environment and on basic human rights wages and conditions. That is what we are doing. It is the dollar that takes action, parliamentarians that speak and the United Nations that, through a very slow tortuous process, comes to agreements. We have the chance to put that into action—except that the government and the opposition are turning their backs. I can count as well as anyone else. I can see what will happen in this vote, but I am going to call a division because it is too important to pretend that it is not happening.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the allegation—the government can speak for themselves—that we are closing our eyes or turning our backs. Labor's record over 13 years is, I believe, a strong record in the types of areas that Senator Margetts has identified. It is not a matter of closing our eyes or turning our backs, it is a matter of dealing with these issues when and where we are able to in respect to legislation and in respect to international agreements in a national forum where we can have an impact. I understand and appreciate your concern for these issues, Senator Margetts. I do not always agree with the particular solutions that you offer but please do not give the Labor side of this chamber a lecture about morality on this issue. There is common concern but we may have differing solutions from time to time about these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the fact that we certainly will not be supporting the amendment. There are, as I have indicated, plenty of chances for people to scrutinise Australia's relationship with the IMF. I did not think there would be an occasion where I would be debating treaties with Senator Harradine and the need to incorporate even more treaties into the decision making process. That issue has arisen but the fact of the matter is that this government gives no ground to anyone in its concern for human rights, nor does it give any ground in its concern for social development and the development of living standards in poorer countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is, Senator Margetts, that you and I would differ on how to achieve that. You and I would probably differ quite profoundly. I would tend to argue, in a wider debate, that many of the policies you would put forward would be policies which would be to the detriment of people in Third World countries. We do not support the policy position which you are coming from. We support a different approach. What you have put down in your amendment is an enormously wide ranging series of issues which would mean that we would not be able to fulfil the obligations we have under the IMF and therefore it would help to defeat the very purpose of the bill.

This is a bill concerned with bringing the IMF up to date with current world developments—to increase its capacity and to assist where crises may occur. In that sense we think it is a huge plus not only to the developed world but to the developing world as well. We do not make any concession that we are less worried about the issue Senator Margetts raised. The way this government has behaved and the way we can demonstrate how our policies are likely to achieve many of the goals you have stated means that this is likely to be more effective than the sorts of policies that you have put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to what the minister has just said, I would like to put forward a challenge. I am ready any time, Minister, if you want to take me on in a public forum point by point on what Greens policies do and say in relation to development; in relation to the economic benefits of diversity, ecological sustainability and appropriate scale of development; and in relation to structural adjustment versus regional based development and community based development. Any time, any day that I am available I will take you on in public. I have the background and I have the theory. I have spoken to a number of people over years and years. Any time you want to debate that in a public forum I will take you on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I just could not resist this. The minister, Senator Kemp, has had a long and proud record of standing up for the rights of parliament, particularly in respect of international agreements. As you know, I had a notice of motion on the Notice Paper for I do not know how many years. It languished there until Senator Kemp, I think, entered the debate and now we have a parliamentary committee on treaties. What is that parliamentary committee on treaties all about? It is a means of ensuring that the parliament does have some say over the particular provisions of the international instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: But here we have a very effective international instrument, the international monetary agreement legislation, to provide for funding. And money talks; that is the whole point. You can have all these other international agreements and so on, but with this one money talks. It talks in many cases, as Senator Margetts has said, of changing and altering the society of the recipients, and of exacerbating in many cases the vertical injustices and imbalances that exist.

What I would have liked, though we are not going to get it, is the committee to consider each and every one of the amendments that Senator Margetts has put forward, tick the ones that we want and cross out the ones that we do not. I would have thought that we should not have denied ourselves the opportunity of parliament having a real and effective say as to the policies to be adopted when structural adjustment programs are imposed on countries with our money. That is all I have to say.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Kemp) read a third time.

BREAK.XREF: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION (REPEALS, TRANSITIONAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill seeks to create the Productivity Commission through the amalgamation of the statutory bodies of the Industry Commission, commonly known as the IC, the Economic Planning Advisory Commission, commonly known as EPAC, and the non‐statutory Bureau of Industry Economics, commonly known as the BIE. For all practical purposes, the mergers have already taken place. Executive action already undertaken means that the merger of the bodies has already occurred in fact, if not strictly in law.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has arrogantly disregarded the supremacy of parliament by acting as if the Productivity Commission was already operating, although the legislation that we are now dealing with is necessary to effect its creation. I think we should reflect on the fact that before the election the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, claimed he was going to respect the role of parliament and the supremacy of parliament. But the approach taken in respect of these three organisations is another example of where the proper parliamentary processes that the Prime Minister so vigorously argued in favour of prior to the election have been totally ignored.

The Industry Commission even released on 19 July 1996 a report under the name of the Productivity Commission entitled Stocktake of progress in microeconomic reform. Clearly, the handling of the report was a blunder, which has not been repeated, but it let the cat out of the bag about the real policy intentions of the government. The Stocktake report showed the policy agenda that the Productivity Commission and the government will pursue, which includes further cuts in general tariff levels from 1 July 1997 from five per cent to three per cent; the abolition of the sugar tariff; and a review of all limits on foreign investment with a view to relaxing the current restrictions. It also includes minimising pricing oversight to situations of monopoly—for example, it would not be allowed for financial institutions or petroleum; the terminating of bounties; the terminating of export assistance such as the DIFF scheme and the export market development scheme; the removal of airport cross‐subsidies, thereby disadvantaging regional airports; and the introduction of road pricing in cities.

Even more ominously, the report strongly suggests that minimum wages could be reduced and that wage loadings, including penalties, overtime and shift rates, could be slashed for many Australian workers. It also suggests stripping back award conditions even further than has been achieved by the government, and we can reflect on that debate and its outcomes in respect of the industrial legislation that was regrettably passed here last year because, I might remind this chamber, of an agreement between the Democrats and the government.

Many of the issues mentioned in the Stocktake report are industry policy matters and the further concentration of advice will significantly increase the weight of the Treasury agenda views in the government. Whilst these views should, of course, be considered, they should be debated in the context of alternatives. Clearly, this is not going to happen with this government.

Labor pursued a competitive advice model to ensure that all sides of the debate would be considered. This is being dismantled by the Liberal‐National Party government and Labor is concerned that this will lead the government to pursue even worse economic and industry policies than the current policies being followed. When it comes to choice, competition and a competitive model for evaluating sources of advice, this government is not very receptive to that particular model.

Before the committee stage begins, I would like to point out some of the concerns that Labor has with this legislation. The first of these is the dismantling of the system of competing sources of advice established by Labor while in government. This approach by the current government of creating the Productivity Commission was announced in one of those Cape Barren headland speeches of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, which he delivered to the committee in Melbourne on 18 July 1995. It is interesting that the speech did not canvass the contribution to the public policy debate made by the Bureau of Industry Economics or by EPAC. There was no acknowledgment of the contribution these bodies have made and no plans to use the expertise or particular strengths built up over years. It was simply an agenda to narrow the focus of advice going to government, and to plonk it totally within the perusal of Treasury.

The Productivity Commission was spoken of only in the context of expanding the functions of the Industry Commission, not in terms of taking on the roles fulfilled by BIE or EPAC. Ironically, though, Mr Howard quoted figures generated by EPAC in another section of that famous—some would say infamous—headland speech.

These two bodies are being dissolved. They have had a very influential impact in the policy process and debate in this country. EPAC has produced some excellent and influential reports across a range of policy areas. The report by the private infrastructure task force is one example of the EPAC work which led to changes in government policy, in this case in the area of infrastructure bonds. The report into child care provides another example of where some of EPAC's recommendations were adopted.

Labor did not support all these conclusions but we recognised the quality of the work and did not seek to silence the body that produced them. EPAC also performed the important task of conducting research into various long‐term economic issues. Examples included labour market matters, investment and economic growth, the effect of tariffs on economic growth and a range of demographic issues.

The Bureau of Industry Economics examined a multitude of industry issues during its existence within the industry portfolio. One important function was the publication of international performance indicators in the context of benchmarking studies. Both general reports and those concentrating on specific industries were produced by the BIE.

Other important publications included various reports into regional trade policy, such as occasional paper 29 which examined the potential gains to Australia from APEC, and report 95/17 which examined the impact of closer economic relations with New Zealand. Other areas included infrastructure pricing, energy efficiency and the greenhouse issue and its effect on business in Australia. These few examples show that EPAC and BIE did have discrete complementary roles in the provision of advice and research and should not have been abolished.

This behaviour shows the agenda of the Liberal‐National Party government, which is to get rid of alternative public policy advice. This is also reminiscent of the behaviour of the current government when it was in power during the early 1980s when alternative views were silenced, when those who disagreed with the New Right agenda were denied preselection.

The second major concern is the result of centralising economic and industry policy advice. The virtual monopolisation of economic policy advice under the treasury portfolio will be bad for Australian industry and bad for cabinet. There will now be no body reporting independently to the industry minister as the BIE used to. There will now be no body reporting independently to the Prime Minister as EPAC did. Treasury's record is not such as to inspire absolute and total confidence in its capacity to get things right, particularly if the only advice comes from its own stable. I know that the Treasury officials are glued to their TV sets watching the in-house coverage of this particular debate as they do with all the economic debates and question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are having a good giggle at the moment.

—I'll take that interjection. We note that that is an innovation of the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer which is designed to instantly pick up areas that occur in debate and transmit them here into the parliament. I am sure Senator Campbell will be on the phone, as Senator Kemp is on the phone during question time, receiving the corrections to responses they give to this parliament—
—They're on the phone a lot, aren't they?
—They should have learnt a lot. I am sure that in Senator Short's case, Senator Mackay, he wished he had learnt a lot. Anyway he is off to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
—He's got volumes on you.

—I will take that interjection. I bet he wishes, Senator Campbell, that, with respect to his performance in this chamber, he had had that sort of snappy policy advice that has been introduced by the Treasurer and Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, Treasury's record is not such as to inspire confidence in its capacity to get every thing right, particularly when the advice is from its own stable. We only have to look at the effect on the Australian economy of the last two budgets. We can debate a lot about the pace and desirability of reductions in government expenditure and the level of government debt, but one thing we do know—certainly, Mr Macfarlane from the Reserve Bank and even the head of Treasury, Mr Evans, have acknowledged it publicly—is that the sharp contractionary nature of the last two budgets has had a significantly depressing effect on consumer sentiment and confidence in the broader economy. That was significantly underestimated. If any of the government members and ministers were listening to broader community views during the parliamentary break they would have become only too aware of the very low level of confidence not just in the broader community amongst consumers but also amongst areas such as small business.

The opposition is not against Treasury nor the agencies in the Treasury portfolio. Rather, we argue for a plurality of views coming from a plurality of sources—quite literally, a competitive model on the provision of economic and industry policy advice to govern ment. As I said earlier, the government is always talking about choice and competition but, when it comes to advice to Treasury and to the Treasurer (Mr Costello), it wants a monopoly.

There is not a monopoly of wisdom within the Treasury portfolio, although I acknowledge what I consider to be a very competent series of men and women who provide advice in Treasury. I recognise their qualities and the intelligent, considered contributions they make, but they are not always right. Therefore, the provision of advice should not be concentrated within that portfolio.

The provision of advice should be contestable, for the same reason that other spheres should be contestable: that is, because the quality of the product will generally improve in a competitive situation. This is advice that Treasury itself would provide on a daily basis, yet, ironically, it is not being followed by the government, which is supposed to be pro competition.

What this legislation is doing is further marginalising the contribution of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) in the economic debate. After the election you could almost see Treasurer Costello rubbing his hands with glee at this proposal—which I am sure came from Treasury—to minimise and shaft the contribution of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, and the minister in particular, in the context of industry policy debate and economic debate in this country. You can just imagine the glee of Mr Costello when he saw this proposal coming across his desk: `Here's a way I can grab more power and bring more responsibilities under the control of Treasury.' The current Treasurer has pursued a consistently arrogant approach. It has been a hallmark of his style since the election of the current government last year.

Our third concern is about the context in which the Productivity Commission may operate. There is no requirement in this legislation for the commission, when providing its advice, to have any regard to the real world in which Australian industry has to operate. Recent reports concerning tariffs indicate the overly theoretical nature of the commission's work. During estimates I had the opportunity to speak to Mr Kerr, the head of the Industry Commission, and my colleague Senator Watson, who is now coming into the Senate, asked Mr Kerr a number of very incisive questions, about textile tariffs in particular. I know Senator Watson shares Labor's concern—and Labor's demand—that the issue of the interim report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries should be responded to forthwith and that its recommendations should be largely rejected. In this context, Labor has called for a freeze in tariffs and continued support for the import credit scheme—which the Industry Commission has recommended be abandoned in the year 2000. We should take careful note of what our competitors are doing in this area.

I want to make a particular comment about my own home state of Tasmania. There are 2,000 jobs at risk in Tasmania. There are six major companies involved. One is Blundstone's, and I am sure I do not have to relate here the importance of Blundstone's and its very impressive record. It has 330 employees in Hobart. We have Sheridan Australia in Hobart, with 125 employees. We have Waverley Woollen Mill in Launceston with 93 employees. We have James Nelson with 81 employees in Launceston. In Devonport, Australian Weaving Mills has 280 employees and Tascot Templeton has 220 employees. Based on the Industry Commission recommendations, we certainly cannot be confident that the Productivity Commission bills we are dealing with will be dealt with in a balanced way, and we call on the government to respond to this interim report as quickly as possible.
There has been some other work carried out by the Industry Commission which we believed was seriously flawed. The motor vehicle industry report is another example that comes to mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every job in Tasmania is an important one.

—I agree, Senator Watson. With a 13 per cent unemployment rate—and that is increasing steadily—on the north‐west coast and an unemployment rate of just on 11 per cent statewide, we cannot afford to lose one additional job in Tasmania from current industries. This is an example of a rural and regional economy that is suffering—particularly at the present time—from the contractionary cuts of both a federal Liberal government and a state Liberal government.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor strongly believes that the legislation should require the commission to have regard to the international trading practice of our trading partners and competitors: that is, what progress is being made by other nations to reduce tariffs and non‐tariff barriers. This advice should also be mindful of Australia's international obligations. This should be formally required of the commission, to help dispel the fear that many people have that the new body will be overly theoretical in its approach and, hence, too dismissive of the real conditions which Australian industry is facing. If the government opposes this proposal, effectively they are admitting that what they want is advice couched in the context of theory rather than of reality.

Our fourth concern again relates to the context of the commission's advice, especially the regional impact of any advice. I have drawn the attention of the Senate to particular examples relating to my own home state of Tasmania.

Our fifth concern, mentioned in our second reading amendment, relates to competitive neutrality. Labor supports competitive neutrality for business markets within the Australian economy—we did more to achieve this desirable outcome than any previous government—but Labor believes that competitive neutrality should apply equally across both the public and private sector. Government businesses should not enjoy unfair advantages which are not enjoyed by their competitors. There should be mechanisms to sort out whether advantages exist and to remove these if they do not have public benefit. Labor also believes that public sector businesses are sometimes disadvantaged in competing against the private sector and that this has the consequence of denying consumers additional choice in some markets.

While we support the appointment of a complaints body for the competitive neutrality reasons, Labor considers this function should be undertaken by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and not by the Productivity Commission.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on Sunday, 31 August 1997, of Diana, Princess of Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following address to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second be agreed to—
"Your Majesty:

We, the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, have received with profound sorrow the news of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales. On behalf of the Australian people, we express deep sympathy to Your Majesty and other members of the Royal Family, especially their Royal Highnesses Prince William of Wales and Prince Henry of Wales, and we mourn the loss sustained by so many people.".
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sitting of the Senate is suspended till 3 p.m. as a mark of respect for the deceased.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 2.02 p.m. to 3 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. What is your response to reports in the weekend press that by mid‐ to late‐1998 the value of the government's health insurance incentive scheme will have been fully wiped out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is an entirely hypocritical question coming from the opposition. After 13 years where they deliberately set out to try to destroy the private health system, they are now crying crocodile tears. The sheer hypocrisy of this sort of attitude by the opposition astounds me. The previous Labor administration oversaw a fall in the drop‐out rate in private health insurance from 64 per cent—it was before you came in, Senator Gibbs, so we can't blame you personally for it—to 30 per cent, so I cannot believe that, now, because we are trying to prop it up and trying to assist people to stay in private health insurance, you come up with these hypothetical questions as to where it will be.

ANSWER.PARA: We saw the shadow minister in the other place last week attacking us and basing it on the figures that ended on 30 June—before these changes were introduced by the government. It will be some time, Senator Gibbs, before we will know the outcome. But, I can assure you, things would be a lot worse if those changes were not introduced, if we did not bring those in as a result of our policy, because at least we are attempting to prop up private health insurance. Nobody knows—we cannot forecast—what the value will be. We do not know; and we will not be hypocritical about that. We will wait to see what those change produce and then we will assure you that it would have been a lot worse had something like that not been done, because it was in free fall under the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's still in free fall!
—It was in free fall. It would have been a lot worse if we had done nothing.
—How much worse?
—Your government—when you were in government—deliberately set out to destroy the private health system. We are at least attempting to do something, Senator Gibbs.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question might be hypocrisy and you say that you are trying to prop up the private health insurance scheme but why is it that, despite the Prime Minister's personal involvement in this policy area, Australians are paying ever‐increasing private health insurance premiums and the companies themselves are facing serious solvency problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the supplementary question because the reality is that these changes were brought in by the opposition when they were in government. No matter what they say about anything that we bring in—
—What changes?

—The changes that caused the demise of the private health system, including the taking away of the bed day subsidy. Before you came here, Senator Forshaw, the bed day subsidy existed—it was taken away by the Labor government—so that people who went into private hospitals had a bed day subsidy. My memory is longer than yours, Senator Forshaw, and I can assure you that those changes that were brought in by the Labor Party spelt the doom of the private health care system as it now exists. Hypocritical is the word, Senator Gibbs, and you were quite correct in admitting that hypocrisy when you asked your supplementary question.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will he outline further good news for the Australian economy which was so badly undermined by 13 years of Labor mismanagement? What message does Saturday's overwhelming victory by the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory send in terms of support for coalition government policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for that important question. It does give me the opportunity to remind senators of more good news on the economic front. Some senators on the other side might have missed that news last week. The first part was in fact that Australia's current account deficit—bequeathed by the previous Labor government—has been reduced by 19 per cent from the 1995‐96 deficit. That is good news, and it is a demonstration of the benefits of sound economic planning. There was further good news in relation to capital expenditure. New capital expenditure was announced: a rate 14 per cent higher than in the previous year—another endorsement of coalition economic policy. Of course, this good news was accept ed overwhelmingly last weekend by the voters in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Shane Stone and his team on an unprecedented sixth straight win. Senator Collins, why won't you smile; it is a great victory for northern Australia! Senator Collins has taken himself to the back bench to concentrate on northern affairs but we can tell him it is not necessary because, between the coalition government in Canberra and Shane Stone's team in Darwin, Northern Territorians are well looked after. Northern Territorians responded to good economic judgments such as the announcement that the railway will go ahead. Finally, after nearly 100 years of promises by governments, the Howard government delivers. That has been very much welcomed by Territorians, as we saw at the weekend, because they know that it is important to their long‐term economic viability. It will give great opportunities for further economic expansion and will lock into the new port in Darwin.

TALK.START.PARA: —The campaign was disgraceful.
—That is right; all the Labor Party can say is, `Disgraceful.' Don't give them a fair go. The railway will lock into the new port in Darwin and provide expanded economic opportunity.

ANSWER.PARA: We saw another good sign for the future of the territory last week when the Jabiluka uranium prospect jumped a very high hurdle in relation to environmental safeguards.
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of interjection is too great.

—I take the interjection from Senator Collins because it reminds me of what he said about that prospect in 1996. What did he say? In speaking about Jabiluka and Koongarra, he said, `Of course they have passed vigorous environmental impact statements.' But he said that, whilst they might be environmentally safe, they were politically deadly. Isn't that so typical of the Labor Party? In other words, they pass the environmental standards, it is good economic judgment but you do not do it because it requires a hard political judgment—a judgment that the Labor Party was not prepared to take.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that that mining prospect has at least jumped these standards is good news for territorians. It will provide more jobs and economic investment. In fact, it is believed that when that mine goes ahead, it will produce some $12 billion of revenue. That is the equivalent of 380 new jobs for the Northern Territory and over $200 million in direct economic royalty payments to the Aborigines. That is a really positive outcome that will be provided consistent with the highest environmental standards. That is what this government is all about and that is what the Northern Territory is all about and that is what Australians applaud—make sound economic decisions, give the people the opportunity for development in jobs but do it according to the highest environmental standards and you will be awarded by the voters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I noted with interest the very important information that the government leader was providing to this chamber, despite the interruptions attempted by the opposition. It was obvious that there is further information that could be provided, particularly with regard to the benefits to Australia of the opening up of additional uranium mines, in particular, the Jabiluka mine, to which he was referring.
