I would ask him to provide that further information to us.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question suggested hypocrisy on this side of the chamber. Where could there have been greater hypocrisy than in the Labor Party's three uranium mine policy? In other words, the third uranium mine was fine; there was something inherently evil about the fourth. What nonsense! They are simply not prepared to take difficult political decisions. It is interesting because when they were in opposition, they joined with the coalition and they acknowledged that uranium mining can be safe.

ANSWER.PARA: You have reminded me, Senator Chapman, of the important report of the committee that you chaired on this very subject. It said:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and con trolled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.

Two ALP senators were on that inquiry. In other words, the Labor Party knows that uranium mining can be safe. It knows that it can provide jobs and economic opportunity. It just was not prepared to take hard political decisions in government, and that is one of the reasons why it is out of government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the financial reserves of private health insurance funds are eroding rapidly? Is it a fact that the industry is expected to record a loss this financial year of as much as $100 million compared with $81 million lost last year and a $62 million profit in 1995? Can you confirm that the Prime Minister will be forced to approve premium increases to Medicare Private and other health insurance funds before Christmas in order to protect their solvency? How do you reconcile these developments with the minister's statements at the time of the 1996 budget that coalition measures would make `private health insurance more affordable for families' and that they would `reduce the upward pressure on the cost of private health insurance premiums'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —That is yet another hypocritical question. We are going to get a series of hypocritical crocodile tear questions from the other side. Now we have the Labor Party standing up for the private health insurance associations. I did not think that I would live to see the day because they have been trying to destroy them for 13 years. Now they are crying crocodile tears about the private health insurance associations and the troubles that they are getting into.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, I remind you that if you look over that 13-year history of what occurred in private health insurance, you will see it has been in free fall for a long time under the Labor Party. Senator Forshaw, I have no doubt that those figures that you are now producing are accurate. I would not doubt the figures because the figures were worse under the Labor Party. They have been worse at various times under the Labor Party. Senator Forshaw comes in here now crying crocodile tears and talking about the free fall occurring in the private health insurance associations. Yes, they are in trouble, because of the policies that you brought in when you were in government. We have only just brought in our changes—as of 1 July—to try to stop that free fall.

I would like Senator Forshaw to tell me how many increases were knocked back by the Labor Party when they were in power for 13 years. I can answer the question for you. None—a big fat zero. You never knocked back any increases that were asked for by the private health insurance funds. Not one did you knock back.

These matters will be considered by the minister, as he said. I am sure they will be considered by the cabinet. With the difficulties that are there, we will certainly try to ensure that the private health funds are maintained in a solvent state. I have no doubt about that whatsoever. It is essential that they should be so because the continuation of the private hospital system of this country boosts the public hospital system because each one per cent, as you know, that goes out of private health insurance costs the states over $100 million in extra costs. So there are major problems as a result of this occurring. Certainly, the funds are probably in trouble, as they have stated. We will look at them responsibly to see what can be done to keep them in a solvent state.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for acknowledging the hypocrisy in the minister's statements that I read out in the question, because certainly all of his predictions are actually coming to zero. Minister, is your government still committed to reducing the upward pressure on the cost of private health insurance premiums, or have you just put this matter in the too-hard basket along with unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —We can see the Labor Party attitude: put it in the too-hard basket. That is what he is saying—either/or. It is obvious that we are boosting the private health funds and we are attempting to keep people in them. We have been promoting them both in opposition and in government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not unusual for reserves to run down. They have run down, as I have said, in the past. It is not unusual for them to do so. Funds are required to retain certain levels of reserves, and from time to time they fall below those levels, and that is what has occurred at the moment. That can occur because of unpredictable increases in benefits paid or the seasonal changes in the industries. Those levels of reserves are monitored constantly, and the government is well aware of the situation with the funds at any point in time.
We are not putting it in the too-hard basket, as you had done in government, Senator Forshaw. Not only did you put it in the too-hard basket—

TALK.START.PARA: —They did nothing.
—Not only did they do nothing, Senator Hill; they deliberately tried to bring about the destruction of the private health system of this country because of their ideological fixations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, the coalition's 1996 election policy document `Better communications' included the commitment with respect to postal delivery: `Those remote households which currently receive a roadside delivery only once a week will be provided with a twice weekly service, wherever possible.' Can the minister inform the Senate of progress in implementing this commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to say that this was an important commitment that we took to the last election and it is one on which we have delivered. In 1992 the Industry Commission recommended that twice weekly mail deliveries be provided to remote Australia. They did that after travelling around the countryside and carefully examining the needs of people in remote areas and making a judgment about how we could improve the quality of postal services.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party of course had some years to act on that. They simply chose to do nothing. Even after we had gone out there prior to the last election and said this was a very important recommendation, they thumbed their noses at the bush and of course they got their just deserts. People in rural Australia in this and in a whole host of other areas made it abundantly plain that they knew what Labor stood for: a few small elites in the capital cities and beyond that they could not give a damn. That is why we regarded this as a very important commitment and we were not prepared to ignore the opportunity to improve communications in regional Australia.

I am pleased to announce that we have in fact now met that commitment, which enables the coalition government to deliver on yet another of a whole series of commitments to regional Australia. Australia Post polled those communities which previously had received only one roadside delivery a week. Where the majority of households in a location voted for an increase, twice weekly deliveries will now be implemented as delivery contracts are renewed. As a result, more than 1,400 households across Australia will receive twice weekly deliveries, at a cost of more than $1.4 million—households in some of the most remote areas of Australia, including Tibooburra, Cooktown, Oodnadatta, Mount Price and Wentworth.

Australia Post, its agents and contractors are to be congratulated on assisting the government in delivering on this important election commitment to regional Australia. I see that Senator Bourne seems to have joined this emergency session of the sandpit club. I am surprised that she would not at least have, on behalf the Australian Democrats, been pleased about this good news for regional Australia. Australia Post is certainly one of Australia's best performing government business enterprises. It is respected around the world as a leading postal service. There is no doubt that its commitment to rural Australia is very much exemplified by this announcement.

We are of course looking at other ways in which postal services might be made even more efficient in order to boost consumer welfare in the postal services sector. Not just in that sector but in a whole range of other areas the services that we have delivered in the bush are there as an enduring legacy of this government and stand in stark contrast to Labor's total failure to deliver in any of those major areas: $1.25 billion over six years for the Natural Heritage Trust, $696 million on the national highway project, $112 million to roads of national significance, $36 million on the road safety black spot program, $11.8 million over three years for the supermarket to Asia strategy—the list goes on.

It is quite clear that in the area of telecommunications there are a number of very important initiatives that we have taken in terms of upgrading the modernisation of the network, such as enabling people to get fast dial-up service to the Internet, and in a whole range of areas so that people are no longer treated as second-class citizens, as they had the pleasure of being treated for some 13 long years.

I just hope that Labor will learn its lesson. Postal services are a very important component of keeping in touch in the bush and we have now, together with Australia Post, made sure that another 1,400 households will get twice the quality of service that they have been getting up until now.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, I refer you to the letter Mr Howard sent to all public servants on 28 February last year in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I give you my rock-solid guarantee that the Coalition will not cut and destroy public sector superannuation schemes or the entitlements of existing and prospective Commonwealth Government employees.
Will the government stand by Mr Howard's rock solid guarantee?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed that the ALP has been putting out press releases seeking to foreshadow decisions that the government might make in this particular matter. I think the short answer is that Australian public servants are much better off under this government in terms of greater flexibility in their employment and they will be in terms of having greater options in relation to superannuation. I would have thought that is not only consistent with the promises that have been made by the Prime Minister in the past but also something that will be applauded by public servants.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is a rock solid guarantee a core promise or a non-core promise?
—What I have said is that I am sure Senator Conroy will be disappointed when he finds that the coalition keeps yet another promise.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Is the minister aware that a clause in the IT outsourcing specification for the Australian Customs Service insists that PC suppliers, which currently ship at least 250,000 PCs a year, must be used? Is the minister aware that Australia's largest PC supplier ships less than a third of that number and would, like all other Australian suppliers, be excluded from tendering? If the minister acknowledges this, what steps will be taken by the government to allow Australian suppliers to tender for this and future IT outsourcing contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume this is a question from the official opposition spokesman for the Public Service. When I got a couple of questions last week from Senator Allison I actually wondered who Labor had in that capacity. What did I discover? Senator Faulkner is the shadow minister for politics. So, by default, let me answer Senator Allison, who actually does have a genuine interest in the subject apart from simply going through the motions.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been reports that smaller indigenous IT suppliers have been concerned about a clause in the Australian Customs Service request for tender document that will preclude them from bidding for the provision of PCs. The request for tender uses the Gartner Group standard for ranking PC suppliers, which in effect would limit the supply of PCs to multinational vendors—that is the claim. The customs RFT does not in fact restrict PC suppliers to tier 1 and tier 2 Gartner Group standards as suggested in the article.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Too late now, you had your chance. Provision has been made for prime contractors to offer PCs that are not tier 1 or tier 2. The government does not intend to exclude existing PC suppliers from the ongoing supply of PC equipment as a result of outsourcing under the whole of government initiatives. However, the government will require acceptable standards be maintained during the life of any outsourcing contract. Therefore, the government will require that PCs and other workstation hardware must be of a standard that is acceptable to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: PC equipment that is currently available to the Commonwealth under PE common use arrangements will satisfy this requirement, subject to review of each supplier's PE status from time to time in accordance with the existing practices. The government does not intend to restrict PC suppliers to Gartner tier 1 or tier 2 companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Has your attention been drawn to comments by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, John Moore, that the Public Service is full of wimps? Can you confirm, as Mr Moore asserted, that the quality of service provided by bureaucrats has fallen significantly over the past decade? What evidence do you have to support this claim? Do you agree with Mr Moore that departmental secretaries once carried some weight and were people who were really significant Australians but now presumably are not? Do you believe it is because, as Mr Moore states, `If you pay people peanuts you get the obvious results'? Or do you subscribe to Mr Max Moore-Wilton's view that he is no longer motivated by remuneration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume you aren't either, Senator Ray, otherwise you would have taken the job that was going begging. It was a gaping hole, money for jam if ever I saw it, but for some reason you chose not to take it. I commend you for that. Maybe you realised what a poisoned chalice it was. The reports of Mr Moore's speech, which I presume Senator Ray has read, show that Mr Moore said:

ANSWER.PARA: In the last 10 years, because of politicisation in the Public Service and the changes of government that has affected them, the general professionalism in the Public Service itself tends to get a bit wimpish.

That should not come as any surprise to Senator Ray. I would have thought you were one of the principal architects of ensuring that the advice you got at the highest levels was very much consonant with your political view of the world. Mr Moore was simply making the point that if you are going to move away from the commitment to fearless, robust and frank advice, if you are going to make sure that they sing your political song, then you run the very risk that you downgrade the quality of the advice you get.

Mr Moore was I think also drawing attention to the fact that if you look around Australia you will find that public servants in some state jurisdictions are actually earning higher levels of remuneration—although, in some respects, probably on shorter term contracts—than they are in the Commonwealth Public Service. That again is a matter that goes to the quality of the service, the professionalism that is on offer and the people that you can attract.
Mr Moore-Wilton, I am sure—and I have not seen any direct quote, but I would be very surprised if he went quite as far as you suggested—but to the extent that he was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the evidence, you dope!

—Well, to the extent that he was saying that there is more to life than money, I think we would all agree with him. If you are wanting to take the money you would not be working in the Public Service. You are here because you are interested in the issues; you are here because you want to play an important and meaningful role in govern ment; and you also would like to be reasonably well remunerated. I would be very surprised if Mr Moore-Wilton was offering to forgo his salary. But, certainly, I would imagine that he wants to see the proper balance being struck. That is a concern that Mr Moore had, and a concern that would be shared by many in government.

ANSWER.PARA: Go back to the start. Reflect on what you managed to achieve over 13 years of politicisation and understand that the consequences of that are quite often that you do attract a narrower category of public servant with a much more political view of the world. That is not in the best interests of decision making in this country.

I think there is more to be said on this front. Certainly we take it seriously because we want to have the best quality advice on offer and we want it to be irrespective of the political views that might privately be held by public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. On the point of politicisation, would the minister like to identify—given Mr Moore's criteria of wimps and no significant Australians—which of the following public servants are not significant Australians: Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, Mr Philip Flood, Mr Tony Ayers, Dr Allan Hawke, Mr Stevens, Mr Sedgwick or Mr Ted Evans? Would he like to identify one departmental secretary who falls into the criteria laid down by Mr Moore?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not propose to rise to that particular bait. I would have thought it was axiomatic. If you want to take people on board because of their political views—
—Name one!
—You well know that there are people who have come from political offices to head up public service departments.
—Name them!

—If you do not know them, it simply demonstrates to you that you took this is as second nature. This is part and parcel of the process. What is important is to understand that you have to draw the line. You ought to make a distinction between political advice. That is why you have a ministerial office on the one hand and a public service on the other. Your view of the world would say, `There really is not much of a difference. They are all there to make sure we get re‐elected. We are only interested in the politics of the issues and, unless they subscribe to our view of the world, we do not want to know about it.' That is not our approach. We are interested in quality. We are interested in merit. It is a great shame that what you did was keep the lid on their salary levels and at the same time insist on people toeing the line. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to his response to the question on notice by Senator Murray on 27 June relating to the environmental impacts of the proposed expansion of Clough's Useless Loop saltworks adjacent to the Shark Bay world heritage area, and I ask: how can the minister be so confident of the advice from the WA government that there will be no impact on world heritage values, when to my knowledge the Department of Conservation and Land Management has not been granted access to the area in question to undertake research?

QUESTION.PARA: Was the Commonwealth part of the process which granted an extension of the salt lease last year in the absence of any environmental assessment of the values of the lease area? Given that there are yet to be submitted scientific findings that the lower hypersaline end of the western gulf, including the lease area and world heritage area, is the sole habitat of unique marine species, in particular a new form of pink snapper, what action will the minister now take to make sure that the state government advice reflects this discovery in this portion of the western gulf of Shark Bay and what action will the government take to protect the species? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable senator knows, this area—
—Have you been there?

—Yes, I have and I was about to tell Senator Cook that this area of property is not within the world heritage area. It is one of a number of commercial activities that take place in the vicinity of the world heritage area. Yes, it is important to ensure that such activities—and in particular any expansion of such activities—are not detrimental to the world heritage values nearby.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that, when representations were made to me expressing concern about this expansion I did cause inquiries to be made to satisfy myself that the environmental impact studies were being properly effected under Western Australian law. As I recall it, the advice that I received—which I confirmed to Senator Murray in answer to a question—was that, yes, on all such advice this expansion would not have any detrimental effect upon the world heritage areas. That is the important point. It was an issue that was raised and it is an issue which I am confident is not going to inhibit such values.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 18 months have you opened anything to world heritage, or have you just mined it all?

—In answer to the interjection, the point is that we are actually interested in economic development as well. We are interested in jobs, but we do say that such development has got to be consistent with high environmental standards. All you were interested in was stopping development. That is one of the reasons we got record unemployment under your regime. That is why so often—

—I raise a point of order. Senator Hill has not answered the question about new, unique species which have not been scientifically dealt with at the moment. The specific question is about how you deal with information that has not yet been provided to you by the state government—information that they have not bothered to get yet.
—I think Senator Hill was distracted by Senator Schacht and he still has a considerable amount of time left to give to Senator Margetts' question.
—Senator Margetts does raise an important point and that is that tomorrow's science will always be better than today's science, but you have to make these judgments on today's science.
—That is profound!

—Some people do not understand that. When information is brought to my attention that suggests that there are new values that need to be interpreted or protected, then I will act accordingly. Now that you have raised that matter, I think it was actually raised in earlier correspondence and taken into account, but I will pursue it and see that it has been adequately dealt with within the various assessments.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I believe there are likely to be a number of new species in this area and the point is that the studies have not been done. Obviously this will affect the world heritage areas if these are the only regions where they breed. I ask the minister: what does this say about the inadequacy of the process and the cumulative impacts of development in Shark Bay on world heritage areas? Fishermen have been fined for feeding the dolphins when they brought the dolphins there in the first place, but you are prepared to oversee the destruction of species. You are not even prepared to find out whether they exist yet, because the Western Australian government has not done the studies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Shark Bay is a very important natural resource. It is quite a unique and exquisite natural resource with values that must be protected. They will be protected by this Commonwealth government in accordance with not only our legal obligations but our belief that they are values that are entitled to be experienced by future generations as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Shark Bay is an area where we do have competing interests. There is tourism that you mentioned and you also mentioned the salt industry. There are other activities such as fishing, pearl growing, et cetera, and it is important to ensure that such activities remain compatible with world heritage values and that regimes are put in place to ensure that those world heritage values are protected. That is a responsibility that this government is willing to accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, I refer you to the Prime Minister's statement on 30 October 1996: `There is a world of difference between a decent market rate and a salary of over $2 million.' Can you confirm that Telstra's chief executive, Mr Frank Blount, has recently received a $500,000 pay rise? Can you also confirm that Mr Blount earned $1.4 million in 1996-97? Can you confirm that this pay rise in the form of a three-year performance bonus comes at the same time that Telstra has written off $1.1 billion to pay for the redundancies of 25,000 staff over the next three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again, Madam President; the politics of envy. The opposition are obviously not prepared to recognise the disparity in government business enterprises and the private sector. As you well know, Telstra is, if not the largest company, probably the second largest company in Australia. Certainly in terms of employment levels it is in the top two or three. So I would have thought that it is very understandable indeed that the chief executive of one of Australia's largest corporations should have a salary level that is roughly commensurate with that on offer in the private sector. That has certainly not been the case to date.

ANSWER.PARA: The CEO's remuneration package is a matter between the Telstra board and the CEO. In other words, the government does not set it. However, Telstra advises that, compared to remuneration paid to CEOs of similar sized companies, Telstra's CEO is paid at the lower end of the salary scale. Telstra has also advised that for the financial year 1996-97 the CEO's remuneration of $1.4 million included a long-term incentive payment accumulated over three years. In previous years the CEO's salary has fluctuated largely as a result of incentive payments.

I do not propose to go beyond saying a person who is running an organisation like Telstra would really need to have a range of skills that are very rarely available in this country. You have to put up with the likes of Senator Schacht rambling on endlessly giving you gratuitous advice about all sorts of mickey mouse issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about you falling asleep?

—That is different. The fact is that running a company of this magnitude requires a very important range of high quality skills, and this country has been very lucky to have Mr Blount in Australia over recent years. Remember that he was appointed during your time. We endorsed the decision at the time and we have continued to support him in that very difficult work. I think he ought to be given an extra entitlement for having to put up with the likes of Senator Schacht, but I am sure he would gracefully decline that.

ANSWER.PARA: The concept of an incentive payment is not unknown in the private sector. Indeed, in many respects it is a very desirable approach to take because it ensures that people simply do not get paid irrespective of performance. I would have thought that rather than being churlish and not concentrating on the main game, as usual, you would be prepared to recognise that this is one of the most difficult jobs in the country and that like many public servants Mr Blount has not been overpaid to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say that it is an extremely curious reason to advance to justify a salary package of $2 million a year. I have been putting up with Senator Schacht for years and I get paid a fraction of what Mr Blount gets paid. In terms of those generalisations that the minister just indulged in, which he said was advice from the Telstra board, and I presume he has advised himself on this issue, what are in fact the market rates that Mr Blount's increase has been benchmarked against?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure, if you want to go and ask Telstra to give you chapter and verse, they will consider your request on the merits. It is an extraordinary proposition. I got up and announced that I had advice from Telstra that the CEO's remuneration of $1.4 million included a long-term incentive payment. So what happens? Senator Collins gets up and talks about a $2 million payment. I do not know where he gets his numbers from. Maybe he ought to go and talk to Senator Schacht on this occasion. I can understand your reluctance to contaminate your mind with the sort of low-grade input that you would be likely to get from Senator Schacht. We are seriously considering reclassifying him as a no-impact facility. We previously had him as a low-impact facility, but I think events have changed for the worse as far as he is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: But the important thing is that, if Senator Collins wants to make contact with Telstra and find out what is on offer in the private sector and what Telstra are paying, I am sure they would be happy to point him in the right direction. I do not say that because I think they are likely to make you an offer—they probably are not—but you never know what might happen out there if you find out what is going on in the real world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.
—Are you still undermining her in the South Australian Liberal Party?
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Could the minister please inform the Senate of the tremendous response from various community organisations to the government's call for pilot work for the dole schemes? Can the minister please also outline to the Senate the benefits that the scheme will provide to both young participants and those in local communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Ferris, for that most astute question. It is a great opportunity—
—That's not what you say about her outside.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, you have been persistently interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. It is frustrating to try to answer questions, only to have Senator Faulkner, who does not have the stomach to misbehave when the cameras are actually on him, to sit here constantly interjecting and sniping like the little school kid that never owned up when he did the wrong thing. When there are school children here, as there are now, they wonder about people like you, Senator Faulkner; they wonder why you will not ever just shut up and listen to an answer. You are just appalling.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has been somewhat inundated with proposals for pilot projects under the work for the dole initiative. The work for the dole initiative, as we all recall, is one of the greatest backflips in history by the Labor Party which occasioned Senator Crowley, who was not laughing at the time, to wander around the parliament like a lost ghost saying, `What do we stand for now?'

Labor initially wanted to oppose the work for the dole initiative and then had to come in here and eat humble pie because, for one reason or another, they changed their mind. Of course, we welcome them changing their mind. They made the right decision.

Some 579 proposals have been received from local councils, schools, sporting organisations, peak welfare organisations and community groups. Early indications, as I am advised, are that the proposals are very innovative and some are of very high quality.

The high demand for these pilot projects clearly indicates that the Australian community has declared its willingness to support young unemployed people and to be participants in the work for the dole initiative. As we know, about 10,000 young people will be participating in pilot projects around Australia. That overwhelming support makes the opposition over there, mercifully, very uncomfortable. They had hoped that work for the dole would fall flat, but in fact that has not happened. We have had an overwhelming response in applications, and the community is very strongly endorsing work for the dole.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections in the chamber.
—Order! Senator Bolkus.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Bolkus tends to interject and make it difficult for other people to hear the answer. He does not tend to put much store in behaviour in parliament. I am sure the young students up there do not think much of you, Senator Bolkus.

BREAK.PARA: The work for the dole initiative offers many benefits to young unemployed people and to local communities. It offers practical work experience, self-esteem, the opportunity to learn something about the work ethic, a sense of belonging instead of being alienated, and the sense of pride and independence that can come from making a contribution.

Projects are going to be located primarily in areas of high youth unemployment and in rural and regional Australia. The department at the moment is in the process of assessing applications. We expect to sign contracts late in September. We would hope that the first pilot projects would commence in mid October.

Clearly, the community supports work for the dole. Labor knows it. That is why it had to do a backflip. I really think that Labor would do well to think very carefully before it further rejects government initiatives for the young unemployed because it will find itself exactly where it is now—having done a backflip with egg on its face because it recognises that work for the dole is an excellent initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, are you aware that the Employment Advocate has approved Australian workplace agreements which allow employees to cash out sick leave benefits? What is your department's view on the eligibility of such employees for the sickness allowance when sick? If they are eligible, does this put an additional burden on taxpayers? If they are not, will this not mean they will receive no income when sick?

—In the time that I have been on the front bench here I have learnt enough to take a second glance at claims made by the opposition as to what is actually happening. I am not aware of the detail of that. I certainly will take the precaution of investigating the fine print of those claims very carefully and give the senator a considered response.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how can you, as Minister for Social Security, explain that the Department of Social Security admitted yesterday to a report of Paul Molloy, as published on page 3 of the Herald‐Sun , and as indicated to me the day before, that workers who swap sick leave for higher wages technically could claim government funded benefits up to $347.80 for a fortnight? A DSS spokeswoman said that new restrictions would be introduced next month. Does this situation not highlight the problem with the Employment Advocate being able to approve AWAs without reference to the public interest?

—I think it is pretty clear that the opposition are so against giving workers choice in their conditions that they would do anything and claim anything to try to diminish value to workers. I would have thought a female senator, of all senators, would have been concerned to see that women workers in particular had more choice than before. Under a union dominated award system women came off second best. The flexibility which Australian workplace agreements will give to workers, particularly women workers, is a great selling point to the Australian work force. Therefore, the opposition would do anything in their power to try to diminish the opportunity for workers to take up the choice that the Australian workplace agreements give them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, why did the Chermside Students Assistance Centre write to the students of the Australian Early Childhood College on 11 August informing students their Austudy payments had been cancelled because the college had `ceased to operate as of 7 August 1997'? Did the centre have any evidence, other than hearsay, to substantiate this claim? Why have DEETYA employees interrogated students in their home and on DEETYA premises for periods as long as of 1½ hours or as many as four times in one day, and why have students under the age of 18 been asked to make written and verbal statements without a parent present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for her question. Senator, I am not aware of the matters that you raise. This is obviously a follow‐up from the question you asked last week. I indicated to you last week that, if you had an example that you wanted to raise, then you should come to me with it. You may have gone to my office. You might like to indicate to me whether or not you have raised that matter. Are you indicating you have?

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.
—Sorry, Senator, have you raised this matter?
—Order! There is too much noise. Senator Vanstone, I ask you to resume your seat until such time as there is silence in the chamber and we can proceed.
—Senator Stott Despoja, I am simply unable to hear—
—Senator, you should be addressing your remarks to the chair.
—Madam President, because there has been so much chit‐chatting by people on the other side—
—If you direct your remarks to me we will get on with it.

—Yes, I am addressing my remarks to you. I am unable to ascertain by sign language from Senator Stott Despoja whether she has raised this matter. If she has raised it with my office I have not yet got the brief back to get to the bottom of it. I will get it as soon as I can and I will get back to her as soon as I can. I just repeat that if she has not given me all the information she has at hand I ask her to do so straight after question time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Indeed my office has made available the information to the minister's office. But is it not the case that your office was first informed of this matter on 14 August—they have an eight‐minute fax transmission to support this—and that the head of the college was told by your staff, `This is a political office, we cannot get involved'?

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, have you not been informed personally of this information? Have your staff made a decision not to inform you? If those events are the case, will you give an undertaking to the Senate now in relation to those students who are waiting for their Austudy payments, some of whom claim they have not eaten in days, that you will investigate and get their Austudy payments to them immediately?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether the head of the college has spoken to someone in my office. Consequently, I am not aware of the conversation that took place. I can tell you this: I would be very, very disturbed if a member of my office sought, as a consequence of being basically a political appointment, to interfere in any investigation that was taking place. I would be very, very concerned with that. You may have a view that if your party were in government you would allow ministerial officers to intervene; but I would not. I will chase the matter up for you and I will come back to you as soon as I have some information.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Can the minister confirm that most social security debt arises from administrative error or oversight and not deliberate fraud? Further, can the minister confirm that most social security debts are repaid by mutual agreement between the person and the Commonwealth services delivery agency, known as Centrelink, to repay the money by instalments? Is Centrelink now overriding these agreements and garnisheeing people's tax returns to repay social security debts? Do people have any review or appeal rights when their tax return is intercepted and paid to Centrelink?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The senator is quite right in saying that fraud against the department is in fairly small proportions in terms of numbers. Unfortunately, however, it means a substantial amount of money in terms of cost to the taxpayer.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I wish that they would allow me to at least explain because clearly this is something that they do not understand despite their 13 years of being in government.

ANSWER.PARA: There are many people who are not committing fraud but who are breaking the social security laws to the extent that the taxpayer, their neighbour, is footing the bill for payment of entitles to which these people are not entitled. People are being paid more than they are entitled to or they are being paid an income support measure for which they have no entitlement at all. They have breached the act because they have not disclosed, for example, their earnings or their living situation.

Your claim at the beginning was that most were due to mistakes or oversight by the department. If that is what you said you are wrong; that is something that I am advised is of the order of about four per cent maximum. Mostly we are talking about people who are breaking the law but they are not perhaps engaged in fraud. It is important, whatever happens, that we clean up the act so that the taxpayers are not spending money that they should not be spending on people who are not entitled. I have already told this parliament a few months ago that we are now saving $19 million per week on money that would have been going to people who are not eligible.

The agency has a responsibility to recover social security debts in a timely manner. Since 1987 legislation has been in place under which, where a customer has a social security debt and is due a tax refund, the refund may be garnisheed in order to repay some or all of the debt. In the majority of cases, tax garnishees were issued for debtors who had no withholdings or other recovery arrangements in place. In some cases customers who are having a portion of their current social security entitlement withheld as repayment towards a debt were subject to the garnishee action. Withholdings are generally limited to 14 per cent of fortnightly payments and, particularly for large debts, do not always represent a satisfactory recovery arrangement.

Where a debtor's tax refund is garnisheed the debtor is notified in writing immediately thereafter and advised of review and appeal rights. In most cases, debtors have not disputed the action. However, where the debtor contacts the agency about the garnishee action, each case is assessed on its merits and, in special circumstances, partial refunds of the garnisheed amount have been negotiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also to Senator Newman. There have been a number of claims about the introduction of the youth allowance, such as that it will force young people to stay in school. Will the minister inform the Senate as to whether these claims are true and what measures are being taken by the government to assist young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for the opportunity to put the facts on the record because Labor seems, once again, to be playing fast and loose with the facts about youth allowance at the expense of young Australians—that is what worries me. It is totally wrong to say that 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds must be in school for the youth allowance—
—Or in TAFE.
—as both the shadow minister, Mr Latham, and parrots like Senator Murphy across the passage here have claimed in this weekend's press. We should be looking out for another Labor lie campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: We in government want to encourage young people to undertake training or education to improve their job prospects. Early school leavers, as I have said in here several times before, are three times as likely to be unem ployed as those who finish with a qualification.

If you are talking about training and education for 16‐ or 17‐year‐olds, that does not mean you have to stay in a school classroom. It is mischievous to suggest that that is the case. There are some exemptions, for example, for under 18‐year‐olds because of illness, homelessness, substance abuse, traumatic home circumstances, job loss or inability to secure an appropriate education place, or other circumstances which make it unreasonable for the young person to undertake full‐time education or training.

There are many opportunities for young people to undertake meaningful education and training in and out of school. In 1996‐97 the government created 52,000 traineeship places, and that was an increase of 44 per cent over the previous year, the last year of the Labor government. There were more than 3,600 inquiries in the first week of the new apprenticeship scheme over the hotline that Dr David Kemp established.

The benefits to these young people from the youth allowance are important. There is less confusion about the different rates of payment and eligibility. It is across‐the‐board equal treatment of young people. Young people living away from home who are under 18 will receive a higher level of payment, including those who are exempt from full‐time study or the training requirement.

Labor surely must understand the good sense behind the youth allowance. If you look at the mini budget back in 1987, the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, said it would remove the financial incentive for young people to leave the education system. He said the new structure was giving a positive message to those who leave school: either find work or undertake training.

The social security minister at the time, Brian Howe, said about the new jobsearch allowance that he hoped would make a difference in removing disincentives, that the government was indicating to young people across Australia that it hoped and expected that young people will not spend lengthy periods of time on unemployment benefits but will get into training, remain in an education program or get some combination of education, training and work. He went on to say that he believed that the unemployment benefit for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds was a payment that in many respects had sent the wrong signals.

The trouble is that they failed to achieve that common youth allowance, which means that there are no incentives to be unemployed; the incentives are all to maintain your contact with the training and education system. It would be very wrong for people like Mr Latham and Senator Murphy to be out there advocating that we keep the status quo. The current system provides more financial incentive for young people to go on the dole rather than undertake further education or training.

It is wrong to give young Australians the idea that they have to stay at school. They have a number of options, but they must acquire skills if they are going to have a chance in the Australia of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, would you withdraw the reference to Senator Murphy you made earlier in your answer.
—Madam President, I withdraw the reflection on Senator Murphy.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —(4.02 p.m.)—Last week Senator Allison, the new Democrats Public Service spokesperson, asked a question about a recent COSBOA study in Cooma on Public Service employment levels. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service (Dr Kemp) has provided some additional information, and I seek leave to incorporate this sheet in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Last year's budget forecast a decline of 10,500 in APS staffing levels in 1996-97.

The 1997-98 Budget Papers include an estimate based on information from agencies that total staff employed under the Public Service Act will fall by approximately 16,500 between 30 June 1997 and 30 June 1998.
The figure of 16,500 fewer people does not equate with job losses. The figure includes:

PARA.TAB: people for whom there is no longer any Commonwealth employment—e.g staff in DAS business units and in areas affected by outsourcing—where a number can be expected to be employed by the successful private sector bidder
people moving from APS employment to other Commonwealth employment—e.g staff moving from DEETYA to the Public Employer Placement Enterprise (PEPE).

SPEECH.PARA: Statistics on APS job losses from centres in regional Australia are unavailable but broad data on the break-up of the voluntary retrenchments from the APS in each State and Territory indicate that the burden is being evenly shared among the States and Territories.

There has been some rationalisation of resources in regional centres by some APS and non-APS Commonwealth agencies as a result of reductions in running costs—these decisions have generally been taken by departments and agencies.

The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia (COSBOA) data on Cooma provides a break-up of the job losses. The main elements of the 361 job losses are the Snowy Mountains Authority (a Commonwealth/State authority—123 jobs); Great Southern Energy (NSW State power utility—93 jobs); Telstra (Commonwealth GBE—31 jobs); and RTA (State Government authority—30 jobs). Only job losses in Cooma Skillshare (4 jobs) and the Department of Education (2 jobs) look as though they could have a relationship at all with the Australian Public Service.
The conclusions of the COSBOA Report about staffing changes in regional Australia are equivocal. The Report states (at page 150) that

"in some cases, especially in the public sector, the overall direct costs to the nation in handling transfer payments and loss of regional infrastructure for example, may outweigh the direct benefits to the agency concerned. But without solid analysis there is not even a beginning of a way for these decisions to be made".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got some further information for Senator Belinda Neal in response to a question she asked me relating to the petroleum sites and franchising acts, and I seek leave to have that incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
SENATOR BELINDA NEAL asked the leader of the Government in the Senate, the Hon Robert Hill, as Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, on 28 August 1997:

When does the Government intend to implement its petrol plan announced by the Treasurer on 11 December to first, end prices surveillance over petrol prices and, second, repeal the Sites Act and the Petroleum Franchising Act after the agreement on a new oil code? Is it true that the government's objective to obtain commitments from the oil majors to allow open terminal access and price transparency is in doubt after Roland Williams, CEO of Shell Australia, wrote to the Treasurer saying that they will sell petrol based on supply contract and that Shell prefers terms of sale?
SENATOR HILL—the Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is committed to encouraging competition in the petroleum retail sector, as it is through competition that consumers are likely to benefit through lower prices. The impact that Woolworths has had on the petrol price in some country areas, where prices have fallen as much as 7¢ a litre in some places, is testament to this approach.

Last December, the Government placed certain conditions on deregulation of the petroleum retail marketing sector, conditions that we believe are important in the interests of competition. Among these conditions were that the Government would lift prices surveillance when it is satisfied that the oil companies had provided certain undertakings on open terminal access and price transparency. Negotiations on these undertakings are well advanced, and the Government remains confident that an agreement will be reached in the near future. It is not possible to place a clear date on when these negotiations will be completed, although it should be noted that it is in the interests of the oil companies to come to an arrangement with the Government on this issue.

The Government has also taken steps to assist the development of a strengthened Oilcode, a matter that we have chosen to link with the repeal of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 (the Sites Act) and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 (the Franchise Act).

A number of issues involved in Oilcode were also identified by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in the report from its Inquiry into Fair Trading. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has indicated that the Government will respond to the Fair Trading report in the near future.

The Government is ensuring that all the pre-conditions that it set in December last year are met before the petroleum retail marketing sector is deregulated. Much effort has been expended in meeting these pre-conditions, which we believe are necessary to ensure that consumers and small business are adequately protected. The Government response to the Fair Trading report, and the ongoing negotiations between the Treasurer and the oil companies, are crucial steps in this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 August 1997, the last sitting day, Senator Hogg asked two questions of me as minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran).

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the question is, what assistance will the government be providing to government departments and Australian businesses in view of the hundreds of millions of dollars they will need to spend to avoid the impact of the millennium bug?

The answer is that Commonwealth agencies have received and will continue to receive advice from the Office of Government Information Technology and other relevant central agencies on year 2000 policy and guidelines for assessment of risks and implementation of compliance strategies. A date standard for the Commonwealth and legal clauses for safeguarding the Commonwealth's interests in contractual relationships with systems suppliers have been promulgated.

The Minister for Science and Technology has circulated information about this problem to small businesses through the National Small Business Forum and has met and communicated with leaders of key industry associations. The minister will continue to publicise the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it!
—I say that I put this answer to the Senate because Senator Hogg is here listening to it. I say that to Senator Faulkner, via the President.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the question is, will the minister confirm that the government will be making no further budget allocations to address the problem?

The answer is that the government is presently giving active consideration to the year 2000 problem, and therefore it is not possible to confirm that the government will make no further budget allocations to address the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given—
or really not given—
by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to a question without notice asked by Senator Forshaw today, relating to private health insurance.

One of the myriad of pledges that this government made in its last budget was that it had the solution to slowing down the decrease in private health insurance membership. It was going to halt the decline. It told the nation that it had the answer, and the answer was to pay a rebate of up to $450 a year, commencing from 1 July this year. That was going to be the panacea that solved the problem of decreasing private health insurance membership.

What did the government do? They actually took $1½ billion of public money and decided that they would pay that by way of a rebate to persons who either had private health insurance or would take out membership in private health insurance funds, and that that rebate would come into operation from 1 July this year. Of course, a large part of that money actually came out of funds that would otherwise have been directed through the health budget into such important areas as funding for hospitals. So the states found themselves suffering a reduction of hundreds of millions of dollars in funds to run their hospitals so that this government could extend a bribe to the people of Australia by saying, `If you just stop resigning from health insur ance funds, we will give you up to $450 a year.'

At the estimates hearing, Senator Herron attempted to deal with this issue and he has again attempted to deal with it today but he has totally failed. He gets up in here and engages in rhetoric about hypocrisy and so forth but the hypocrisy on this issue is demonstrated very clearly by the minister and by this government—the people who claimed that they had the answers. What did Minister Wooldridge say only a year ago? He said:
Every bit of intelligence I can get,—
I do not think he was getting any from his own side—

every bit of feedback from every one of my colleagues, everything I get from my own electorate and every other piece of information that I can possibly get my hands on tells me that what we are on here is an absolute winner.
He said this policy was a winner and only a month or two ago, on 21 May, the minister said this:

We are confident that the incentives package and other reforms we are making, including the Medicare levy surcharge on high‐income people who do not have health insurance, will stabilise the level of private health cover from the beginning of July when people will be able to have their premiums discounted by their fund.

Just prior to 1 July there were reports in the newspapers that thousands upon thousands of people were making inquiries to funds to take out membership in anticipation of the introduction of the levy.

What is the reality? The reality is that fund membership is still declining and it is declining at a rate that is no better—in fact in some cases it is worse—than it has ever been. We also have this despicable spectacle of the funds making further applications for increases. Only recently we have had an announcement that MBF would be seeking a 15 per cent increase in its premiums as well as the introduction of a $50 per night levy for beds in private hospitals. This comes on top of another 15 per cent increase that was approved by the government back in February—all in all, total increases that will amount to over $300 per year, already in excess of the $250 that a couple would receive in a rebate if they remained in a fund or took out membership.

A similar case exists for HCF, and I gave examples of the impact of this on pensioners when we dealt with it in estimates. What is going to happen in this chamber shortly is that a minister or someone else from the other side is going to get up to say, `The Labor government never knocked back any increases.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't.

—That is true. We did not but, Minister, we did not take $1½ billion out of public funds and extend it as a bribe to the people of Australia saying, `If you stay in a health fund, you will get up to $450 a year.' We did not do that. At the same time as granting those increases, you are offering that $1½ billion, which, as I said, was taken out of such very needy areas of the health system as public hospitals. But the people are not buying your bribe because the people still realise that, until somebody such as this government can bring the doctors to heel and deal with the problems of overcharging and the excessive costs of health, we will not fix the problem of declining numbers in private health insurance. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the call, Madam Deputy President.
—Be gentle on him.

—I will be, Senator Macdonald, because the poor fellow does not know what he is talking about. He is trying to come up to speed from opposition, having been in this place a short time, and he is totally unaware.
—I have been in a private health fund all my life so I know what I'm talking about.
—It is a little different, Senator Forshaw, from being here in the chamber.
—It just keeps going up and up and you keep getting less and less.

—Yes, things have been going up. I would like to inform Senator Forshaw of two inescapable facts that occurred even under his government: people are getting older and technology is costing more. The reality of those two things means that, no matter who is in government, there is going to be an increasing cost of health care and you must ally that with the new facilities that are becoming available.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Forshaw talks about bribes. I am sure that the people who do have private health insurance do not regard it as a bribe. It is an attempt to try to stop the free fall that occurred under the Labor government—instituted by them. To give an example and just to show the hypocrisy on this question, Minister Lawrence on 19 May 1995—as Senator Forshaw said there was a concern about people dropping out and that she brought in changes—said:
It won't be immediate and I think in the short term before the legislation starts to operate you'll see increases in the number of people dropping out.
So I would give it a year or two before you start to see that—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right, when you are giving them $1½ billion.
—floor that we are hoping to place under it actually start to operate.
—You are propping them up and they are still asking for more.

—The previous minister thought it would take a year or two before her changes took effect. Senator Forshaw is expecting miracles from 1 July. The figures that he is quoting are the ones up until 30 June. He expects miracles but we will not really know the ultimate figure until the tax returns are done next year because some people will get the rebate, as Senator Forshaw well knows, by tax rebate. He also called it `a despicable application' for increases. They were his words. Were all the applications that occurred in the last 13 years and agreed to by the Labor government also despicable, because that is the description?
—Your minister said exactly the same thing about them.

—They are not. They are only despicable when they occur under a coalition government. When they occurred under the Labor government, they were not despicable. It proves my charge of hypocrisy. Nothing could be more hypocritical than the statement that Senator Forshaw just made—that they were not despicable. When they are made under the Labor Party, they are not; they are despicable when they are under the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Forshaw has not woken up to the fact that the cost of a bed day in a public hospital is much higher than the cost of a bed day in a private hospital for the same procedure. I would ask you, Senator Forshaw, to go back to the books and go back to the figures and check that out because it gives the lie to your statement that, in some way, the changes that we are introducing are taking funds from the taxpayer and giving them to the private system.

It is cheaper to run the private system, Senator Forshaw. If you check the figures, Senator Gibbs, you will see that it is. The cost of a bed day in a private hospital is much smaller than in a public hospital because of the quite legitimate concerns that public hospitals have in relation to the training of medical students, the teaching of registrars and the research that goes on in those public institutions. We tried to tell the Labor Party year after year after year, but there was a fundamental lack of understanding because they were driven by the philosophical approach that Medicare and the full public care of patients were going to be better in the long run. The philosophical drive of the Labor Party led them to that end. They did not realise that the competition provided in and between private hospitals and in and between private hospitals and the public hospitals would lead to greater efficiency.

The more we promote people into the private system the better it is for the taxpayer, Senator Forshaw. It would be better for the taxpayer if we could have that system which we once had—where two‐thirds of the population voluntarily insured themselves through the private system—because it allowed more funds for the public hospital system. More funds per capita were available for the public hospital patients. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue, as everybody here agrees. The test, perhaps, is the fact that people are not going into the private funds. In fact, they are leaving them. There are many reasons for that, some of which have been debated here today. One reason is this: there is a problem not only with the private health cover premiums but also with the amount you have to pay if you do go into hospital. People go into hospital under a private insurance scheme and find that the insurance scheme does not cover the cost of the various procedures that are carried out. So, in addition to the premiums that you have to pay, you have to pay quite substantial sums in addition to the amount given by the private health cover. That is a problem. You have to pay the premium and also that additional amount.

SPEECH.PARA: We can go into the history of what happened over 13 years under the previous government and what is happening under this one, but the big issue—Senator Herron would know this better than most—is that health cover and health care be provided so that all citizens can go about their lives knowing that they will be properly cared for. That is not happening now. Indeed, the system is only running because it is subsidised by those carrying out medical care. The nurses in Victoria are a prime example of how that has happened in recent times. They got to the point where they could not afford to carry the system in the way they had been up to that time. They had to take action—quite militant action as it turned out in the end—to get what was properly theirs. Another example of how the system is subsidised by the health carers is the young doctors who now do not get a provider number—an entitlement taken away by the present government. Those young doctors are working hours and hours to keep the system going.

This problem will not be solved by the government and its representatives in this chamber getting up and saying, `We are doing our best. We are going to give a $450 rebate to taxpayers who take out private insurance.' That is a token, and no more than a token, towards the solution to this problem. What is needed is a solution.

The previous minister for health, Carmen Lawrence, was mentioned by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). At least what she did was to make an attempt to bring this under control. But what can this government point to—besides the $450 rebate and the removal of the provider number from young doctors, who now have to subsidise the system—to show they are trying to make this system a fair and just one? The minister has said that people are getting older. That is a good thing. I hope the minister agrees that it is a good thing, and I hope he agrees that we are entitled to proper care. He is saying that technology is getting more expensive. The government knows the issues. The thing is to address them. You do not address those issues by getting up and saying, `Look, the previous government did not do as much as it should have.'

We look forward. Senator Patterson is about to tell us how we are going to look forward. She is going to take us forward. If not Senator Patterson, Senator Knowles will tell us. Either will do because they both have that forward looking vision. I do not want any mention of the previous government from the next speakers. What I want from them is the vision for the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many times we have had this speech since these people went into opposition, but it is probably about the third or fourth time that we have had these same questions. These are the very people who sought to destroy the private health insurance system. These are the very people who took $846 million out of the private system.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney has just said that we have done nothing other than provide an incentive for people to get into private health insurance. Let me tell you, Madam Deputy President: it would be more than the previous government ever did—if that were all that we had done. But what we have done also was to make people on higher incomes pay an extra one per cent levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never mention that.

—That never gets a mention. But the interesting thing is that these people on the other side—who, sadly, do not know anything about the private health system, which is completely evidenced by the contribution that Senator Forshaw has made—do not realise that former Senator Richardson said only last year, when commenting on the private health insurance system:

BREAK.PARA: One idea I had which had no chance of ever being accepted by my caucus or cabinet colleagues was to charge an increased Medicare levy for high‐income earners who refused to take out private insurance. I was never comfortable with the thought of wealthy people elbowing battlers out of queues in public hospitals.

Former Senator Richardson, as health minister, was unable to get that through the Labor caucus. He thought it was fair; caucus thought, `No, we can't do that to the high income earners.' Former Senator Richardson went on to say:

Everyone has to lose some battles but I wish I had won this one. Now the Liberal Party is putting forward the same idea. Even the thought that the Liberals are prepared to make the rich pay more when the Labor Party would not is enough to scare the hell out of me.

There can be no doubt about where the great majority will stand on this. The vast numbers of Australians earning less than $50,000 a year will reckon that those earning more and able to afford more ought to be paying more. They will be even more convinced of the worth of this proposal if the Coalition adopts the rest of my proposal as well.

But it is interesting because Senator Richardson, in commenting on the Lawrence reforms—reforms that were an absolute and utter disaster, a total failure—also went on to say that `they are also not allowed to believe that the public hospital system will ever find itself unable to cope with the influx of formerly insured citizens, which one day will create one hell of a problem'. These quotes come from the Labor Party side. Why can't the Labor Party recall this information?

Quite frankly, it was the previous Labor government which, as I say, took $846 million out of the private sector. They abolished the bed day subsidy, which Senator Forshaw does not even know about; his eyes just glaze over and revolve around in opposite directions in his scone. They also removed the reinsurance subsidy. These are fundamental changes which were made by the Labor Party that have seen the demise of the private health insurance scheme. Also, of course, they required the funds to pay a 25 per cent gap for medical benefits.

Here we have a situation where the Labor Party are accusing the coalition government, in some weird and wonderful way, of creating a disincentive by providing families with $450 towards their private health insurance. It is totally and utterly illogical. Yet this comes from a party that did not reject one request from the private health insurance companies for fee increases during their 13 years of rule of this country—not one request was rejected. The Labor Party will not acknowledge that—and yet they allowed every single solitary request to go through, with no incentive having been provided to individuals or families.

The 25 per cent of pensioners who have private health insurance deserve assistance. Yet the Labor Party are still saying that they will not provide it. So the question remains in my mind, seeing they are so outrageously loud in their condemnation of this: will the Labor Party abolish the rebate? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to speak on this matter. It is my view that this government's health insurance policy is in a shambles—an absolute shambles—and it should be no surprise to anybody that it is. Figures show that, during the last quarter, total private health insurance membership fell by 1,000 people a day. People are dropping out because it is far too expensive. They are simply not getting value for money.

SPEECH.PARA: Since his intervention, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has allowed about 30 health funds to increase their premiums, and those increases have already swallowed up most of the benefit of the tax rebate for families. The latest Weekend Australian states:

Figures released by the Health Department in May showed that between September 1 last year and May 7, premiums for more than 2.7 million fund members rose by an average of 8.4 per cent—but some exceeded 15 per cent.
The item goes on to say:

The Government is bracing for another wave of premium increase applications to offset hefty losses in the three months to June. The first fund to move was MBF, this week lodging an application to increase premiums by up to 15 per cent.
I repeat: premiums are being increased by up to 15 per cent. The $450 rebate is gobbled up before they even get it.

The incentive package rebate scheme, which was launched only two months ago, is in dire trouble. The scheme is costing the taxpayers $1.7 billion—and it is a scheme which benefits only one-third of the population. Nobody would deny a benefit to low income earners. But the reality is that, to implement this scheme, the government slashed federal funding to public hospitals by $800 million and abolished the Commonwealth health program thus saving another $400 million.

The $1.7 billion, which this government has squandered on a failed health insurance initiative, could have been spent directly on patient care. The money could have kept 6,000 public hospital beds in operation for the next four years. It could have been used to reduce hospital waiting lists. Jeff Kennett described this expenditure aptly as `money flushed down the drain'. The Weekend Australian states:

Figures calculated this month by the Government's health insurance watchdog, the Private Health Insurance Administrative Council spell out the full extent of the industry's financial woes, showing the payback rate has risen from 84c to 97.5c in the dollar over the past decade.
The industry is expected to record a loss this financial year of as much as $100 million, compared with an $81 million loss last year and a $62 million profit in 1995.

This week MBF, probably the largest health fund, applied for premium increases of up to 15 per cent from 1 October. This will cost families another $275 a year. To add insult to injury, MBF also wants a $50 a night fee for staying in a private hospital. If this is allowed, people will be forced back to the public health system. This makes a mockery of the government's plan to free up public hospital beds. People are being priced out of existence as far as private health insurance premiums are concerned.

One wonders where it will all end. If you pay private health insurance you are to be penalised by paying $50 a day for a bed. This, of course, is in addition to the other out‐of‐pocket expenses that private health insurance does not pay for.If a person does opt to receive treatment in a public hospital rather than in a private hospital, MBF pockets about $200 in subsidy paid for private patients in public hospitals. What a disgraceful joke perpetrated on the Australian people, saying that the rebate they will receive will take pressure—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I just find it interesting that people on the other side who never got up to talk about private health insurance now get up to talk about it. I just want to remind them about what some of the previous Labor health ministers said about what their reforms would do to private health insurance—and the cost of it. Then Senator Richardson, in 1993 at a Labor Party conference, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We've got to look seriously at how to get the numbers in private health cover up.
