He said, `The drop last year was dramatic.' He was indicating then in 1993 that the health system was unworkable or in danger if we dropped below 30 per cent of people in private health insurance. In an article in the Australian Financial Review on 22 July 1993, he said:

I told the private health insurance industry in a meeting on Monday this week that I regard it as my task as health minister to ensure that we stop the reduction of health insurance coverage and turn it around to get more people back in by the end of this three years, and we will.

That was prior to the election. They did not do that. All we saw was a continual and steady decline at a very rapid rate in the number of people in private health insurance—down from 64 per cent to half that number by the time they left office. In May 1995, former Minister Lawrence, after bringing in the changes and trying to cover the gap by getting doctors under contracts, said:

It won't be immediate and in the short term before legislation starts to operate we will see increases in the number of people dropping out, so give it a year or two before you start to see the floor that we are hoping to place on it actually start to operate.

It has not started to operate. The legislation is still in place and I think something like 80 doctors have signed up under this wonderful initiative that was instigated under Labor to try to do something about the very problem that the people on the other side are talking about. People get a shock when they go into hospital and find that there is a gap, that their hospital expenses are totally covered but their medical expenses are not. They also get a shock to find that their doctors charge them more than Medicare or the hospital fund will rebate. The Labor Party tried to bring in this initiative. We told them it would not work but they were going to bring it in and they were going to bring the doctors to heel. What happened? Nothing; and we have seen a decline in private health insurance.

As Senator Knowles has pointed out, we have brought in a rebate for people on low incomes who take out private health insurance. Let me tell you that had the Labor Party been in the premiums would have gone up and up and you would not have had your $250 if you were single or your $450 if you were a family. Those opposite do not sit on this side. We need to know whether, if they got back into government, it would be their policy to take away the rebate. The question is: where are their policies? They do not have policies; they are devoid of them and they do not know whether they would take it out or not.

So private health insurance fees went up as a result of Labor's legacy of neglect of the health system for 13 years; and Labor have no policy about what they would do if they got back in—whether they would give a subsidy or not. Senator Gibbs says that in the last quarter there has been a decrease in the number of people in private health insurance. Let me tell you that those figures were taken before the initiative of the rebates came into effect, so the figures do not actually have anything to do with the initiative in terms of the rebates.

They also talked about the fact that the private health insurance premiums had gone up. They went up 12 per cent per annum under Labor. Did we hear any of them screaming out and saying it was terrible, and did we see them stopping it? Not once did one private health insurance fund come to the then Labor government, ask for an increase and have Labor reject it—not once. Every single time Labor approved the increase.

In the last quarter there has been a decrease in the number of people insured but it is based on figures, as I said, taken before the rebate initiatives started. It is the lowest decrease for seven years. In the 15 months since we have been in government there has been a 1.9 per cent drop‐out rate. In the last 15 months of Labor there was a 2½ per cent drop‐out rate. So we are starting to see a reduction in the number of drop‐outs. As the rebate initiatives start to take effect, we will expect to see some change. But you cannot turn the Titanic around. Labor neglected health for 13 long years. They let the insurance go, they took out the reinsurance pool and they neglected private health insurance. The Australian public will pay for that legacy of Labor for quite some time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (A.B.C.) and asks that:
1. The Senate votes to reaffirm its will to maintain the existing role of the A.B.C. as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
2. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the A.B.C.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned with the recommendations of the draft Industry Commission report into the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industries and that acceptance of these recommendations could see a further 1900 Tasmanians lose their jobs.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support Tasmanian Textile, Clothing and Footwear workers by rejecting the Industry Commission's recommendations to slash tariffs and export assistance for this vital Tasmanian industry.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) congratulates Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation (ANTAR) for the successful launch of its Queensland branch in Brisbane on 31 August 1997;

(b) notes that the widest possible representation of the Queensland community was present to lend its support to the indigenous people and express its concern about the Federal Government's 10‐point Wik legislation;

(c) supports pastoralists such as Kerry and Camilla Cowley, from Bollon in south-west Queensland, who helped launch ANTAR and who have worked with the Gunggari people to establish native title over their property; and
(d) recommends that:

PARA.TAB: (i) all Australians should understand the debate about native title, expressed as follows in the words of Camilla Cowley, speaking about the Gunggari people: `They wanted some place to call their own to take their young people for cultural camps and activities, to help address some of the problems all our society is having. They had no desire or intention to take my home, or anyone else's', and
(ii) disputes over native title be resolved by face-to-face discussion and not by extinguishing native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997
Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997
Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997
Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Imposition) Bill 1997
Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997
Sales Tax (Customs) (Alcoholic Beverages) Bill 1997
Sales Tax (Excise) (Alcoholic Beverages) Bill 1997
Sales Tax (General) (Alcoholic Beverages) Bill 1997
Sales Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1997.
I also table the statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during this sittings. I seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997

These Bills amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921 as part of the Commonwealth's safety net to protect State and Territory revenues following the decision of the High Court in the cases of Ngo Ngo Ha v State of New South Wales and Walter Hammond and Associates P,'L v State of New South Wales.

The customs and excise duty will be increased by $ 167 per kilo on tobacco products currently dutiable at $84.27 per kilo and by 8.1 cents per litre on petroleum products currently dutiable at $0.36872 per litre and $0.34697 per litre.

The increases in customs and excise duty rates on these products were implemented immediately by the publication of notices in the Commonwealth Gazette in accordance with section 273EA of the Customs Act 1901 and section 160B of the Excise Act. These notices were published on 6 August 1997 and took effect from 7 August 1997.
These Bills will formally incorporate the increases into the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

Introduction and passage during the 1997 Spring sittings is desirable as the early passage of this package of legislation will provide certainty in Commonwealth/State relations in respect of this issue.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison)
FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (COLLECTION) BILL 1997
FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (IMPOSITION) BILL 1997
FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) (ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES) BILL 1997
SALES TAX (EXCISE) (ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES) BILL 1997
SALES TAX (GENERAL) (ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES) BILL 1997
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Purpose of the proposed Bills: The Franchise Fees Windfall Tax Bills provide for the imposition, determination, collection, and administration of the 100% franchise fees windfall tax which applies to business franchise fees paid before 5 August 1997 which are refunded by a State or Territory. There are also consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to exempt from income tax refunded business franchise fees subject to the windfall tax and to deny an income tax deduction for the tax.

The Sales Tax Bills modify the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to impose a 15% increase in the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages There are also consequential amendments to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 as a result of the increase in the rate of sales tax.

The proposals were announced by the Treasurer on 6 August 1997 in response to a recent High Court decision which held that certain State and Territory franchise fees are invalid under section 90 of the Constitution.
Reasons for urgency: The proposed Franchise Fees Windfall Tax Bills will apply from 5 August 1997. The proposed Sales Tax Bills will apply to dealings from 6 August 1997.

The bills are part of a package of legislation to protect State and Territory revenue. The States and Territories are relying on the legislation to protect their current financial year revenues. To provide certainty it would be desirable if final legislation could be enacted at the earliest opportunity.

Result if the proposed Bills are not dealt with in the Spring Sittings: State and Territory revenue would be greatly affected. There would also be continuing uncertainty for taxpayers. Taxpayers could also face difficulties in organising their affairs and in complying with the law.
(Circulated by authority of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator the Hon Rod Kemp)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Kernot, I withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion No. 3 standing in her name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the celebration of Adult Learners Week Australia between 1 and 7 September 1997, and

(ii) the importance of the national overview of adult education provided in the 1991 report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and the 1996 report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) congratulates the Australian Association of Adult and Community Education (AAACE) for the coordination and promotion of Adult Learners Week;
(c) offers:

PARA.TAB: (i) support to the objectives of Adult Learners Week, including the need to encourage and inspire more adult Australians to participate in lifelong learning and skills acquisition, and
(ii) national recognition to those engaged in learning, teaching, tutoring in areas of adult education and training;

SPEECH.PARA: (d) notes that across Australia more than 2 500 neighbourhood houses, community learning centres, community evening colleges and workers educational associations are providing lifelong learning to more than one million adults; and

(e) congratulates AAACE for continuing to raise the profile of adult education and lifelong learning so as to encourage participation by the 55 per cent of Australians who have no post-school qualifications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the continuing order of the Senate of 1 May 1996 relating to the allocation of departments to legislative and general purpose standing committees be amended as follows:
Under Economics , omit `Industrial Relations' substitute `Workplace Relations and Small Business'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the assistance given by the New Zealand Government to advance peace talks between Bougainvillean representatives from all sides of the conflict for the purpose of ending the 8-year war on Bougainville,

(ii) media reports suggesting that the Australian Government perceives an independent Bougainville as a security threat in its own defence environment, as well as a potential trigger which may lead to the break‐up of Papua New Guinea (PNG),

(iii) an article in the Age of 21 August 1997 which reported that the Australian Defence Force had made secret contingency plans to provide logistic support for a United Nations sponsored peace mission, including the use of the Special Air Services (SAS), specialised troops, planes and supply ships, and

(iv) the call on 28 July 1997 from non-government organisations, churches and unions, including Aidwatch, the Uniting Church, the Maritime Union of Australia, the South Coast Labor Council, the Civil Aviation Authority and Friends of the Earth, for the suspension of military aid to PNG due to the role of Australian assistance in prolonging the war and aiding human rights abuses; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) suspend military aid to Bougainville, particularly at a time when peace negotiations have reached a new level, and

(ii) reject any proposal to allow the use of the SAS, specialised troops, planes or supply ships on Bougainville, as it may destabilise the current momentum for peace and offend the Bougainville Revolutionary Army and the Bougainville Interim Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that Comsuper has declared a credit rating of 20 per cent for its Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme; and
(b) congratulates Comsuper on its effective management of funds which has resulted in this outstanding performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give the following contingent notice of motion.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The contingent notice of motion read as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (contingent on the order of the day for consideration in committee of the whole of the message from the House of Representatives relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 being read)
That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the committee making further amendments to the bill in relation to the sale of mining rights.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee for inquiry and report by 31 March 1998:

PARA.TAB: The direct and indirect impact of cutbacks in federal, state and local government services on regional communities, including:
(a) an assessment of the Australia-wide extent of government service cutbacks and an estimation of the full national economic cost of such cutbacks, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (i) direct and indirect job losses in regional communities,
(ii) direct and indirect loss of income to regional communities,
(iii) the impact upon families living in regional communities,
(iv) an assessment of the impact on economic growth levels in regional communities, and
(v) an assessment of the impact on the quality, accessibility and delivery of government and government-funded services in regional communities;

PARA.TAB: (b) an assessment of which regional communities and areas have been most adversely affected by cutbacks in government services; and
(c) an assessment of the impact on taxation revenues from the loss of jobs as a consequence of cutbacks in government services.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That the committee, as part of its investigation, commission or carry out representative studies of several regional cities and towns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the planned launch of the Cassini space probe on 6 October 1997 by the United States (US) Government from Florida, bound for Saturn, with 72.3 pounds of plutonium on board, the largest amount of plutonium ever to be taken into space,

(ii) Cassini's instruments are to be powered by a radioisotope thermoelectric generator (RTG) instead of by solar cells, using heat emanated from the natural radioactive decay of 73.8 pounds of plutonium,
(iii) the bad track record of rockets of the kind that will transport Cassini, the Titan IV, which has previously blown up after take‐off during a satellite launch,

(iv) reports of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's environmental impact statement on the project, which states that if inadvertent re-entry occurred during the space probe's journey, approximately 5 billion of the earth's 7 billion people could receive 99 per cent of the radioactive exposure, and

(v) the International Committee on Radiological Protection (ICRP) has set the maximum permissible level of plutonium in the human body at 0.00000004 curies, however, the RTGs on board Cassini are carrying 406 000 curies, 1.6 times the total radiation released by all atmospheric nuclear tests to date; and

BREAK.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) urgently contact the US Government to stop the plutonium‐generated spacecraft from being launched, and
(ii) conduct its own investigation into the health and environmental risks of an accident involving the Cassini space probe and its potential effects on Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that 1 to 7 September 1997 is Adult Learners Week;
(b) supports the Adult Learners Expo's goal of lifelong learning and the economic, social and cultural development of Australia; and
(c) congratulates the Australian Association of Adult and Community Education for pro moting community empowerment through lifelong learning.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Joint Select Committee on the Australian Republic

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Bolkus, I withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion No. 718 standing in his name for today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) residents and farmers at Werribbee, south west of Melbourne, protested on 31 August 1997 at the proposal by CSR Limited to fill a disused quarry with prescribed toxic waste,
(ii) the region produces more than 60 per cent of the State's vegetable consumption and would be at risk from the real and perceived danger from toxic contamination,
(iii) 1 500 formal objections have already been lodged, and
(iv) if agreed to by the State Government, the tip will attract waste from other States;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) urges the Victorian State Government to reject this proposal; and

(c) calls on the Federal Government to put in place measures which ensure the reduction or elimination, reuse, recycling and recovery of hazardous materials, rather than their disposal in landfill sites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy and I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, we will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that the inaugural Australian Youth Forum was held in the Old Parliament House from 29 to 31 August 1997, with more than 350 delegates from around the country, aged 16 to 21 years;
(b) congratulates the organisers, facilitators and sponsors of such an inspirational and empowering event;

(c) notes that the conference made recommendations pertaining to racism, youth employment, youth suicide, visions for the future, education, environment, self-esteem, drugs, youth homelessness, entertainment and youth rights; and
(d) calls on all members of the Federal Parliament to read and respond to the recommendations contained in the summary report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes the week-long vigil being conducted in the Bourke Street Mall, Melbourne, by People for Public Housing to draw attention to the crisis in public housing;
(b) condemns the Howard Government for its damaging and unnecessary decision to cut public housing funds to the States by $200 million over the next 4 years; and

(c) calls on the Government to immediately make a one-off $250 million grant to the States for public housing, as suggested in the Democrats' Restoring Confidence plan, a grant which would allow 2 500 extra dwelling units to be built in the 1997‐98 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate, on behalf of Madam President, I present the eighth edition of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice , which has just been published.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor‐General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Audit activity report: January to June 1997 .

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia board on the operations of the bank, together with the financial statements and the report of the Auditor‐General for the financial year 1996‐97.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am taking this opportunity of the tabling of the Reserve Bank annual report to speak about the very worrying inadequacies concerning the composition and method of operation of the Reserve Bank board. There are three aspects I want to concentrate on today: firstly, the fact that the membership of the board is extremely unbalanced; secondly, that the board's governance and modern systems of board accountability are lacking; and, thirdly, that existing practices confirm a clear danger that conflicts of interest and insider trading may be possible.

I will deal with issue of the board's membership first. Essentially, this is a male board—at a ratio of 10:1—and is heavily weighted towards big business making up the majority and Public Service appointees in the minority. In the new year, the government will be appointing two replacement board members to the 11‐member Reserve Bank board. My personal view is that those two appointees should be women to redress the unacceptable gender bias on the board. It is also my personal view that the board interests should be balanced by those two appointments originating from two of the following three sectors: small business, unions, or community and social justice organisations.
There are no formal qualification criteria for the appointment of directors to the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia. Mr Greg Smith from Treasury said:
Basically the person is required to be suitably qualified and without unacceptable conflicts of interest in relation to banking activity or taxation matters.
He or she must also not be a member of the finance sector, as laid out by the relevant act.

Turning to the second problem—poor governance and the lack of modern board accountability mechanisms—on 31 July I put questions on notice concerning the RBA board to be answered prior to the August estimates committee meeting, which they were. I followed this up with estimates questions on 18 August 1997, some of which are still on notice and remain to be answered. The Hansard record at E70 to E73 records my exchanges with the RBA board director, Mr Evans, who also heads Treasury. What is fundamentally apparent from those questions and answers received to date is that the RBA board is singularly and inadequately managed in terms of potential conflict of interest matters, that it has inadequate governance procedures and woefully inadequate practices concerning potential conflict of interest situations.

The third area I wish to comment on relates to the recent publicity surrounding the gold sale by the RBA and the substantial coincidental and simultaneous benefit that one company, whose chief executive officer is also a member of the RBA board, achieved between the time of the RBA board gold sale decision and its public announcement some months later. That director of the board, Mr Hugh Morgan, was, at the same time, the active chief executive officer of a gold company which apparently sold a quarter of its stocks forward in the period affected by this decision and before its public announcement. It should be said, however, that forward sales of gold are standard practice for that industry and are in no way unusual.

The media commentary was exceptionally concerned and it seemed to me that the media was worried that there may have been a perception of insider trading. However, they were extremely judicious and avoided making direct allegations—firstly, because they had no proof; secondly, because they were no doubt afraid of being sued; thirdly, because the governor reassured them that everything was above board; and, finally, as I have said, because forward sales are indeed standard practice.

The problem is: how does the Reserve Bank or parliament itself get to the bottom of a situation where a board member's company may be perceived by the public at large as possibly benefiting during a period when a decision is secret? I and the Australian Democrats have no proof of wrongdoing and make no inference of wrongdoing. However, the board has not appointed an independent person or persons to investigate the issue thoroughly to satisfy themselves, the media and the public that everything was indeed above board. We only have the word of the governor, which, with respect and quite frankly, is not good enough since he is an interested party in this matter and, as co‐director, is not independent enough to be seen to objectively consider the matters at hand.

The Australian Democrats, in noting the inadequacies recently exposed in corporate governance on the Reserve Bank board, do urge the government to provide the board with proposed guidelines to prevent conflicts of interest or insider trading from occurring. To date, I am profoundly concerned at the lack of action of the government on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the appropriateness of current unfunded defined benefit superannuation schemes applicable to judges and parliamentarians, together with submissions received by the committee and transcripts of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in respect of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is often said that there is one matter parliamentarians seldom disagree about: their pay and their pensions. This report shows just how wrong that assertion is. The report deals with two matters: the parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme and the judges' pension scheme. There is little doubt that the parliamentary scheme needs reviewing.

Superannuation and the nature of employment in the wider community have changed significantly in recent years. However, the scheme is now out of step with superannuation in the wider community. It is questionable, however, whether the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation was the best body to do such a review. Many senators, myself included, felt very uncomfortable about this reference because it required sitting parliamentarians to review their own entitlements. Nonetheless, we have done our best with what was always going to be a difficult reference. Unfortunately, we were not able to come up with a unanimous set of recommendations.

At the outset, I should note that the Senate committee is unanimous in respect of the judges' pension scheme. This scheme serves important wider objectives, and we recommend that it be retained with minor modifications. The section of the report that deals with parliamentary schemes is another matter. Essentially, members of the committee were in agreement that there is a need for reform and that the Remuneration Tribunal should play a role in parliamentary superannuation. However, coalition and Labor Party members put forward different views in the report about how the reform should be approached, and the Australian Democrats senator has chosen to put in a dissenting report.

As most senators would be aware, the general public sees the parliamentary scheme as excessively generous. The media does its best to perpetuate this image by highlighting the cases of young defeated members of parliament, some of them former ministers, who are presumed to enjoy very substantial parliamentary pensions for the rest of their lives. In reality, many parliamentarians do not survive political life for long enough to enjoy the generous benefits the media is so willing to highlight.

The average tenure of parliamentarians is tending towards shorter parliamentary careers for a variety of reasons, including an increasingly volatile electorate. Consequently, fewer parliamentarians will qualify for a pension. Nonetheless, parliamentarians can receive benefits that are generous by community standards—if they survive in politics for long enough. Contributors to this inquiry focused heavily on this provision.

Most people in the community are in accumulation schemes funded by contributions. Very few can obtain access to their benefits before the age of 55. The government has also moved to tighten up preservation requirements so that contributions made after 1 July 1999 will not be available until age 55. The government announced one exception to this rule: people can get access to their benefits early if they take them as non-commutable life pensions or annuities.

If the parliamentary scheme was not changed, parliamentarians who qualified for a pension would still be able to get their benefits early. However, it is quite unusual for trustees of funds to allow any benefits, let alone full pension benefits, to be paid before retirement age. It remains to be seen whether trustees will change their views as a result of the government's announcement. At this stage they have not, and the parliamentary scheme is therefore seen as excessively generous. There is a strong case for bringing it into line with prevailing practice.

It is understandable that there are people in the community who resent the apparently generous superannuation provisions enjoyed by parliamentarians. The average Australian workplace is now much less stable than it was, and many people face an uncertain and volatile employment market. In many ways the rest of the community has caught up with the general lack of stability that has always characterised political life. However, you cannot consider superannuation in isolation. It has to be viewed in the context of overall remuneration.

While there is no difficulty in attracting people to stand for parliament, many talented people will not contemplate parliamentary service. This is because the parliamentary remuneration, particularly at ministerial level, lags well behind what might be expected for similar levels of responsibility in the private sector and in some public sector positions. Conditions of service in parliament should not be such that talented people who could make a real contribution to political life are deterred from entering parliament. If we cut too hard into parliamentary superannuation, we may compound this problem.

The committee agreed that the scheme has many significant shortcomings. It is out of step with community practice and standards in the wider community. It also does not necessarily serve its members well. There are some outdated provisions and attempts to achieve too much in relation to what a superannuation scheme could be expected to provide. There is also a lack of transparency in parliamentary superannuation, and this lack of transparency gives rise to much of the criticism.

As I noted earlier, Labor and Democrat members have different views, and I will let them speak for themselves. I do not wish to comment on the views of the Labor Party senators in detail. However, I think it is somewhat disappointing that they were unwilling to commit themselves to recommendations for reform rather than delegating responsibility to the Remuneration Tribunal without further comment. I think there was an expectation that we would come up with specific recommendations. While there were limits as to how far coalition senators thought they should go, we have attempted to offer some directions for reform. I thank my colleagues Senator McGauran and Senator Ferguson in this regard.

Coalition senators believe that the first step in reforming the scheme should be to apply similar preservation standards to parliamentary superannuation as apply in the wider community. The coalition senators' major recommendation is that future members should not be able to access any pension benefit until they are 55. However, coalition senators acknowledge that there is a case for paying current members an actuarially discounted benefit if they leave parliament before they are 55 years of age.

Coalition senators concur with the view put by several witnesses that the PCSS attempts to fulfil too many functions and considers the scheme should operate solely as a method of providing income for retirement. Coalition senators also consider that new parliamentarians should be offered the choice of opting out of the present PCSS in favour of a fully funded accumulation scheme or retirement savings account of their choice. This could become part of the establishment of a fully funded parliamentary scheme.

If our recommendations are adopted, we consider that the new rules should coincide with the new preservation rules announced in the 1997-98 budget and commence from 1 July 1999. This date falls after the next scheduled election and would allow current members sufficient time to consider their options.

I am very conscious that some of my colleagues will not be happy with aspects of the report. I regret that. It is difficult to turn your back on what is the norm in the wider community. In closing, I would like to turn to the Democrats' dissenting report. I regret that the Democrats approached this inquiry with a fixed agenda and, to achieve such an outcome, some of their assumptions were questionable. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in speaking to this report, I do not intend to make comment about the government senators' recommendations or indeed those of the Australian Democrats. Senator Watson has spoken for the government senators, I will be speaking for Labor members of the committee and Senator Allison can outline her concerns and recommendations. I would also like to thank the secretariat for the very intensive work they have done in preparing the material contained in the report. This is the 25th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and it deals with a difficult and vexed question relating to politicians' superannuation and the judges' pension scheme.

BREAK.PARA: The report, as I said, is very comprehensive. If we look very briefly at the history of the parliamentary contribution superannuation scheme, we see that it commenced in 1948. Initially some of the reasons for the establishment of the scheme were that, firstly, for those entering parliament it often meant forgoing potential superannuation payouts from previous employers due to leaving that employer prior to retirement age; secondly, electoral and parliamentary demands reduced members' chances to re-establish careers when their parliamentary term was over; and, thirdly, there was the need to entice people into parliament who would not otherwise come.

The report does outline a number of major changes that have occurred to the scheme, particularly the commutation factor introduced in 1973 and changed in 1978. As Senator Watson has pointed out, the core feature of the parliamentary fund is that it is a defined benefit fund. The main issue of contention has been about what is an appropriate level of effective contribution by the taxpayer into that fund. There are a number of issues dealt with by the report and I am sure Labor senators were conscious of the changing and emerging trends in superannuation in this country, particularly since 1983. Up until that time superannuation was generally enjoyed by approximately 40 per cent of the Australian work force. We had the introduction of the superannuation guarantee, and that now covers nine out of 10 people in the Australian work force.

There has been a significant number of defined benefit funds in the public sector—certainly those covering the current Public Service and in particular the military—which were established for quite valid reasons, given the context of the employment and the various difficulties in maintaining people within both the military and the wider public sector; and there has been a significant number of defined benefit funds of various levels of effective employer contribution for many years in this country.

There have been a number of changes to the legislation governing superannuation, one of which is I think perhaps the most import ant—the introduction of superannuation guarantee—to the extent that now nine out of 10 employees in this country do enjoy effective superannuation coverage. One of the other themes to emerge in recent times has been the issue of choice: how you can improve the flexibility of a member of a fund to have a greater role in the decision making about which fund they wish monies to be contributed to on their behalf and also to have a greater choice with respect to investments that occur through their fund.

Generally in Australia over the last 10 years or so there has been a move away from defined benefit funds towards accumulation funds. I think Senator Watson has referred to a number of the disadvantages that relate to defined benefit funds. Clearly there is an issue related to cost and there is an issue related to the transparency of such funds. As I said earlier, accumulation funds seem to be emerging rapidly as the major fund cover for the significant majority of Australian employees. There are certainly a number of advantages with respect to accumulation funds. The cost of an accumulation fund is much more measurable. The cost of an accumulation fund, by its very nature, is readily able to be identified and it is also more transparent. There are a number of disadvantages, and we deal with those in the report, particularly relating to issues such as conflict of interest.

One of the interesting facts that I was a little surprised at when considering this issue—I think it is on page 21 of the report—was an examination of the age of parliamentarians. This is an important statistic when attempting to measure in some way the future liabilities of the fund. I was a little surprised because I had assumed that the average age of politicians had dropped significantly in the last 20 or 30 years; but that does not appear to be the case.

As Senator Watson referred to earlier, there certainly was a recognition of the concern of the Labor members on the committee about whether the current fund is as relevant in today's world as it once was when compared to the emerging trends that I referred to in my earlier comments. The greatest difficulty that faced any politician serving on this committee was having to make quite specific recommendations for reform of the scheme that affects both the future entitlements and current entitlements of members of parliament—and perhaps, depending on how far some members of the committee may wish to go, past accrued entitlements of members of parliament.

For those reasons, the Labor members took a view, which is referred to in the committee report, that the independent Remuneration Tribunal set the conditions of employment of federal politicians in this country. The Remuneration Tribunal is independent and widely respected in its role. Again, the report draws attention to the fact that parliamentary superannuation has been determined by various acts of parliament, as amended, since its introduction.

The Remuneration Tribunal has never had carriage of the detail of the superannuation fund covering members of federal parliament. The Labor senators believe that it is appropriate for the fund to be examined in light of the background that I have outlined. We believe that it is not appropriate for members of parliament to make specific recommendations about changes to the scheme. There would be a conflict of interest if members of parliament were to do that.

Rather, we see it as the role—we hope that legislation is introduced to do this—of the Remuneration Tribunal, as the appropriate body, to make necessary recommendations to reform the scheme in light of that tribunal's independence. It has extensive experience with remuneration matters, and it has the ability to evaluate the totality of the scheme and its objectives. We have recommended accordingly.

We believe there is a case for reviewing the parliamentary contribution scheme. We have contributed extensively to the various chapters of the report. Labor senators are very conscious of the accusations of potential conflict of interest in making recommendations which could be seen as attempting to benefit members of parliament. It is best left to the independent tribunal which we believe is appropriate—that is, the Remuneration Tribunal. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Cheryl Kernot, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference show that we seek to look at the fairness of the schemes, particularly in relation to the cost to the public purse and in relation to the benefits received by other citizens.
What is happening now is that the scheme we have in place is failing the test of fairness.

I think it is fair to say, as Senator Watson has already indicated, that this inquiry was not welcomed by the major parties. Our recommendations, in so far as they would reduce to varying degrees the entitlements of parliamentarians, are not likely to be popular with many of our colleagues. However, in our view, the evidence to the committee was compelling in making the case for such a direction in reforming the scheme. I reject Senator Watson's suggestion that we came into this with a fixed agenda. We certainly had a very strong agenda, but it was not a fixed one. We listened to the evidence that was before us as did other members of the committee.

Our report expresses the very firm view that the scheme is too generous and that it is in urgent need of reform. The majority report goes some way to acknowledging the criticisms of the scheme, and it explores the inequities inherent in that scheme between members of parliament whose terms of office and retirement ages vary quite widely.

However, as we anticipated in drawing up those terms of reference, the report fails to tackle that more substantive issue to do with the level of public subsidy to the scheme. It shirks what we acknowledge is the very difficult, but nonetheless important, task of bringing that scheme much more in line with community standards whilst having proper regard for the unusual nature of parliamentary life.

The Democrats believe that the evidence that the level of hidden public subsidy to the scheme is excessive is compelling. In our view, the majority report made a mistake in not recommending about the appropriateness of the level of public funding as outlined in the terms of reference. We share the majority report's concern about politicians voting on their own remuneration and, for that reason, we support the view of the majority report that it would be appropriate for the tribunal to determine a fair level of superannuation benefits for parliamentarians. However, this review ought to take place in the context of a very clear direction from the parliament that the level of super benefits ought to be reduced.

We strongly disagree with the view that superannuation should be considered as part of a total remuneration package for parliamentarians, with the implicit view that any reduction in superannuation should be offset somehow by an increase in some other component of that package. As was noted in the majority report, the Remuneration Tribunal itself has expressed reservations about the total remuneration package approach to salaries. It argued that accountability is best served by the public knowing the purpose for which funds are available to parliamentarians, recognising the distinction between provisions directed to a parliamentarian's individual benefit and those expenses which are incurred in the discharge of electorate functions.

The total remuneration package approach to parliamentarians' remuneration would allow parliamentarians to arrange their remuneration to best suit their individual needs. This, for some, could mean minimising their tax obligations. It may be seriously questioned whether it is appropriate to consider a tax package at a time when the government, through the tax office, is trying to crack down on that sort of abuse.

Our submission recognised that remuneration arrangements for parliamentarians needed to balance several considerations: the need for office holders to be able to live appropriately but not ostentatiously whilst holding office, without the need for an independent income; the removal of any financial need of illicit income from misuse of office; the need for remuneration to be sufficiently attractive to provide an adequate consideration for qualified citizens to leave the private sector to enter parliament; and the need to be sufficiently modest to ensure that offices do not become a source of money making and that the public has confidence that the remuneration levels are appropriate.

We felt that, based on these criteria and the evidence presented to the committee, there was a strong and compelling case for retaining parliamentary superannuation schemes. The longer a parliamentarian is in office the more distant, in most cases, they become from their profession or their occupation, making it very difficult to return successfully to that former work. Against this it should be noted that parliamentarians who take up senior ministerial office are able to develop new skills and contacts which very often result in better opportunities in career paths. But, on the whole, most parliamentarians do not move up into higher office.

One of our recommendations was that, in restricting the parliamentary contribution superannuation scheme to retirement income purposes and reducing the level of public subsidy, there should be introduced a separate and additional dislocation allowance to assist former parliamentarians in transition from office to the work force. We recommended that the scheme should be restructured as a fully vested accumulation scheme with the level of public subsidy being substantially reduced, as I said earlier, and with the government contribution becoming an appropriate multiple of the parliamentarians' 11.5 per cent contribution. We think that that redundancy function I mentioned earlier should be quite separate from the retirement function.

We also recommend that the government contribution should cease after 18 years and parliamentarians ought to be permitted to reduce their contributions to 5.75 per cent after 18 years of service, as at present; that membership of the scheme remain compulsory but, where a member can satisfy the trustees that they have adequate retirement savings already, they should be able opt out of the scheme thereby forfeiting the benefit of the government contribution; that the rule for survivor and invalidity benefits be reviewed; and that parliamentarians be able to make additional contributions if they so opt and be paid interest on those contributions.

BREAK.PARA: It is our view that the benefits under the scheme be paid as a pension actuarially determined, based on the value of the accumulated benefit when the parliamentarian retires or turns 55, whichever is later, with parliamentarians able to commute up to 50 per cent of their pension to a lump sum at present. Finally, we recommend that the new scheme apply equally to new and to current parliamentarians in respect of the future service. We believe that entitlements of existing members should be determined under the current scheme as at the date of the closure of the existing scheme, with the Remuneration Tribunal determining appropriate transitional arrangements. It is on this recommendation that we most depart from the other two reports.
In all respects, the Democrats support the analysis and the conclusions in the recommendations of the majority report in relation to the judges' scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I know that there is only limited time. I hope at some later stage there will be an opportunity to respond to some of the wildly inaccurate statements made by Senator Allison. All I wish to say at this stage is that Senator Watson, in his haste to try and make sure that he got out all of his information, forgot to thank the work of the secretariat: Peter Hallahan, Rod Adams and the other members of staff who worked very hard, particularly this last weekend, to make sure this report was put down on time. There were a lot of last minute negotiations and a lot of last minute amendments. Senator Sherry has already acknowledged the work that they did. He knows as well as Senator Watson, Senator Allison and I do just how much effort and time were put in by them to make sure that this report was put down on time, as had been promised. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Abetz, I present additional information received by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in response to the 1997‐98 budget estimates hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Abetz, I present, on behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, the committee's ninth report entitled Amendments to the Bonn Convention , together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to have the tabling statement incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The report I have just tabled on behalf of the committee chair deals with a number of amendments to the convention on the conservation of migratory species of wild animals, the so‐called Bonn Convention.
These amendments propose the listing of two species of cetaceans in Appendix ii to the convention, one species of albatross in appendix I and ten species of albatross in Appendix ii.

At the conference of the parties in April, Australia proposed the listing of the 11 albatross species, while the Netherlands proposed the listing of two northern hemisphere species. With the earlier listing of a northern hemisphere species, all 14 albatross species are now listed under this convention.

The dolphin and porpoise proposed for listing are rarely seen in Australian waters and little is known about them. Nevertheless, the committee believes that Australia should continue to collect information on these animals, and on other species not often found in our waters.

When the committee examined the 1996 subsidiary southern bluefin tuna agreement with Japan, seabird by‐catch was an issue of concern. We made particular reference to the fate of albatrosses which interact with long‐line fishing operations.

The latest listings provide another opportunity to re‐visit the subject. We need to be aware that fishing provides many jobs, directly and indirectly, and that too many constraints will have an impact on fishing as a business. At the same time, Australia is a signatory to the Bonn Convention and is therefore legally obliged to introduce and enforce measures which protect migratory birds like the albatross.

Many Australians would be uncomfortable if this nation did not take appropriate steps. Our report supports the listings, and we believe that our recommendations will assist in carrying out this public duty more effectively.
We have therefore recommended that:
Australia continue its efforts to optimise membership of international agreements;
All commonwealth departments and agencies involved in managing our membership of the convention harness the available expertise in the most effective way;
The Australian fisheries management authority (ALMA) examine the observer program to establish the costs and benefits of placing trained observers on all boats in Australia's fishing areas, and
ALMA discuss with the tuna fishing industry the testing of such techniques as night setting of bait on the high seas.
However, we are concerned about three things.

Firstly, it is regrettable that the first national interest analysis (IN) which was tabled omitted the listing of the two species of cetaceans. I understand that the oversight occurred in spite of a number of organisations involved in the process asking the sponsor whether any other species were involved in these listings as well as the albatrosses.

Secondly, we are concerned about the time it took to produce the record of the proceedings of the conference of parties. This ended in April and was still not available when the revised in was tabled in mid‐June.

While we have not made a recommendation on this matter, we have suggested that Australia should offer the secretariat to the conference whatever assistance it can to ensure the results of the conference are available as soon as practicable after its conclusion.
Thirdly, we are still not satisfied with the amount and timing of the consultation involved in the process of parliamentary scrutiny of treaties.

Last Monday, in the course of some additional remarks in the other place on our eighth report, my colleague the honourable member for Moreton drew attention to two examples of inadequate consultation in areas where particular organisations should have been involved in the process. In the case of the Bonn Convention, such consultation as did occur about the listing of the cetaceans was probably later than desirable.
The contribution made by various NGOs to this inquiry, and to an earlier one on restrictions on the use of blinding laser weapons and landmines, was considerable and we thank them for their efforts.

On the latter, our fifth report, on the chair's behalf I would like to take the opportunity to acknowledge the courageous efforts of the late Princess Diana of Wales and her written acknowledgment of the committee's work in this direction earlier this year. We will treasure her response at a time when the world has a heavy heart at her sudden passing.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman, Sen Dominic

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the committee's annual report for 1996‐97. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

BREAK.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FAMILY AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Senate that those bills which have just been announced by the Acting Deputy President are being introduced together. After debate on the motion for the second reading has been adjourned, I will be moving a motion to have two of the bills listed separately on the Notice Paper . I move:

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (SPECTRUM LICENCE TAX) BILL 1997

The Radiocommunications (Spectrum Licence Tax) Bill 1997 seeks to apply an annual spectrum licence tax, to recover spectrum maintenance costs, to spectrum licences issued under the Radiocommunications Act 1992. The associated Radicommuni cations Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 will provide for collection of the tax.

Spectrum licensees benefit from spectrum maintenance practices such as international coordination, domestic planning, interference investigation and policy development carried out by the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) (the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) from 1 July 1997) on behalf of all radiocommunications licensees. It is appropriate therefore that spectrum licensees should contribute to the recovery of associated costs, by paying a proportionate share of annual spectrum maintenance tax.

The collection of an annual spectrum maintenance tax was supported in the bipartisan HORSCOTCI Report "Management of the Radiofrequency Spectrum" in October 1991. However there is currently no provision for spectrum licensees to pay a spectrum maintenance tax.

Apparatus licensees have always paid these maintenance costs. With the first spectrum licences being issued in 1997, this is the appropriate time to correct the anomaly between the two licensing systems. The proposed act will harmonise arrangements between apparatus licences and spectrum licences and will make transparent the share of the ongoing costs of spectrum management paid by spectrum licensees.
Now I turn to the details contained in the bill.

The actual amount of the tax will be set by a SMA determination, as is presently the case for apparatus licences. There will not be a set maximum limit on the tax that can be imposed on a licence holder. This is because of the highly flexible nature of spectrum licences. Such licences can, for example, be traded, sub‐divided and amalgamated, giving rise to the possibility that a single licensee could hold a large proportion of spectrum in a particular band.

However, the following checks will limit the degree of discretion the SMA has in setting the amount of the tax. Once made, any such determination will be a disallowable instrument. Furthermore, in order to limit the SMA's discretion to increase the tax, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, under section 235 of the Radiocommunications Act 1992, may give the SMA directions in relation to the performance of its functions and exercise of its powers.
Madam President, the amendments I have outlined will enable all radiocommunications licensees to share the costs of the SMA providing an efficient spectrum management service in Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The Radiocommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 seeks to collect an annual spectrum licence tax from spectrum licensees. This will be a tax for spectrum maintenance. The associated Radiocommunications (Spectrum Licence Tax) Bill 1997 seeks to apply the tax to spectrum licensees.

Spectrum licensees benefit from spectrum management practices such as international coordination, domestic planning interference investigation and policy development carried out by the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) (the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) from 1 July 1997) on behalf of all radiocommunications licensees. Therefore spectrum licensees should contribute to the recovery of associated costs, by paying an annual spectrum maintenance tax.

The collection of an annual spectrum maintenance tax was supported in the bipartisan HORSCOTCI Report "Management of the Radiofrequency Spectrum" in October 1991. However, there is currently no provision for spectrum licensees to pay a spectrum maintenance tax.

Apparatus licensees have always paid these maintenance costs. With the first spectrum licences being issued in 1997, this is the appropriate time to correct the anomaly between the two licensing systems. The proposed act will harmonise arrangements between apparatus licences and spectrum licences and will make transparent the share of the ongoing costs of spectrum management paid by spectrum licensees.
Now I turn to the details contained in the bill.

In order to collect the spectrum maintenance tax, the bill seeks to amend relevant acts including the Radiocommunications Act 1992, Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983 and the proposed Legislative Instruments Act 1997.
The amendment to the proposed Legislative Instruments Act 1997 will provide that the SMA is required to undergo a consultation process before making a determination setting the amount of a tax.

There is also provision for regulations exempting spectrum licensees who satisfy certain criteria (including the provision of non‐profit safety of life services) from payment of the spectrum maintenance tax.
Madam President, the amendments I have outlined will enable all radiocommunications licensees to share the costs of the SMA providing an efficient spectrum management service in Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FAMILY AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

This bill gives effect to a number of measures announced in the Government's 1997‐98 Budget, a measure announced in the 1996‐97 Budget, the introduction of a maternity immunisation allowance that forms part of the Government's strategy to improve the rate of child immunisation in Australia and to a number of non‐Budget measures that will assist in more effective and efficient social security administration.

Under current arrangements, family payment above the minimum rate can be paid for up to 13 weeks when one or both parents go overseas temporarily, providing the child stays in Australia. However, if the child goes overseas, family payment above the minimum rate is not paid and families currently receive only the minimum rate of family payment. This can cause the family financial stress.

One of the measures announced in the 1997‐98 Budget provided for the Social Security Act 1991 to be amended to allow above the minimum rate family payment to be paid for up to eight weeks when either the parent or child, or both, go overseas temporarily. The bill provides for this, effective from 1 January 1998.
Another 1997‐98 Budget measure included in this bill will allow better targeting of family payment and maternity allowance to those in need.

The bill provides that from 1 January 1998, the hardship provisions that apply for family‐related payments will be amended so that families with an assets value between $406,000 and $602,500 will qualify for minimum family payment only if their family income is at or below the point at which income reduces family payment to the minimum rate (currently $27,125 plus $4,399 for each child after the first child). As qualification for maternity allowance is based on qualification for family payment, those families who do not receive family payment because of this initiative will also not qualify for maternity allowance.

The third 1997‐98 Budget measure to be implemented by this bill provides for amendments to be made to social security and veterans' affairs legislation so as to remove the entitlement to rent assistance, from 1 January 1998, of persons who live in public housing but do not pay rent directly to the public housing authority (other than those who live in public housing where market rent is being charged).

The bill also provides for the implementation, from 1 January 1998, of a 1996‐97 Budget measure that will extend the range of employer provided benefits currently taken into account in the income test for family payment, maternity allowance and childcare assistance. This extension will cover employer provided benefits received by an employee in the form of financial investments (including units in cash management trusts), as well as reimbursements to an employee for expenses incurred for his or her private use.

Australia currently has an immunisation rate of 53 per cent according to the recommended schedule for children 0‐6 years. This is not good enough. We need to implement a strategy that will lift immunisation rates to an acceptable level.

As part of that strategy, this bill provides for the introduction of a maternity immunisation allowance. The maternity immunisation allowance will be payable in respect of children born on or after 1 January 1998 and who, having reached 18 months of age, have received age‐appropriate immunisation up to that stage (unless the child is otherwise exempted from the requirement). The maternity immunisation allowance of $200 will be payable in addition to a maternity allowance of $750 that will be payable following the birth of such a child.
The maternity immunisation allowance will also be paid in addition to the maternity allowance, in respect of stillborn children or children who die before reaching 18 months of age.
A maternity allowance, currently $870.30, will continue to be payable following the birth of a child who is born on or after 1 February 1996 but before 1 January 1998.
A number of non‐Budget measures included in the bill will impact on family‐related payments. These are aimed at ensuring more equitable and efficient delivery of services to families.

A number of other non‐Budget measures included in the bill deal with disability‐related payments. Two such measures provide for the introduction of revised impairment tables for disability support pension and the subsuming of disability wage supplement into disability support pension.

The assessment processes for disability support pension will be tightened to ensure that those people whose impairments have only a relatively small impact on their overall inability to work will not qualify for that pension. Rather, they will receive a more appropriate income support payment. To assist in this process, revised impairment tables, which are used to assess whether a person's impairment is 20 points or more, are being introduced. These revised impairment tables are a refinement of amendments that were previously proposed in the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and take account of submissions received from thirty eight peak disability and welfare groups. The major changes between the revised tables as proposed in 1996 and those included in the bill are the re‐introduction of some minor impairment scores and the clarification of issues such as `enforced' treatment, `double assessing', assessing fatigue and investigations to be undertaken by medical officers.

Disability wage supplement was established in June 1994 as a separate payment for people with disabilities participating in the Supported Wage System, a productivity‐wage based system administered by the Department of Health and Family Services. Currently, people in receipt of disability support pension who commence employment through the Supported Wage System are required to transfer to disability wage supplement, even though the qualification criteria for the two payments are very similar. Many customers have expressed a reluctance to make this transfer and a preference to continue to receive disability support pension. The take‐up of disability wage supplement has been very slow, with less than 300 customers in receipt of this payment two years after its inception.

The bill provides for disability wage supplement to be subsumed into disability support pension from 1 January 1998. All existing disability wage supplement customers will be transferred to disability support pension and the disability support pension provisions amended so that participation in the Supported Wage System will be an alternative qualification criterion to a person having a continuing inability to work because of an impairment.

Another non‐Budget measure included in the bill provides for amendments to be made to the Social Security Act so as to provide for a new method of determining the value of a payment received by a customer in a foreign currency.
The existing method set out in the Social Security Act for the conversion of foreign currency for income test purposes has not been used because of system limitations.

The new method proposed in the bill extends the conversion of foreign currency to all social security payments, not just social security pensions, and to all foreign currencies. There will also be a requirement to apply an appropriate exchange rate from the first social security pension payday each month.
Two recent Federal Court decisions have considered legal questions concerning entitlement to rent assistance where entry contributions are paid to retirement villages.

In the unreported decision of Department of Social Security v. Knight, it was held that regular instalments paid by Mrs Knight as part of her entry contribution to a retirement village were rent. Accordingly, Mrs Knight was entitled to rent assistance in respect of those payments.

It was never intended that any amount that could be regarded as all or part of an entry contribution, however payable, was rent. Accordingly, it is proposed to amend the Social Security Act to clarify the original intention.

In another unreported decision, Secretary, Department of Social Security v. Montgomery, it was held that notional annual deductions from the refundable portion of an entry contribution were not rent. Although this decision accords with the intention of the legislation, the bill amends the Social Security Act so as to establish beyond doubt that such notional deductions are not rent.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Act 1996 implemented amendments to the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, from 20 March 1997, that allow the backdating, through the deemed earlier lodgement of a claim, in circumstances where the person makes a telephone inquiry about claiming payment and then formally lodges a claim and qualifies for disability support pension, sickness allowance, newstart allowance or youth training allowance.

This bill builds on those measures so as to extend the telephone lodgment provisions to carer payment, partner allowance and parenting allowance. The bill also extends the ambit of these provisions to include contact by facsimile and computer. This "extension" will apply not only for carer payment, partner allowance and parenting allowance but also to the payment types to which the telephone lodgment provisions originally applied.
Lastly, the bill amends the Data‐matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 so as to include the family tax initiative in the Data‐matching Program.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill is intended to ensure that small businesses are exempted from the federal unfair dismissal provisions, in respect of new employees. This exemption is necessary and appropriate, given the special features of small business—and it is necessary, to ensure continuing growth in employment in small business.

Senators will be aware that the Government's commitment to an unfair dismissal exemption for small business was announced on 24 March 1997, as part of the Government's small business statement, and that a regulation was made under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, to give effect to such an exemption, which was to take effect from 1 July 1997. Senators would also be aware that this regulation was disallowed by the Senate on 26 June 1997. As a result, this bill was introduced later on the same day into the House of Representatives to give effect to the Government's intentions.

Madam President, as the Prime Minister said in launching the Government's small business statement, helping small business to grow, employ, export and invest in Australia's future has been a top priority for the Government since its first day in office. The Government's economic and industrial relations policies are central to its agenda for the growth and development of the small business sector—and the Government is also committed to tackling the impediments to small business imposed by unnecessary government regulation and paperwork, as set out in the small business statement.

The Government has, of course, already made substantial progress in labour market reform, which is and will be of particular benefit to small business.
