The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 has changed the federal industrial relations system, and the relationship between federal and state industrial relations systems, providing small business with greater opportunities to develop industrial relations arrangements best suited to their individual circumstances. In particular, small business employers have new opportunities to make direct agreements with their employees. Small businesses that choose to remain in the award system are benefitting from a simplified and more flexible system; small businesses now have greater certainty with respect to industrial action within their business; the Employment Advocate has been given a specific charter to assist small business.

Of course, unfair dismissal was one of the most important industrial relations issues for small business, prior to the last election. Our commitment, in Better Pay for Better Work , was to introduce a new unfair dismissal scheme, which would recognise the circumstances facing small business: and we have done this. The new system is more balanced and fair to both employers and employees. It is less legalistic and costly, with an emphasis on conciliation. Employers are protected from frivolous and malicious claims by the requirement for a filing fee and access to costs where a claim is vexatious. In considering unfair dismissal claims, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has to consider a range of factors, including the possible effect of any order on the viability of the employer's business.

Madam President, these changes are important—but they have not gone far enough, for small business. It is an unavoidable fact that the defence of an unfair dismissal claim, however groundless, is especially burdensome for small businesses. In many larger businesses, expertise and resources can be put into recruitment and termination procedures. Small businesses have no such resources. Even attendance of witnesses at a hearing can bring a small business to a standstill.

The Government has been listening to the concerns of small businesses, their experiences of the impact of unfair dismissal claims (particularly under the previous Government's provisions), and their fears that the simple fact of employing someone makes them vulnerable to unfair dismissal claims. The Government was mindful of all of these concerns and fears in the development of last year's legislation: the issue was amongst those raised in the Government's discussions with the Australian Democrats, and the scope for additional exemptions, by the regulations, was always there, as part and parcel of the act's provisions on termination of employment.

Section 170CC of the act allows for exclusion of `employees in relation to whom the operation of the provisions causes or would cause substantial problems because of . . . the size or nature of the undertakings in which they are employed'. And this language is drawn directly from the International Labour Organisation's Termination of Employment Convention, 1982, which expressly allows exclusions of this type.

Our announcement of the small business exclusion on 24 March 1997 was welcomed by small business. Rob Bastion of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia said `That's obviously the jewel in the crown . . . that is the one which will actually create jobs . . . I'm certain of it'. And, Madam President, this is the crucial point—this exemption is not just about removing a burden from small business, it is about the positive employment benefits of the expanded job opportunities that will surely result from the removal of that burden.
I turn now to the terms of the bill itself.

The exemption is to commence on Royal Assent. However, it will not affect existing employees. As it is intended to encourage new employment, the exclusion will only apply to employees who are first engaged by the relevant employer after the commencement of the amendment.

The exemption is from the federal unfair dismissal provisions, only. Employees will still be protected by the Workplace Relations Act. Section 170CK protects employees against dismissal because of any discriminatory reason. Sections 170MU and 170WE prohibit dismissal of an employee because the employee engages in protected industrial action, seeking a certified agreement, or AWA industrial action. Section 298K, in the freedom of association part of the act, prohibits dismissal which involves victimisation, or is otherwise contrary to freedom of association. And section 170CM prohibits dismissal without 1‐5 weeks notice (depending on the employee's length of service and age), or pay in lieu, except in cases of serious misconduct.The exemption also does not affect the rights of apprentices in small businesses, who have a particular need for protection, given the additional impact that any break in the continuity of their employment may have, in terms of attainment of qualifications. This bill will not affect existing rights in this regard.

The exemption applies only to businesses employing 15 or fewer employees. This size of small business was chosen because of the precedent provided by the Employment Protection Act 1982 (NSW), introduced by the Wran Government, and followed by the then Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the 1984 Termination, Change and Redundancy Test Case. An exemption for businesses of this size will benefit a substantial proportion of all businesses in the federal jurisdiction, but will not cover too many businesses of such a size and complexity that they are likely to have a separate management structure (which would facilitate defence of unfair dismissal claims).

The bill provides that, in counting the number of employees in a business, casual employees are only to be counted if they have been engaged on a regular and systematic basis for at least 12 months. The intention of this exclusion is to reflect the fact that a business which occasionally engages additional casual employees is not necessarily a large business.
This bill will have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

Ordered that the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill 1997 and the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Newman) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: The bill has two main purposes: first, to put in place arrangements for the provision of general revenue assistance to the states and territories in 1997-98, consistent with decisions reached at the 1997 Premiers' Conference and related agreements with the states and territories; and secondly to provide authority for the Commonwealth to pay the states and territories the revenue it collects under the safety net arrangements which are being implemented to protect State and Territory revenues following the High Court decision of 5 August on State business franchise fees.

The bill will amend the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. The existing act covers the provision of financial assistance grants and special revenue assistance for 1996-97 only, with interim arrangements for the continuation of payments for a maximum of six months. The bill extends for a further 12 months the provisions of the act relating to the payment of financial assistance grants and special revenue assistance, and specifies State and Territory entitlements in 1997-98 to payments under the safety net arrangements.

The general revenue assistance to be appropriated by this bill is about $16.8 billion, or around 12 per cent of estimated Commonwealth outlays in 1997-98. Accordingly, these payments constitute a significant element of the Commonwealth Budget and have an important bearing on the spending and borrowing of the public sector as a whole. The states and territories are able to allocate the funds provided by the Commonwealth under this act according to their own budgetary priorities.

In addition, the bill appropriates revenue replacement payments to the states under the safety net arrangements estimated to exceed $5 billion in 1997-98. The safety net arrangements are revenue neutral for the Commonwealth.
I turn now to the elements of the bill which give effect to decisions of the 1997 Premiers' Conference and related agreements.

The 1997 Premiers' Conference agreed that the states and territories will be provided with real per capita growth in financial assistance grants in 1997-98 and that the real per capita guarantee for financial assistance grants will be extended to 1999-2000. Amendments to the act are consistent with the per capita element of the real per capita guarantee being conditional on states meeting the terms of the Agreement to Implement the National Competition Policy and Related Reforms. This Agreement also provides for the commencement of $214.7 million in competition payments to the states and territories in 1997-98. On 7 July 1997, the Treasurer announced that in light of the National Competition Council's report on competition policy reform, each State will receive the per capita element of growth in financial assistance grants and an equal per capita share of a total amount of $214.7 million in competition payments in 1997‐98.

At the 1997 Premiers' Conference it was decided that the states and territories would make fiscal contribution payments of $626.5 million in 1997-98 and $313.5 million in 1998-99. It was also agreed that half of the scheduled 1997-98 fiscal contributions of Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory will be deferred until 1998-99 in recognition of their difficult economic circumstances. The need for the 1998-99 fiscal contribution will be reviewed at the 1998 Premiers' Conference in light of developments in the Commonwealth's fiscal position.

The Commonwealth will continue to provide states and territories with maximum flexibility concerning the method of payment of the State fiscal contributions. A State's share can be paid by way of deductions from general revenue assistance, direct payments to the Commonwealth or a reduction in funding provided under a specific purpose grant. Provisions have been included in the bill for states' 1997-98 fiscal contributions to be deducted from general revenue assistance.

The major part of the assistance provided under this bill is the provision to each State and Territory of a share of the pool of financial assistance grants which is estimated to be about $16.1 billion in 1997-98. In accordance with the agreement at the 1996 Premiers' Conference, this amount includes the grants that were previously paid to the states as arterial road grants. The 1997 Premiers' Conference agreed that the distribution of financial assistance grants should be in accordance with the per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The bill updates the per capita relativities in the act accordingly.

The bill authorises the payment of special revenue assistance to New South Wales and Victoria of $435.5 million in 1997-98 as payments under the guarantee arrangements associated with the Medicare Agreements. The Commonwealth will fund $62.2 million of these payments and the residual will be funded from the financial assistance grants pool.

The Australian Capital Territory will also receive $34.5 million from the Commonwealth in 1997-98 in the form of transitional allowances and special fiscal needs. This payment is outside the scope of this bill and has been included in the Appropriation bills.
I now turn to the elements of the bill which relate to the safety net arrangements.

As announced by the Treasurer on 6 August, the Commonwealth has agreed to introduce safety net measures to protect State and Territory revenues following the High Court decision of 5 August on State business franchise fees. The High Court decision affects annual State revenues of around $5 billion and leaves the states open to refund claims, amounting to many billions of dollars, in respect of past business franchise fee payments.

The Commonwealth will use its tax powers to collect the revenue that the states and territories previously collected by way of business franchise fees on petroleum products, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. The states and territories acknowledge that this will represent a State tax imposed and collected by the Commonwealth at their request and on their behalf. The safety net arrangements are intended to be temporary and will be reviewed within six months.

The proposed amendments provide authority for the Commonwealth to pay the states and territories the revenue it collects under the safety net arrangements, expected to exceed $5 billion in 1997-98. It is intended that revenue replacement payments be made together with the Commonwealth's weekly payments of general revenue assistance.

Some states will receive more revenue than they previously raised under their business franchise fees. This is necessary if no State or Territory is to be worse off as a result of the High Court decision since the Australian Constitution requires that the Commonwealth apply taxes uniformly across the states whereas states' business franchise fees vary in their rates and coverage. However, the states and territories have indicated that these excess revenues will be refunded to manufacturers or wholesalers in order to avoid as far as possible price increases for consumers and petroleum users. To ensure the safety net arrangements operate as intended, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is monitoring price movements of affected products.

The amendments also include a provision which returns to the states any tax revenues the Commonwealth might receive under the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Act 1997. This will ensure that State finances are protected from claims for refunds, on grounds of constitutional invalidity, of past payments of business franchise fees.

As I noted earlier, the safety net arrangements are revenue neutral for the Commonwealth. Revenue replacement payments will simply return to the states amounts raised by the Commonwealth on their behalf, after allowing for Commonwealth administrative costs.

It is vital to the integrity of State and Territory finances that legislation to give effect to the safety net arrangements is enacted without delay. Accordingly, the Government is giving this bill—and the associated revenue bills—the highest priority.
Madam President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the related nature of my notices of motion, I seek leave to have business of the Senate notices of motion Nos. 1, 2 and 5 taken together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That regulations 23, 25 and 33 to 37 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 109 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.
That regulations 10, 12, 13, 16 and 43 to 46 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 109 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.
That the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 185 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.
These motions are interrelated. They put in place a new regime for work rights, review application periods and the structure of the review application fee for both migrants and refugees.

The ALP initially supported the motion for disallowance of statutory rule No. 109 of 1997, but backed down and negotiated certain amendments in exchange for opposing the disallowance motion. The negotiated changes are reflected in statutory rules 1997 No. 185 made under the Migration Act 1958 and amend some of the provisions of statutory rules 1997 No. 109.

In negotiating this deal the ALP has demonstrated something it has in common with the coalition: grubby politics, illustrative of a capacity to trade justice and basic human rights standards presumably for something else, or maybe just wetting the finger, putting it in the air and seeing which way the polls lie in relation to talkback radio on issues of migration and refugees.

The claimed reason for the regulation is to reduce the level of abuse of the refugee status determination procedure. However, Mark Sullivan, Deputy Secretary of DIMA, told Senator McKiernan at the Senate estimates committee on 11 June 1997 that the regula tions have broader application than those considered to be abusing the system. So it is clearly acknowledged at the highest levels of government that the regulations will have a deleterious effect on bona fide asylum seekers. Indeed, it is understood that these regulations are already having that effect.
Also in the Senate estimates hearing of 11 June, Mark Sullivan from DIMA defined abuse as follows:

A person who applies for a protection visa, knowing that they are seeking not protection but the coverage of what a protection visa in process offers them, is committing an abuse. . . . It does not include people who make applications in good faith.

Yet the punitive scope of the regulations extends beyond those making abusive claims for protection and, although it was conceded by DIMA that there is no provision for waiver in cases where an application is found not to be frivolous, carefully drafted alternative regulations designed to target abuse but not punish bona fide users were not even considered.

It is apparent that the only study of abuse that has been made is one that equates `abusive' with `unsuccessful'. So these regulations have been passed without any meaningful study having been done regarding the extent of abuse, the nature of it and the most effective way of addressing the problem without prejudicing those seeking protection in good faith. The best the Deputy Secretary for DIMA could do was describe:

. . . an escalation in the number of claims from nationalities for which there is little experience in Australia or internationally of found claims for protection and an increasing high rate of refusal at primary and review stage of such claims.
Whilst it may raise suspicions of abuse, this does not equate with abuse.

Most particularly, it is noted that much of the blame of abuse is being levelled against unscrupulous agents. The unscrupulous agents in that context are the abusers, not those who are being exploited by them. What, one might ask, is being done about that? Nothing. It is clear that no study of levels of abuse applying the DIMA definition has been made. Indeed, the only report that might shed some light on what studies have in fact been done has, extraordinarily, been given the status of a cabinet‐in‐confidence document notwithstanding the fact that it is the product of a `public review', as described by the minister in a media release dated 31 March 1996.

So what of the innovative ALP amendments? The government has agreed to abandon the least offensive of all the amendments—the 14‐day appeal to the RRT. Although it is accepted that this is a just result, overall it is a small victory—it was a meaningless provision that would have done little to shorten processing times. Contrary to its previous position, the ALP agreed to the continuation of the $1,000 penalty. Imposed only on persons unsuccessful in their refugee applications, it is manifest nonsense to call it other than a penalty.

The only changes are that there is a two‐year sunset clause and an agreement to refer the matter for an inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations in 1998. The implication of this is that there is effectively no change for people rejected at the primary stage until the sunset clause takes effect. The only outcomes are that the introduction of the sunset clause constitutes an admission as to the questionable efficacy of a provision that is clearly unjust, and the sunset clause confirms that persons refused refugee status by the Refugee Review Tribunal become the guinea pigs of all other ill‐considered and misconceived regulatory frameworks.

It is cold comfort to be bona fide asylum seekers now that the regulation will cease to have effect two years down the track. The penalty will still serve to intimidate or deter bona fide asylum seekers from accessing the review procedure and will penalise people who are not abusing the system. Although described as a fee, it would not serve the ostensible function of cost recovery. How many asylum seekers would be able to afford to pay the penalty, having been denied for the most part access to work rights as well as other forms of basic subsistence through the asylum seekers assistance scheme?

Asylum seekers cannot claim asylum seekers assistance for six months after they apply for refugee status, and access to ASAS ceases after a person is refused refugee status at the primary stage of a determination process even though the overturn rate of primary decisions is reasonably high, although there have been extremely rare exceptions. The 14‐day limit on work rights has been increased to 45 days. This makes little appreciable difference to most asylum seekers.

The ALP describes itself, in a most unjustified and self‐congratulatory way, as having introduced an innovative change—that is, if there is no primary decision within six months of application, the prohibition on work rights lapses. How innovative this is is highly questionable given the new measures that have been introduced to speed up primary processing times, such as reductions of interviews and the practice of rejecting people before they have even had a chance to obtain legal aid or to submit a declaration as to their claims. On top of this, even if the prohibition were to lapse after six months, to impose no work and no access to financial assistance for six months is perverse brutality. So much for the creative genius of the ALP!

Whether it be 14 days or 45 days, this regulation offers no discretions and no safety nets. Indeed, this provision is the most debilitating of all. It will ensure that all applicants—bona fide or otherwise—who apply more than 45 days after arrival will have no means whatsoever to sustain themselves independently of charities and community groups upon which there are already heavy demands. Similar measures in the United Kingdom were met with strong opposition from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who described them as `constructive refoulement'—that is, returning refugees to frontiers where they could face well‐founded fear of persecution by forcing them into destitution and out of their country of asylum.

The amendments accommodate to some extent those making sur place claims—for instance, persons claiming to be refugees as a result of events arising in their country of origin after their arrival in Australia—for whom there would be a guarantee of priority processing, in individual cases, or scope, in the case of groups, for the minister to issue a gazettal notice waiving the prohibition on permission to work. This is reminiscent of old provisions that permitted people to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds that were dependent on the minister's gazettal of a particular country as being one that breached human rights; a gazettal that never happened.

What, for example, would the minister do in the case of a coup in, say, Cambodia? Would the minister, in the interests of international relations and political expediency, decline to gazette a country thereby waiving the prohibition on permission to work for its nationals seeking protection? After all, the Australian ambassador in Phnom Penh has said that the coup leader is a `democrat at heart', and Minister Ruddock has already told Sam Rainsy, the leader of the Khmer Nation Party, that Australia is not going to interfere.

Several case studies illustrate the injustices that are already being perpetrated by these regulations. They demonstrate systemic problems with the operation of the regulations that, if they were not just simply overlooked, could have been foreseen.

Let us look at case study No. 1, the holder of a business visa. A man came to Australia quite legitimately on a business visa. Through no fault of his own the business went bad and he lost his job. Unfortunately, his right of residency in a third country, not his country of origin, was conditional on the job. Loss of employment therefore led to loss of that right of residency. Although not his country of nationality, he had lived and worked there for many years.

He is in Australia on a three-month multiple entry visa, which was all he needed while he was undertaking his business activities, which involved international travel. However, if he leaves Australia now he is at risk of having his next entry denied on the basis of change of circumstances, which means that he must return to his country of nationality. He cannot return to the country where he previously held right of residency.

Were he to return to his country of nationality he would most certainly be at risk of persecution. It is considered that he would stand a high chance of succeeding in a claim to refugee status. In the meantime he has been in Australia on business for more than 45 days in the past 12 months, which means that under the new regulations he cannot get permission to work. He has a wife and children to support, having relocated himself on the expectation that he was going to be here for some time. The loss of his job has also meant the loss of his income. He now has no income and substantial liabilities as a result of the relocation. He cannot support his family. He is, of course, ineligible for asylum seeker assistance.

Case study No. 2 concerns X, a victim of torture and trauma. X is from Sri Lanka and was issued with a Sri Lankan temporary visa class 435, a visa designed to serve the humanitarian purpose of ensuring that Sri Lankans were not forced to return to their country, which is still experiencing a situation of generalised violence. Notwithstanding that there has been no perceptible change in the human rights situation in Sri Lanka, the minister decided not to extend the class 435 visas which expired on 31 July. The visa included, quite properly, permission to work. X had a job which gave him a modest income. Y was also the holder of the 435 visa but he could benefit from a ministerial announcement of 13 June which declared him eligible to remain permanently in Australia under a new scheme. The situation for X, distinguishable from Y only by date of arrival rather than by any other circumstance, is that he is ineligible for the 13 June categories.

No longer able to benefit from the protection available under the class 435 visa, but having claims to refugee status considered to be meritorious, X lodged a protection visa application. X had never sought advice. He had been hoping things would improve in Sri Lanka.

X, of course, has been in Australia for more than 45 days. Now he finds himself in a situation of having no permission to work because it is prohibited while he applies for protection against gross violations of his human rights. While he waits for a decision, thanks to the coalition and its ALP lap dog, he is prohibited from supporting himself through gainful employment and has no right of access to basic subsistence support. Remember: he is already heavily traumatised.

The 45‐day time limit creates a presumption that those who do not apply within 45 days are not seeking protection in good faith. Experienced practitioners in the refugee field are able to say that, notwithstanding the change from 14 to 45 days in which to apply, few applicants would be able to learn about the process, find an adviser, make an application, find an interpreter and make an adequately prepared protection visa application within 45 days of arrival.

The asylum seeker is left with another hard choice: make an inadequately prepared application and get permission to work, or spend longer on preparing a thorough application and be denied work rights and therefore be condemned to destitution. To take the second choice is also to invite a conclusion that the application is not made in good faith. Whilst this is a nonsense and must be seen as such, it was not beyond the DIMA deputy secretary to start casting aspersions on the bona fides of people's claims on the strength of the time within which they made their application. Of people applying more than 14 days after arrival—as the time limit for permission to work then was—he said, `The question then is whether this person is seeking protection or seeking some other cover.' While he acknowledges that persons applying outside the time limit for permission to work may still have their refugee claims decided, it is clear from Mr Sullivan's statements that it is a small step for the department to take the view that a person seeking asylum after that time limit is therefore abusing the system.

With respect to immigration cases, I have also been provided with some case studies that illustrate the impact of these changes. Case study No. 1 concerns A, who migrated to Australia on an independent visa during 1993. He came to Australia with his wife and two children. A is the sole breadwinner in the family and they are struggling to pay off a mortgage and meet the expenses associated with raising a young family.

A's elderly parents applied for a visitor visa to come to Australia to visit their only grandchildren. The Australian embassy refused their initial application because they are affected by a `risk factor' characteristic. A has sought advice in relation to having the decision reviewed. He was advised that he had a right of review at the Migration Internal Review Office and that the application fee is $500. He was further advised that his review application would be unlikely to be successful at MIRO as his parents are affected by a risk factor characteristic and that he had a further right of review to the Immigration Review Tribunal. The cost of application for review at the IRT is $850.

A could not justify spending $1,350 seeking a review of the decision to refuse his parents a visitor visa to Australia when there was no guarantee at the end of the review process that his parents would be granted visitor visas to Australia.

Case study No. 2 concerns B, a Somali who was granted refugee status in Australia during 1994. After he was granted refugee status, B re-established contact with C. B had known C from when he lived in Somalia and they are now engaged. B lodged an application to sponsor C to Australia under the prospective spouse category but this application was rejected by the Australian embassy. B sought a review of this decision at MIRO and has received a rejection. He has been advised that he has a further right of review at the IRT but with another application fee of $850. He cannot afford this fee and is unable to proceed with the IRT review.

These case studies highlight the fact that the regulations contained in statutory rules 109 are yet again another example of DIMA using a blunt instrument to respond to claims of abuse in the system. I am aware that some of the agencies in the non-government sector worked long and hard to come up with proposals that they felt dealt with the nub of the issue, but unfortunately they were rejected by both the government and the ALP.

I think this is yet another sad day in the history of migration and refugee policy in this country. What you do is set the hurdles higher and higher. You reduce the resources more and more. You make it more and more difficult for people to access justice and have recourse. You make it more and more diffi cult for those people to access advice. You make it more and more difficult for people to be treated as normal human beings. And, having set the hurdles so high, you then penalise people for not clearing those hurdles. You then say, `We've made it so difficult, we've cut you off at the knees, and now we're going to penalise you to make sure that you never do this naughty thing again.'
This is not justice: it is not justice from the government and it is not justice from the ALP. I urge honourable senators to support my disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on a motion by Senator Margetts to disallow certain migration regulations. As Senator Margetts has indicated already, the government has had discussions with Mr Duncan Kerr, who was the then opposition spokesperson in this area, and those discussions have led to an agreed outcome in many areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that it is not easy for quite a number of us on this side to agree to these regulations; nor do I imagine was it easy for Duncan Kerr to proceed down the path that he did with respect to discussions with the government. What we see through these regulations is a government committed to dismantling infrastructure which took quite some time to develop—infrastructure which was being recognised increasingly throughout the world as impressive; infrastructure which was giving people a fair say in the system.

We were confronted with a whole raft of rules and regulations which were unacceptable to us, and the opposition took the view that the best outcome we could achieve was to minimise the impact of such regulations by trying to enter into constructive negotiations. As a consequence of those negotiations, as I say, there has been an agreed outcome and we will not be supporting Senator Margetts's motions .

As I have said, we have developed in this country over a period of time a system which has been regarded as impressive not just internationally but also domestically. There are some problems with it—there always would be some problems with it. But at the end of the term of the previous government, even the Refugee Council of Australia was placing on record its appreciation of the way the system had been developed both by the department and also by the previous government.

The relationship that I had with those organisations, though rocky for a while, was one that by the end of my term in office was working quite well. Senator Harradine, I know that there have been problems all the way through and that the relationship was rocky. But we had, I think, developed a system whereby, through the RRT, people were being given a fair hearing, an unbiased hearing, and a hearing through which they could access information such as the state of country files, and whatever. It was a much more transparent process than before.

The government says that the system, as it stood when it took office, was one that allowed manifestly unfounded claims for refugee status. People will always try to pursue a claim. But it is not up to governments to decide what is manifestly unfounded in respect of refugee status. We had a system in place to make that assessment, and that system is one which was developed only in recent years.

But our system has always allowed people to make claims because of the very nature of our constitutional system. Sometimes international agencies refer to the Australian system as having the magnetic effect of our democracy, of our rule of law, of people having the capacity to have their claims tested in a fair and unimpeded way. That I think is quite critical when it comes to the assessment of refugee status.

We tried—although Senator Harradine would argue that from time to time we failed, and I accept that in respect of some cases his argument would have some validity—to stay out of the process and we tried not to prejudge it. We also tried in the context to increase the number of refugees that Australia would take—not just as refugees, but also people in humanitarian circumstances. As a consequence, under the previous government the numbers in this category kept on going up. Under this government, the numbers in these categories of humanitarian assistance keep on going down—and this is at a time also, I must say, when world demand for assistance has not abated.

Only in recent weeks we have seen a situation in Cambodia which would have been ripe for a new special assistance category to assist those people in their time of conflict. Quite a number of people, we gather, sought protection, sought assistance from Australia. But the government's response was not to introduce a humanitarian category, an offshore SAC program—a program which would have been a ready response in the past. That is just one example of where we could have involved ourselves in international assistance—but we have not.

Internationally and domestically, we have a government which is more isolationist, a government which is starting to close doors to refugees and humanitarian cases, and a government which at home is also trying to close avenues available to those people through which to seek assistance.

One thing that the government wants to do is extend the operation of prohibitive clauses. I had a chance to read the transcript of the Ervin case, the Black Panther case, the one that Minister Vanstone would know a lot about. A few telling points came out of that transcript.

One point was the total ineptness of the Commonwealth's representation before the High Court. The second was the fact that the High Court and Chief Justice made it very clear that, no matter what you do, you will not be able to stop people going to the High Court of Australia in search of their rights for procedural fairness and natural justice under administrative law. The third was that the High Court would prefer the government to set up alternative mechanisms in terms of court redress to handle those cases rather than have the High Court itself handle them. It also became quite apparent through that transcript that, if it had to, the High Court would handle those cases itself.

This is a message, I think, to the government when considering the merging of tribunals in the not too distant future: to take into account not just the constitutional imperatives but also the burden that they would be plac ing on the High Court. Unless the government hears the warning from the bench, Senator Vanstone may not be the last minister to be comprehensively bounced by the High Court.

Senator Margetts says, `Well you're supporting these regulations.' Senator Margetts, I say to you that we are being confronted by a pretty harsh agenda. In that context, the Labor Party chose to see whether it could get constructive outcomes to minimise the impact of a harsh and heavy-handed measure by the government.

These were not measures that we introduced in government, nor would we have introduced them in government. But, confronted with them now, former shadow minister Duncan Kerr had, I think, an obligation to see how we could minimise their impact. I am informed that, in terms of those negotiations, there have been some six key changes proposed by the opposition which have been agreed to by the government. There is agreement to extend from 14 to 45 days the period in which an application for a protection visa can be made and the person can be eligible for work rights. An introduction of the original 14‐day period would have made it virtually impossible.

In considering the specific issues of withdrawal of work rights after any cut‐off period, the government had been alerted by the opposition to circumstances which the government had given no consideration to in its original proposals, namely, the sur place claims; that is, claims in respect of a person who arrives in Australia with no intention or cause to seek asylum but for whom, whilst in Australia, circumstances in their home country change in a way that would cause them to legitimately seek Australian protection.

The regulations in SR185 and SR97 do not articulate the way in which the government agreed to deal with the sur place claims. Our spokesman was of the view that it would probably be cumbersome to do so by way of regulations. However, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) has agreed to make a statement in parliament. For the record, the minister has agreed to deal with such claims as effectively as possible, as follows: for individuals, a guarantee of priority processing to be con tained in a section 499 ministerial direction; for groups, a gazette notice mechanism to enable the minister to remove them from the effect of the cut‐off; and for an applicant who does not meet the above, access to work rights to be granted if he or she holds a substantive visa at the time of making the protection visa application and the department has not made a primary decision on the application within six months. I understand the minister agrees that, to remove doubt and to not confine the commitment to the wording of the statement by the minister or the ideas I have outlined here, flexibility may be required and, if so, flexibility will be given to the spirit of the agreement.

There were heaps of measures that we found objectionable. One was the $1,000 post‐decision fee for failed applicants to the RRT. Under the agreement it will remain, but our concerns have been met by the government agreeing to insert a two‐year sunset clause. The matter will also be referred within two years, along with other issues, for review by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

I say those concerns have been met but I must say they have been met only for the moment, because these issues are live issues and ones that we will monitor to ensure that the impact of them is minimised. From our perspective, that $1,000 post‐decision fee is an unconscionable measure but it is one that we have had to live with in the context of trying to get some limitation on the government's regulations.

For these reasons, the opposition tried to seek a constructive outcome, an outcome which we think makes some important changes to the government's regulations. But I do say that we do not do ourselves any service as a nation when we embark upon this domestic bashing policy at home. We have developed a reputation internationally, and developed it over successive governments, as a protector of and assister to refugees and those who come under humanitarian circumstances.

These are the sorts of regulations that Malcolm Fraser would never have bowled up. These are the sorts of regulations the previous Liberal governments would not have bowled up. These are the regulations that this Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and this obsequious minister bowl up. Unfortunately, parliament has to be confronted with the reality of them and we are forced into a situation where we have to try to negotiate a constructive outcome, rather than bowl them over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The disallowance motions before us, moved by Senator Margetts, will be supported by the Australian Democrats. As has been mentioned, they reflect in part a deal that has been struck between the government and the Australian Labor Party, a deal that the Australian Democrats have been neither a party to nor privy to.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations before us put in place a new regime for people to work in Australia, the review periods for applications and the review application fee for both migrants and refugees. As we have already heard from Senator Margetts, the Australian Labor Party, the opposition, previously supported the disallowance motion for statutory rule No. 109; but that was before the former shadow minister, Mr Duncan Kerr, began acting as if he were the parliamentary secretary to the minister for immigration.

The reason—we have been told—for this turnaround, this change, is to prevent abuse in the system. The Australian Democrats believe—as I would expect every party and person in this chamber to believe—that cheats and frauds should be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. However, it is quite a different thing for the government to stigmatise and demonise migrants and refugees as cheats and frauds in the same way, we believe, they have attempted to do that with students and the unemployed. One can only wonder why the opposition would now buy into this political rhetoric when most community leaders and most politicians, we believe, are working hard to douse the hatred flames ignited by an Independent member in the other place.

In classical terms this, yet again, is an attempt to crack a walnut with a sledgehammer. Of course, when that kind of approach is taken, ultimately a lot of other people get caught in the net—cracked as well, if you like. Certainly, Senator Margetts was able to illustrate a number of case studies.

We are concerned that changes like these provide ammunition for the anti‐immigrant and anti‐refugee forces in this country. We are stereotyping all immigrants and refugees in this way. Senator Margetts also pointed out the paucity of documented cases of abuse. We have had no meaningful study as to the extent or nature of so‐called abuse, as was pointed out. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that there are presently 20 million refugees worldwide. Of those, Australia will accept 12,000. Of those, 2,000 designated as refugees will be people who are already here and 10,000 will be persons overseas in need of urgent resettlement.

We can only begin to wonder—and the Democrats are very concerned about this—how these people will manage the new regime being introduced by the coalition and the opposition parties. The Democrats do not believe that bona fide persons should be priced out of the system. As I have said on previous occasions in this place, we do not believe in economically rationalised immigrants. Our policy makes it very clear that refugees should be given priority. The preference for looking after refugee and humanitarian cases is explicitly stated in Democrat policies; and I have made that very clear on a number of occasions in this place.

We believe that all people, despite their personal circumstances, should be assessed on their merits—their personal situation—not on whether or not they can pay their way into this country. If that had been the case in the years following the Second World War, we would have a very different society today.

I would like to draw to the attention of the chamber the provisions of section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act, which stipulate that regulations are not to be remade while subject to a disallowance motion. The provision of that section, in part, states that `no regulation the same in substance as the first‐mentioned regulation shall be made unless' the notice for disallowance has been dealt with by the Senate. The section provides:
A regulation made in contravention of this section has no effect.

I raise this point as a concern of the Australian Democrats. In future the opposition should think twice before hatching similar deals with the government that not only diminish the standing and the rights of migrants and refugees in this country but may be unlawful as well.

Senator Bolkus expressed his concern about the dismantling of the system and the potential erosion of rights, as he certainly perceives in the initial round of the regulations. I appeal to Senator Bolkus and his colleagues: do not let the government dismantle the system and do not let them implement these regressive regulations.

The Democrats will certainly be supporting the disallowance motion before the chamber today. We appeal to colleagues in this chamber—certainly the opposition—to rethink their position and support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that we have before us is a motion by Senator Margetts for the disallowance of certain migration regulations as contained in statutory rules 1997 No. 109 and regulations as contained in statutory rules 1997 No. 185 and made under the Migration Act 1958.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to speak to No. 185 because, for all intents and purposes, that is what we are talking about, which is the result of the discussions that took place between the opposition and the government. I acknowledge that in some ways those discussions resulted in a lessening of some of the harshness of the regulations but I remain of the view that they will still have a substantial negative impact on bona fide asylum seekers.

I heard what Senator Bolkus said and I know that there has been a change of forces midstream. Actually I do not know about it happening midstream, but I understand that Mr Martin Ferguson is now the shadow minister for immigration. I am just wondering what he thinks about the outcome, which we are seeking to disallow. I was interested to hear what Senator Bolkus said. As I heard him, he said, `When in government, we wouldn't have proposed these regulations.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He also used the word `unconscionable'.
—I acknowledge the—
—Interjection.

—Yes. There is a nicer word. I do not think it was really an interjection; it was a supplementary contribution from Senator Margetts. Now that they are in opposition, I do not know why they would not oppose these amendments. Nevertheless, the discussions—no doubt with the minister; he is always open to discussion on matters—have resulted in a lessening of the harshness of the regulations that were previously put forward as statutory rules No. 109.

BREAK.PARA: Statutory rules No. 185 go too far. Their punitive scope go beyond those making abusive claims for protection and they will affect innocent parties. My main concerns—I have a number of others; and I might just acknowledge what Senator Margetts has said as she has covered the field quite extensively—relate to access to work rights and the $1,000 fee. Whilst a 45-day period to apply for work rights is certainly preferable to a 14-day period, those who represent asylum seekers say that many of their clients are falling through the cracks and are without means of support because of this regulation.

Many asylum seekers are vulnerable. They have little English and do not know how to access the determination system. What are these asylum seekers to do if they are unable to prepare a protection visa application within 45 days of arrival? Do we want to be responsible for forcing them into destitution when they have been prohibited from supporting themselves? The problem with this regulation is that no safety nets come with it. As Senator Margetts mentioned, the UNHCR actually condemned similar measures when they were introduced into the UK.

If I can just go to the $1,000 fee: there is no provision for waiving it in cases where an application is found not to be frivolous. I know of many people, especially Chinese asylum seekers fearing persecution on the basis of China's one‐child family policy, who failed at the RRT stage and were later given asylum when the courts found the RRT had erred in its ruling. My concern is that a person who fails at the review stage is, with this $1,000 fee, automatically equated to an abuser of the system.

The system is not perfect, as we know. Asylum seekers who genuinely fear persecution if returned to their homeland have failed to gain protection on our shores. To me, that is refoulement and, to me, we have an obligation not to refoule. That these people were unsuccessful does not at all mean that they were wanting to rort the system.

Unfortunately, other ways of targeting alleged abuses without affecting bone fide asylum seekers were not considered by the government or, alternatively, rejected by the government. Bona fide asylum seekers will be deterred from accessing review procedures. How are they to pay the fee if they are unsuccessful? I understand what Senator Bolkus just said about the two years and about the reference of certain matters to the joint committee. I do not know what the result of that will be, but bona fide asylum seekers will be deterred from accessing the review procedures. How are they to pay the fee if they are unsuccessful? I will come back to that point.

Targeting those who are least able to pay it seems a strange method of cost recovery. Perhaps it is being cynical to suggest that perhaps the intention of the fee is that the unsuccessful applicant will be unable to pay it, will therefore incur a debt to the Commonwealth and will therefore never be able to come back and apply again.

I would like to see evidence of the alleged abuses that are taking place. Why is the only report on this not being released when it was a result of what was originally described by the minister as a public review? I would like the minister to respond to that in her summing up. I will be supporting the motion that has been put forward by Senator Margetts and supported by Senator Stott Despoja.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came in during this debate, Senator Bolkus had already commenced his contribution, and I listened with interest to the remainder of it. In essence, he basically said those opposite do not like this and they do not want to do it but they are going to.

SPEECH.PARA: I had occasion to have a quick look at a release put out by Duncan Kerr, the shadow minister for population issues and immigration, on 25 June this year. It is quite a contrast to what we hear from Senator Bolkus, who tonight spoke on behalf of the former government, the opposition, and to what they said at the time. A couple of quotes might be illuminating:

Both the Government and the Opposition accept that in recent times the refugee stream has been corrupted by some manifestly unfounded claims for refugee status. If this continued, confidence in the system would have been eroded.
There is a clear admission from the opposition that something had to be done—and something reasonably drastic. I will come to some figures on that in a minute. The press release went on:
There is a need to toughen up the system . . . That is why the Opposition had sought a workable response which could be supported by both parties.
He even praises one aspect and says:
An innovative change is that, for people who apply outside the 45 day period, their work rights will be restored after six months if their application has not yet been determined by the Department.
This is a piece of praise from the opposition for these regulations which I did not hear from Senator Bolkus when I listened to his contribution. Mr Kerr goes on to say:
The changes will hit those who seek to abuse a system designed to protect the most vulnerable whilst minimising the impact on genuine claimants.

Senator Harradine is right: when you toughen up a system—it could be any system—there is the likelihood that you will make it harder for some of the genuine people. That is the real crime committed by people who misuse and abuse a system to the point that it has to be tightened up. Sadly, often the people for whom the system is designed are disadvantaged, and it is because of the people who misuse it.

I said I would give some indication of why Duncan Kerr had said there was a need to toughen up the system and that the refugee stream had `been corrupted by some manifestly unfounded claims'. I would like to quote briefly from Mr Ruddock's response to a question in the other place in June. He said:

However, this year we expect to receive some 10,000 applications for refugee status in Australia, and possibly more. That is 20 times more than we saw only seven years ago. The cost of assessing all of those claims through the various stages with the judicial intervention, asylum seeker support and the like is over $60 million a year.

A large number of the applications are not coming from residents of countries that are generally associated with human rights abuses. Numbers have come from the Philippines, Tonga, Fiji and Thailand. This financial year, the department has finalised more than 3,000 applications from those countries that I have mentioned and has been able to identify only four bona fide refugees.
That bears repeating—of the 3,000 applications finalised this financial year only four were identified as bona fide refugees. Minister Ruddock went on to say:

People are turning up at my department and asking for a $30 work visa, the name by which we understand the protection visa is now becoming known. By lodging an application, such individuals can obtain work rights in Australia and they know that they cannot be sent home until after their refugee application has been properly assessed and considered by the department, possibly the Refugee Review Tribunal, accessing my discretion—
that is, the minister's—
and applications to the courts. We also know that, in many cases, what they are seeking is access to Medicare, benefits for which they have in no way paid or contributed.

That is just a brief excerpt from statements Mr Ruddock made recently. I think it strengthens the case argued by Duncan Kerr, the shadow minister for immigration and multicultural affairs, in relation to these matters.

In relation to Senator Stott Despoja's contribution, I am constantly left almost speechless by the Australian Democrats' contributions on these matters. As you may know, Madam Acting Deputy President Patterson, the Democrats apparently have a zero net migration policy and yet consistently seek to frustrate the government's agenda. Last year, for example, we were seeking to get through the parliament some changes in regulations that would have slightly reduced and changed the composition of migrant intake. Despite the fact that the Democrats have a zero net migration policy, they nonetheless refused to accept any of those changes. It is sort of, `We want the world to be black, but we want it to be white as well and we do not have to explain why the two never meet.'

The 45-day cut-off period for work rights is perhaps worth mentioning. There has been a suggestion that these will force people to make hasty and poorly prepared applications. The government does not accept that that is the case. I think Senator Harradine might have been the one to raise this matter. All a person has to do is lodge an initial application and their claims are going to be assessed thoroughly.

The cost of these matters is worth highlighting. I did understand someone to say that we do not want these things to be dealt with in an economically rationalist way as if to say that is all that is behind these changes. But, equally, we are accountable to taxpayers for how we use their funds. To simply say that we want to exercise care in the spending of money does not mean that you are necessarily pursuing any particular ideological bent; you are simply doing what everyone in this place ought to be doing—that is, exercising care in the expenditure of taxpayers' funds.

I will give an example of non-refugee cases. The review fees are refundable if you win. I understand Senator Margetts raised this point and said that she knew people who did not want to pay because they could not be guaranteed that they would win. That is the nature of a review, Senator. It is an independent assessment, and there is no guarantee. If they could be guaranteed that they would win, it would be a case of purchasing a decision. I do not really think, Senator, that you want to be on record as supporting a system where people are permitted to purchase a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said, and you know it!
—Perhaps I will continue and come back to that, Senator Margetts. The import of what you said—
—Senator Vanstone, could you please direct your comments through the chair?

—I would be delighted to. I only wish other people would do the same. Then it would not be so enticing for people to respond to them. What Senator Margetts did say was, in effect, that people do not want to pay because they do not get any guarantee that they are going to win their appeal. It follows that if what you are saying is that they would pay if they could be guaranteed that they would win their appeal, then you are, in a sense, saying that if you sold these thing it would be okay. That is what a guaranteed outcome is.

BREAK.PARA: In any event, the review fees are refundable if you win. The unit cost of an Immigration Review Tribunal matter is somewhere around $3,200—$850 is about 25 per cent of that. The rest of it is paid by Australian taxpayers who expect a system to be a workable, sensible system—not a half-hearted system and definitely not one where there are 3,000 applicants in one year only four of which are considered to be bona fide. They do not expect that. For refugee cases, the review is free. But it is true that $1,000 is payable if you lose.

Let me turn briefly to the matters raised by Senator Stott Despoja. She had some concerns that the regulations put in place as a result of the agreement between the government and the opposition on these matters may be in breach of section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act and thus invalid. I understand her concern is that the amending regulations may be the same in substance as the regulations that are subject to her disallowance motion. I can confirm that advice has been received from the Attorney-General's Department that the amending regulations are in fact valid. I understand that the Senate has been given a copy of that advice, as have the opposition, Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine.

In essence, the legal advice is that the regulations do not infringe the Acts Interpretation Act and are therefore valid. This is because they are not the same in substance as the regulations subject to Senator Margetts's motion, as the legal advice points out at paragraph 6, and they are indeed substantially different. If the Senate wants, I would be happy to table those. But I understand senators have them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be nice, thank you.
—In which case, I seek leave to table the advice.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators would be aware, in statutory rules No. 109, the government put in place a series of measures which seek to reduce the number of unmeritorious claims for refugee status. While the government has a non-negotiable commitment to ensuring that people seeking refugee status have their claims properly and responsibly considered, it is most concerned that the process is being abused by certain applicants `buying time' in Australia when they are not entitled to refugee status.

BREAK.PARA: In addressing these concerns, the government introduced a number of measures contained in statutory rules No. 109 which are aimed at deterring unmeritorious applicants from lodging claims for refugee status. For example, the amendments reduce the time period within which applications for review by the Refugee Review Tribunal must be lodged. They introduce a $1,000 post‐decision fee for unsuccessful refugee review tribunal applicants and limit access to work rights for protection visa applicants where they have not lodged their application within 14 days of being in Australia.

Statutory rules No. 109 also contains measures aimed at addressing other abuses within the system by reducing the time period within which applications for internal review or for review by the IRT must be lodged; by removing certain refund provisions in relation to internal review and review by the IRT; and by including in special assistance category visas the requirement that, before being granted the visa, the minister must be satisfied that the applicant is not eligible for a permanent visa of any other class.

Following the making of statutory rule No. 109, the government met with the opposition to discuss those sorts of measures. I am advised that those meetings resulted in an agreement to work constructively towards reducing the number of unmeritorious claims by making some further amendments as follows. The application period for review of refugee decisions is to remain at 28 days and the period for internal review and review by the IRT is to be set at 21 days. The existing provisions for refund of review fees of successful applicants for migration internal and external review are to continue. However, the external review fee would be increased to $850 to ensure there was no effect on the budget. A further amendment will introduce a two‐year sunset clause to the regulation requiring a $1,000 post‐decision fee for unsuccessful review applicants. In the meantime, we will be asking the Joint Standing Committee on Migration to review the issues in 1998.

Another amendment is to replace the 14‐day period in which a protection visa application must be made in order to attract work rights with a 45‐day period. For people with sur place refugee claims, there will be regulations enabling the minister to remove specified groups of people from the effect of the work rights cut‐off as necessary. Individual sur place refugee claimants affected by lack of work rights will have the effect minimised by priority processing. We expect to make provision for this in a ministerial direction.

For people who have substantive visas at the time of making protection visa applications, we will allow access to work rights if the department has not made a primary decision on the application after six months of the application being lodged. In other words, there have been some constructive negotiations.

I want to refer briefly to the press release of Duncan Kerr, who is the shadow spokesperson. On 25 June he clearly thought that something needed to be done. That is why he said that the opposition accepts that in recent times the refugee stream has been corrupted by some manifestly unfounded claims for refugee status. He went on to say that, if it continued, confidence in the system would have been eroded.

I understand that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) and the opposition spokesman have remained in touch on these issues and have agreed that it is essential that the measures which have been put in place to address the abuse in the onshore refugee determination process and review systems proceed unhindered. Therefore, we are very grateful that the opposition has indicated that it will support the government in opposing these disallowance motions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have seen one of the nastier aspects of scapegoat politics in Australia. We have seen the ongoing politics of blame. That is, you find the people who are least able to fight back, who have the least power in our society—in the world, in fact—and you blame them for those things that are going wrong in your country. The blame is delivered in an around about way, but the scapegoat politics say that, if things are not going right in your own country, you find a way of taking people's minds off those things and find them to blame. So you blame Aboriginal people, the unemployed, the young and refugees. It works very well. Here it is working well again.

SPEECH.PARA: It has never been the case that there are no other options available. If there are people who are using refugee applications for work solely, there have been constructive suggestions made—and this was not mentioned by the minister—by non-government organisations, and the government has refused to consider them. They are not interested in dealing with solving or directing against perceived problems. As I mentioned in my main contribution, they are not actually interested in targeting those people who are actually breaking the law—that is, those people who are giving that advice and profiting from giving advice who may be sponsoring people who are wanting to work.

Of the countries that the minister mentioned, one was Thailand. It springs to mind that there are a number of people in Thailand whom I have heard of in border camps who may well not get their applications approved in Australia because they slip in between those cracks. They may well have a situation where they have not been able to get other individual people to sign documents which prove that they were tortured. About two weeks ago I heard from a person who has come from Burma a month ago who gave a vivid, heart-rending description of systematic torture within Burma.

It could well be that people in camps in Thailand could be classified as not being able to prove their origins, as not being able to prove that they have been systematically tortured. They may well fall amongst those 3,000. It may well be that there are changes in government policies which mean that only four are judged to be bona fide for various other reasons. But it may also be that Australia is closing its eyes to some instances in the Philippines, for example, where there are constant and daily dangers to people's lives. There are parts of the Philippines where living and staying in those areas will mean constant and daily dangers to their lives and their futures.

It is interesting: only four refugees were judged to be bona fide. There were 3,000 applications and only four were judged to be bona fide. You have to wonder just how many people from those countries also slipped between the cracks. It is not a case where the government can say, `Simply those abusing the system are responsible.' In relation to those people who are murdered, who are raped, who are in gaol for the rest of their lives because of this measure, you and the Labor Party cannot sit and say, `Those people who are responsible are those people who may be from Tonga, or maybe some other applications are being given the advice to apply in a certain way.' You cannot say that you are not responsible for their deaths and tortures and rapes. You cannot sit here and say that you are innocent of what will happen to those people because they somehow slipped between the cracks in the system and have not been able to jump your hurdles.

How dare you say that somehow or other not supporting this disallowance motion means that people in this system indicate that they support rorting the system. There are ways of dealing with that. You have not even talked to those groups who are suggesting ways that they can be dealt with. You want to blame those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, I think you are straying and not directing your comments through the chair.

—Sorry. Madam Acting Deputy President, it is a very emotional argument. I guess we will have to see whether or not the Acts Interpretation Act will hold water. If this disallowance motion does not get support within the Senate, then there will potentially still be challenges to it in the way it was done. Be that on your own head as a government. I wonder, if we were to do an assessment of how trade agreements and the granting of refugee status balanced up in Australia, just how that would work and how many people would end up having their lives threatened because of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus said that the $1,000 fine was unconscionable. Yes. The fact that we have had a change of shadow minister in the meantime, between when notice of this motion of disallowance was first given and the debate today, just makes you wonder how it might have changed—whether or not those people who will be forced to return to appalling, inhumane circumstances would have had their lives saved if there were a different shadow minister. That is as bland as it may be. I just wonder whether or not there ought to be some rule that people ought to be strapped to their chairs to listen to the stories of torture and find out what it is like to be systematically raped, find out what it is like to have their families killed and find out what it is like to live in constant fear of being picked up and put into prison. I wonder whether those people who suddenly judge it simply as a matter of economic risk or fraud believe that. I wonder whether that has ever touched their hearts in any real way.

I do not think there is a lot more I can say in this regard, except to say that the government were offered means to deal with the issue of potential fraud. They chose not to use them. They chose to use the means of scapegoat politics—`Blame the victims; go for populist polls; let's make it look as if everybody who is applying for refugee status is a potential cheat on the system; and let's get some votes in a cheap, nasty, cruel way.' I commend my motion to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I believe I have been misrepresented.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time today the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave credence to a headline in the Age newspaper which read `Kernot warns of six‐month delay on Wik bill'. If the Prime Minister or his staff had bothered to read the transcript of the interview I gave on Meet the Press , he would have heard a question of clarification from Laura Tingle from the Age as to whether I was proposing that the Senate delay its discussion of native title issues until the High Court determines the issue of the race power. I answered:

BREAK.PARA: No, I'm not saying that.
I repeat that: no, I am not saying that. My answer continued:
I'm sure we could start, but I think it would be incredibly counter‐productive if we were to get to the end and find that the High Court then requires us to go back . . .

The Prime Minister has, I believe, deliberately misrepresented me. One can speculate rather imaginatively as to the reasons for this. I take this opportunity to set the record straight. It is unfortunate because this debate has already been characterised by extreme hyperbole and misrepresentation, and I believe the Prime Minister demeans himself to add to that at this crucial stage of the debate.

BREAK.XREF: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION (REPEALS, TRANSITIONAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude my remarks by formally moving our second reading amendment to the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 . I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

PARA.TAB: "but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) expresses its concern at the monopolisation of economic advice under the Treasury portfolio, with the abolition of Economic Planning and Advisory Council and the Bureau of Industry Economics meaning the disappearance of independent sources of economic and industry policy advice to the Prime Minister and to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism;
(2) expresses its concern that the centralising of economic and industry policy advice under one Minister increases the risk of the Government adopting inappropriate policies in these areas;

(3) expresses its concern on the basis of the interim Productivity Commission's now completed reports on Micro‐Economic Reform and the Motor Vehicle Industry, that the new Productivity Commission will be far more preoccupied with advancing the Government's political and ideological agenda than with balanced, sensible and technically sound advice assisting industry development; and
(4) expresses its strong preference for an alternative structure for industry and productivity related advice to Ministers, one that:

PARA.TAB: (a) is provided by a diverse range of fully qualified and experienced individuals and organisations, not operating solely under a Treasury umbrella;
(b) fully involves industry, trade union and relevant community groups in the development of advice; and
(c) has full regard to the larger economic, social and especially regional consequences of the advice given".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments about the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 . Australian industry is demanding a commitment from this government. What we need is an economic advisory body that advocates pro‐active, clear and distinctive industry policy that is aimed at providing Australia with a sustainable industry program. What we do not need is a monolithic, myopic institution that has at its heart the driest form of economic rationalism. Because of the Productivity Commission's adherence to this economic theory, it ignores the complex reality of Australian economic life.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber are only too aware that economic rationalism does not prescribe for a government industry policy. This paradigm does not advocate for industry help. What the Productivity Commission will advocate because of its adherence to the economic rationalist paradigm is an absence of what this government calls `market distortions' created by what this government refers to as `an interfering government', and that the market forces drive prosperity and that minimal government is advantageous.

The Productivity Commission will argue that Australian business should not compete with other countries in businesses that they are successful in. For example, the Productivity Commission says there is no point competing with the IT&T industries in Ireland and there is no point competing with the IT&T industries in Israel because they are successful at it. The comparative advantage of nations comes into the equation. The Productivity Commission will prescribe an Australian economic efficiency market fuelled by self‐interested individuals; therefore the Productivity Commission will argue that the market determines industrial outcomes and will allocate resources premised on purely market forces.

It appears that the Productivity Commission has a slogan: `Get the economics fundamentals right and she'll be right'. It is not just the Productivity Commission that argues this; this is the fundamental premise on which this government operates. By the very presence of this set of bills before the chamber there is no denying that the coalition government wishes to institute a body that will be a tenacious adherent to one economic theory, and that is economic rationalism. In its driest form this economic theory does not prescribe policy directions for social justice or social welfare; this theory assumes that poverty would be overcome if an efficient market were allowed to reign supreme. It is what used to be known as the old trickle down theory, although there are probably less edifying terms for it which I will not go into here.

For example, this theory's proponents argue that unemployment is a voluntary action because of the refusal to allow minimum wages to be set. There is no reason to believe that the Productivity Commission is going to act any differently.
