By implementing this set of bills as they are it will be the catalyst and the harbinger of the collapse of an alternative competing economic advice bureau, which I understand Senator Sherry has already referred to. With the passage of these bills all competing advice will have been legislated out of existence.

The Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 will be the implementing tool by which this government will filter out all dissenting comment, and economic advice will be through one portfolio: Treasury, who will reign supreme in the field of economic policy. It is not just us who are uncomfortable about the notion of Treasury having what seems to be a fairly omnipotent power in relation to economic theory. I would be very surprised if there were not members on the other side who had concerns in relation to this.

The Productivity Commission set of bills before this chamber is signalling the death knell of rational and balanced economic advice. The implementation of these two bills will see the institutionalisation of the Productivity Commission's power as the dominant economic advice bureau. It will see the institutionalisation of the driest form of economic rationalism. It will be the institutionalisation of a government body's view of Australian society in the narrowest of economic terms. The implementation of this set of bills will institute a government body that divorces social equity and wealth redistribution from government policy. They will not be factored into the equation. The Productivity Commission does not consider those aspects of Australian life as important in terms of its economic modelling.
As Professor Quiggin comments in his submission to the Economics Committee on the Productivity Commission:
The dominance of the Productivity Commission creates a danger that erroneous and even incoherent assumptions may be applied consistently.

Implicit in the setting up of this commission is the abolition of two alternative economic advice bureaus: the Bureau of Industry Economics and the Economic Planning and Advisory Commission. EPAC, with its origin in the 1983 economic summit, was an important body. It was important because it provided an alternative public advice bureau. It was an avenue that public bodies, non‐government organisations and the general public could access to discuss different economic policy views. This was a critical forum for providing not only alternative views but also economic education. From the number of economic policies that it discussed and passed advice on, EPAC showed that it has the capacity to interact with the community and stakeholders in an open and genuine way. Unfortunately it could be argued that EPAC is just another institution that is paying the price for being created during the Labor government. Once again the coalition is dismantling a forum, in my view, because of ideological spite.

The BIE, because of its position within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and its attachment to the industry, science and tourism portfolio, provides another avenue to seek alternative economic advice. This body conducted examinations on a plethora of industry issues, playing an important part in distinguishing Australia's industry and economic framework. Under this set of bills, BIE and EPAC will cease to exist. They will be exterminated because of ignorance and blind arrogance in relation to having one conduit for economic advice and the supremacy of Treasury.

Under Labor we promoted the competitive advice model, where economic advice was gathered from a number of sources. It was a significant way to ensure that economic policy differentials were canvassed and a variety of competing views judged on their merits. With this set of bills we have a body that argues from a narrow and blinkered economic viewpoint to its own and to Australian industry's detriment. Because of its inherent nature the Productivity Commission will push for economic efficiency that discounts any social and environmental consequences of economically efficient markets where resources have been allocated efficiently. The Productivity Commission is not in the business of taking into account social factors or environmental factors. They are not even considered in relation to this. Therefore Australian society will be defined by the Productivity Commission in the narrowest terms: productivity and allocative efficiency.

BREAK.PARA: I would remind the chamber of a number of recommendations that have emanated from this commission, most of which are encapsulated in this wonderful document called `Microsteps to Economic Reform', which I understand Senator Sherry referred to earlier. I might add that it was written by a commission that does not even legally exist yet.

The report clearly states the commission's claim to be arbiter in education, health, community services, taxation, environment, industry policy and federal relations. It believes that it can achieve an efficient, well ordered society by attaching a price to every individual activity of judges, nurses, teachers, RAAF pilots, park rangers and so on. For example, for law and order the Productivity Commission suggests scrapping the police force and hiring private security guards and detective agencies. Ridiculous!

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7 p.m. to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of Senator Mackay's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: For the RAAF, the Productivity Commission recommends that the services should be contracted out to some no frills airlines for the supply of air defence, air strike, long range maritime surveillance, close battle field ground support and troop transport.

The Productivity Commission follows the maxim that every and any thing that government provides should be contestable. It presupposes that people are educated enough to understand the choices that they have in front of them, that Productivity Commission bills they will gather information to help them to make a informed choice. However, given the recommendations the Productivity Commission made in their submission to the west review on education, its highly unlikely that people will be able to afford the education in order to make a informed decision.
It's interesting to note that despite the commission advocating the contracting out of government services, it doesn't suggest its own economic advice be contracted out.
The government believes in contracting out all of its services however, Mr Howard doesn't look at contracting out economic advice, instead he creates this monolith.

The Productivity Commission will be a flawed institution, if only for its support of suspect quantitative methodology. Now you don't have to be an economist with a special inner glow for econometrics to see that the Orani and the Monash models are flawed in their assumptions.

The commission used the Orani model to arrive at their assumptions in their micro economic report. The inputs used were premised on time periods that were so short that no fixed asset could be introduced into, or removed from, any production process, so short that no exchange rate could vary, so short that no household could begin to spend any increase in income.

However there was a wonderful paradox that for some aspects the time period was so long that all prices adjust fully to a change in wages which adjust fully to prices which adjust fully to wages ad infinitum. What a surprise!

The fundamental flaw in the Orani model is the assumption of full employment. Now we all know that there isn't full employment, yet Costello and Howard seem to have suffered amnesia, or is it rather a case of wishful thinking? How can we implement a economic advice bureaus recommendations that are premised on suspected parameters.
If this commission was not going to have such an impact upon Australian society, the institution would be farcical.

A derivative of the Orani model, the Monash model, used to justify the cut in car tariffs, is just as suspect. This model again has reasonably simplistic views. The Monash model believes that the gains estimate will vastly exceed an approximate upper estimate of the gain provided by a simple rule of thumb based on imports.

What we have before us is a commission that uses suspect econometrics which have been savaged by economists, business and academics. And because of this set of bills, the Productivity Commission will be unchallenged.
This set of bills will create as the unions argue a entrenchment of power of the Productivity Commission as the epitome of dominance of economic fundamentalism in government decision making.

In conjunction with this is the concern I have over the virtual monopolisation of economic policy advice under the treasury portfolio which will adversely effect Australian industry. This will only mean that more people will being losing their jobs.
As the 29 July 1996 Sydney Morning Herald article said:
in the name of reform, Peter Costello is engineering a big reduction in the amount, diversity and breath of view of economic research done by federal agencies.

Inherent within this monopolisation of research and economic information, is the removal of key institutions from the portfolio of prime minister and cabinet to the auspices and the control of treasury. It has been argued quite succinctly in the press that the manipulation of the Productivity Commission by treasury is the culmination of its efforts to restore the monopoly over pretty much all of the economic advice that it had lost to prime minister and cabinet.

By putting the Productivity Commission under Mr Costello's effective control the commission will act as a intellectual filter. That's it pure and simple. The Productivity Commission will act as a sponge for economic rationalist policies and a barrier to competing and dissenting economic views.

This control over economic advice will signify the death knell for industry policy. For as we already know and are aware Mr Costello is not an strong patron of industry policy—or as he defines it "business welfare".

This attitude is inherent within the department of treasury. The treasury's intellectual horizon is limited, it does not have the academic ability to analyse regional differences or look at the economy in terms of industry. This will be further exacerbated with the introduction of the Productivity Commission.

The clearest example of this are the comments made by Mr Staples, from the Industry Commission. Mr staples slammed the Mortimer Report saying that there was a lack of depth in its analysis and that he had grave concerns about the "call for a one billion dollar fund to attract investment."

I suppose it shouldn't have been too much a surprise, however the Mortimer report is one of three reports damning the government's lack of industry policy. The MTIA report even went as far as saying that there was now a political imperative to get industry policy under way.

The absence of any sign that qualitative research is used in treasury analysis raises the question about the fundamental nature of this department. What does it take for treasury to realise that there are people attached to quantitative research? Or is the treasury and Costello not overly concerned that for example, one hundred thousand TCF workers could join that "work for the dole" queue with no hope of ever getting off. Or is the government looking for more participants for its work for the dole scheme? One hundred thousand workers could lose their jobs all because the treasury, Costello and Productivity Commission don't want to be seen as dealing out "industry welfare".

How many examples does this government need to show them that major sections of the manufacturing sector are leaving? In the last month we have had Gloweave, Berlei, Clark's, Dupont's and in my own state Blundstone's leaving or threatening to leave.
Last Thursday the senate supported an alp motion to freeze tariffs until 2005. It will remain to be seen whether the government will respect the Senate's wishes.
This coalition government is abandoning our industry, whilst the Productivity Commission sits back and argues that we don't pay enough attention to agriculture and mining sectors.

I'm not inferring that we should forget those sectors, however there is an urgent need for the manufacturing sector and industry as a whole to receive more than tacit support and lip service. We cannot afford to keep losing our industry assets.

The TCF tariff issue is one case in point. The Productivity Commission, otherwise known as the industry commission, recommendations are to cut TCF tariffs from up to thirty seven percent to five percent by the year 2008.

If the Productivity Commission implements its TCF report's recommendations then we are in immediate danger of losing and selling off our talent to our overseas competitors. We are exporting our jobs, our skilled labour and our talent.

A reduction in TCF tariffs will effect three thousand companies and one hundred thousand full time jobs. Regional areas, such as Tasmania and the nation as a whole cannot sustain this loss. One hundred thousand people who are directly employed will be thrown on the scrap heap. And that figure doesn't even account for those people who are reliant on TCF industries for their business such as the small corner shop, retail shops, supermarkets—basically every business that TCF workers patronise will lose if the Productivity Commission's recommendations are taken up.
TCF industries are represented in every state, they play a significant and crucial role in state economies.

Tasmania is one such state that cannot afford to lose industries. The Tasmanian economy is not just standing on the brink of the economic abyss it is in it. The Nixon report would have told the prime minister this—but rumour has it that his office doesn't even know of the reports existence.

If the Howard government implements the Productivity Commission's recommendations, it will be further damning evidence that Howard has abandoned Tasmania. The Productivity Commissions recommendations will see the loss of two thousand, three hundred jobs. That is one thousand jobs in the south, five hundred in the north and seven hundred on the west coast.
This job loss will destroy regional communities. It will push Tasmania further into the economic black hole. And ultimately the responsibility for this will be at John Howard's feet.

As all senators would be aware, a major Tasmanian family business, Blundstones announced last Wednesday of its planned move offshore if the government implemented the soon to be Productivity Commission's recommendations.

This company is one of Tasmania's success stories, it has been producing boots since 1870. During its one hundred and seventy years of production, it has employed generations of Tasmanians. Now three hundred and fifty young Tasmanians are facing a uncertain future.
As Tony Stacey, chief executive of Blundstones said;

We need at least the same level of certainty from the Howard government as they have given the motor vehicle industry. . . we need and ask no more from policy makers than to ensure our industry has a level playing field on which to compete internationally.
Tasmania needs every job and every industry it has, we simply cannot afford to lose anymore because of the government's complete disregard for regional areas.

Tasmania has already lost ten thousand jobs in the last eighteen months. Let me make this very clear to all senators, ten thousand jobs in eighteen months means twenty jobs per day, one hundred and forty jobs a week, five hundred and fifty per month gone. We only have one hundred and thirty five thousand, five hundred full time jobs left in the state. That is sixty thousand less than the population of Hobart. If the Howard government has its way and implements the Productivity Commission's recommendations then there will only be one hundred and thirty three thousand, two hundred jobs left in the state.
Tasmania is haemorrhaging—we are losing jobs and we are losing skilled labour.

We simply cannot afford this jobs drain anymore. Reduction in TCF tariffs means for Tasmania's economy a loss of around forty eight million dollars in wages, will Mr Staples come down and tell Tasmanians that we can afford this? I doubt it.

Mr Howard came to Tasmania, but could not bring himself to face Tasmanians and could not bring himself to talk at the CEDA forum on regional development. It would appear that John Howard has lost interest in Tasmanians and their economic fate. It would appear that Mr Howard simply does not have a commitment to Tasmania. Or maybe one of his advisers left Tasmania off the map!

Howard has dug himself a grave, a grave that is called the Productivity Commission whose adherence to hard economic rationalism will cost the Australian people more money than the supposed savings this commission projects.
Howard's government has instituted a body that will be a reflection of this government's true agenda.

If this set of bills are passed unamended then we will lose the depth of knowledge and debate that has arisen because of competing economic advice bureau. Industry, unions and community groups would have lost an important forum which aided the development of economic advice.

We will lose rational and balanced economic advice emanating from a range of government portfolios. Thereby relinquishing the diversity and range of fully qualified and experienced individuals and organisations.

Instead we will have instituted the dominance of the Treasury and the Productivity Commission over all economic policy and advice. And there will be no regard for the larger economic, social and regional consequences of the Productivity Commission's advice.
We will have instituted the government's ideology and agenda, which will be expressed through the Productivity Commission's recommendations .

We will have instituted the driest form of economic rationalism which will have not have a government economic advice voice against it. We will have instituted a piece of legislation, if unamended will have dire consequences for industry and therefore for working Australians. And for those who haunt the dole queues it will signal the end of hope for a job, a future, and self esteem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 and the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 . The bills authorise the takeover of the Bureau of Industry Economics and the Economic Planning Advisory Commission by the Industry Commission, to be refashioned as the Productivity Commission. The new Productivity Commission then gets all of the reporting powers of the old Industry Commission plus a couple of massive new powers, like its own proactive research and the power to receive and investigate so‐called competitive neutrality complaints.

SPEECH.PARA: I am on the record for years here as being an ardent critic of the old Industry Commission, and the Democrats do not think Australia needs a productivity commission either. Indeed, I think the tide in Australia is turning and that the barren, heartless, soulless and ultimately gainless ideology of the Industry Commission, trading as the Productivity Commission, is now out of step with the needs of the nation. This is evidenced by the enormously popular decision by the government, supported and let us say urged on by the Democrats and Labor, to reject the commission's recommendations on motor vehicle tariffs, and the near unanimity that any call from the commission to cut TCF tariffs should also be rejected.

The Democrats think that the $25 million the government intends to spend this year propping up the ideological outpouring of the Productivity Commission would be far better spent commissioning independent expert reports from Australian and international experts on how best to position Australia for the 21st century.

The very best part of these two bills, the part that the Democrats will wholeheartedly support, is the schedule abolishing the Industry Commission. The Industry Commission and its predecessor, the Industries Assistance Commission—which was a euphemistic title, I think, considering it was really the industries abolition commission—have done untold damage to the Australian economy, particularly to our manufacturing sector, over the past two decades. I give notice that I will be seeking to have the second reading motion divided to allow us to vote against the Productivity Commission bill but in favour of the consequential amendments bill.

I am afraid history will record that the Industry Commission was the creation of the Labor government and that its ideological zealotry underpinned Labor's industry and tariff policies of the last decade. I cannot understand Labor's continuing support for this dressed‐up Industry Commission with a powerful, expanded mandate. I cannot understand that they do not recognise that it has the same potential for job shedding, tax cutting, flat earth ideology as the old Industry Commission dished up to a generation of Labor ministers.

Interestingly, the ACTU, in its submission to the Senate committee on this bill, urged that the bill be opposed. We agree with the ACTU that the commission would pick up the worst prejudices and practices of the Industry Commission but in a way that is less open and accountable. The ACTU concluded in its submission:

There is nothing to indicate that the commission would have the capacity or the will to recognise the interests of industries, consumers and the community, the social and environmental consequences of measures proposed by the commission, which it would be required to have regard to under the general policy guidelines in section 8 of the bill.

Labor proposes amendments, but in their amendments what we see is a further amendment of these policy guidelines; guidelines which we know the zealots of the commission will twist to their own purposes.

If Labor fails to support us in opposing this bill, we will be proposing very strict guidelines, particularly on what must and must not be included in the reports of the commission. We think this approach is far tighter than the wimpy nature of the Labor amendments.

Time and time again the old Industry Commission, at the bidding of the Labor government which created it, could be relied on to call for cuts in tariffs, cuts in public spending, cuts in all forms of regulation, cuts in wages—irrespective of the impact of these on unemployment or on communities or society generally. You could rely on the good old Industry Commission to crank up the old ORANI model to spew out great predictions of how much better off the country would be if only the government and its nasty taxes would disappear and the market were allowed to run unfettered.

But of course the Industry Commission goes missing in action when time and time again its forecasts of an economic nirvana fail to arrive. Each time the commission has an answer to this. When we say, `Where is the nirvana? Where is the paradise? We have had 14 years now: where is the evidence?', what does the commission do? It simply moves the goalposts further to the right across the wasteland of the level playing field and says, `Oh, it has not worked yet because even more reform is required to get it going.'

The Industry Commission's greatest failure, I think, was that it always had a blind spot for the casualties of its recommendations. Former Democrat senator Sid Spindler was one of those who constantly kept track of the impact of the Industry Commission's policy failures. The 1993 report of his independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development evidenced widespread job losses caused by tariff cuts closing down large chunks of Australian industry. The report found that tariff cuts as advocated by the Industry Commission had cost hundreds of thousands of jobs, but that the so‐called benefit of lower prices—which was meant to be the big trade‐off—had not eventuated. The proportion of manufactured goods sold in Australia and also made in Australia fell from around 65 per cent to less than 50 per cent during the 1980s.

In more recent years, the Industry Commission was encouraged by the former government to move outside its original role of destroying the Australian manufacturing sector. It was asked to destroy the public sector as well. This is what that wonderful big bang reform called `competition policy' was all about. In 1995, the Industry Commission, enormously enthused about the then Prime Minister's plan to force the public sector to compete, was asked to produce a report on the benefits of competition policy. The report promised a $23 billion bonanza and a five per cent rise in national GDP if only the public sector was forced to be more like the private sector. It sounds like the Demtel man, doesn't it?

Professor John Quiggin, an ANU macroeconomist, sat down and carefully analysed this report. He found it was riddled with double‐counting errors; broad, brash generalisations of benefits; and complete omissions of transitional and adjustment costs. In short, it was just plain faulty, and seriously so. Correcting the report for all its errors, this big promised benefit was frittered down from $23 billion to just $1 billion to $2 billion. That is a huge difference.

The last few years have not been good years for the Industry Commission and its much criticised ORANI model. Last year it produced its highly controversial report on the car industry, predicting a national economic gain of $1½ billion from zero car tariffs. After criticism from the private sector, this figure was revised down to just $75 million with just a six per cent fall in industry employment. Chris Murphy, from Econtech, one of the modellers who identified the flaws in the commission's original model, said, `You are still wrong.' He forecast that 24 per cent of jobs in the industry would go, and that is 10,000 in South Australia alone compared with the 1,000 estimated by the commission. So we have $23 billion to $1 billion to $2 billion and 10,000 jobs to 1,000 jobs, and we are staking the whole future of policy development on this faulty reckoning.

Brian Toohey, in his excellent book Tumbling Dice: the story of modern economic policy, provides a whole chapter on the continued failure of the ORANI model and the damage caused by the commission's reliance on it. Too often commission reports based on ORANI have been accepted on face value by successive governments who want to believe that the sword of ideology of economic rationalism preached by the Industry Commission would work. They did—they fervently wanted to believe that. That was their world view.

In recent years I should acknowledge that, with its broader policy role, the commission has been developing what I suppose purists would call deviant or, at best, revisionist tendencies because the commission has occasionally produced reports that were based on unbiased assessments of the usually overwhelming evidence free from the usual ideological hang‐ups. But, of course, these reports were not the ones that were welcomed by the government because they did not have the ideological set‐up that was to prepare us for the next move in the government's policy agenda.

I would have to cite the commission's report on public housing, its report on research and development and its recent report on the private health industry as three clear exceptions to the prevailing rule because these are reports that made recommendations on a positive role for government in these industries and these are recommendations that this government has chosen to completely ignore. I suppose the new Productivity Commission will stop deviating from the rigid ideological framework that is set up in the future because these messages are clearly not the messages that its masters now want to hear.

The Democrats think the bill before us is dangerous in expanding the role of an ideologically driven organisation that has already been shown to rely on faulty theory, faulty modelling and a faulty view of the real world. I am particularly disturbed by provisions in the bill that would make such an organisation the impartial investigator of competitive neutrality disputes. For a start, the Democrats do not support the nature of competitive neutrality disputes. Does the public sector have a massive competitive advantage over the private sector? Doesn't the private sector have a massive competitive advantage over the public sector because the private sector is not required to be publicly accountable through the parliament for its activities because it is not expected to provide comprehensive service to all those who need it, as is the basis of public service?

In short, I do not believe that we need a body to hear complaints about competitive neutrality and, even if we did, the one‐eyed ideologues at the Productivity Commission would be exactly the wrong people to hear such complaints. Imagine a public sector agency trying to persuade such right‐wing ideologues of the importance of universal service obligations. Senator Campbell is frowning. He has not been paying attention to the good old Industry Commission and its history; I have. I think it is fair to call them right‐wing ideologues. Imagine trying to persuade them of the importance of universal service obligations or the importance of accountability, democracy or social responsibility because these are not variables in the ORANI model of the Australian economy. Therefore, they are not regarded as important in the Industry Commission's view of the world. So it is fatally flawed from the beginning.

The Democrats will be voting against this bill at both the second and third reading stages. We think the Industry Commission has done enough damage to the Australian econ omy and its institutions. We think that to propose expanding its role, renaming it, giving it new powers and telling it to do more is simply inviting more social and economic dislocation. If, however, the bill does proceed to the committee stage, we will be moving a number of amendments that seek to modify the operating guidelines of the commission to take into account matters that are essential to the development of industry—matters such as ecological sustainability and social sustainability. We want to require the commission to give more consideration to the employment, social and community impacts of its recommendations. We want to require it by law to provide alternatives rather than a single dogmatic position.

To continue in the guise of broadening the considerations to match the commission's broader role, the Democrats will also be moving amendments to require at least one of the commissioners to be experienced in the principles of ecological sustainability, and at least one to be experienced in social welfare services. We think that this would help balance the dry economics of the commission's dominant paradigm. But, most of all, the Democrats would prefer to see this bill defeated. We hope the Labor Party will join us in killing the Productivity Commission and the Industry Commission. This would be a welcome break with Labor's past.

As I said, I will be seeking to have the motion for the second reading of these bills divided, as we do wish to proceed to deal with the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 . The Democrats will be moving amendments to transfer the staff and the work of the Industry Commission to Treasury, where I am sure they will feel quite comfortable and at home ideologically. It would be a soft landing for them, so to speak—a soft landing that successive generations of Industry Commission staff have failed to provide for the hundreds of thousands of workers retrenched in the name of the Industry Commission as a result of their recommendations.

The Democrats urge the Senate to oppose the Productivity Commission Bill, to support the abolition of the Industry Commission as one definitive step we can take to lay to rest the demons of economic rationalism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Productivity Commission is an organisation designed simply to provide yet another powerful taxpayer funded voice for an extremely limited economic ideology which has been promoted in Treasury and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for far too long. This ideology is so prevalent because economic fundamentalists have been in place in the top positions of virtually every federal department for some period and they have been extremely active in setting—and selling—policy for both major parties.

SPEECH.PARA: By the term `economic fundamentalist' or `fundy' I refer to those who adhere to a very simplistic, idealised and naive notion of the operation of economic markets, with no reference to the reality of the impact of their policies whatever. An example I have given recently was the Wallis report, which was supposed to look at the impacts of deregulation within financial markets in Australia. If it had done that maybe we would have had a different report. But it did not do that at all. It said, `We are not going to look into that.' I do not know why but in fact it turned around and recommended more of the same. So, without actually looking at the impact of what had been done, it turned around and said, `Let's look at more of the same.' That is an example of economic fundamentalism that is operating in Australia at the moment.

The Productivity Commission looks set to be a more rabid and nasty version of the Industry Commission. The Industry Commission, as an example of the work of economic fundies, was notable for its heavy ideological position. My problem with the old Industry Commission and the proposed Productivity Commission is that they are in effect an embodiment of faith in a particular version of the so‐called `international free market'. They are quasi‐religious organisations which emulate rationality but do not relate to it. They hold inquiries into the economic market, and their reports are nearly always simple reiterations of their faith.

The reason I describe the Industry Commission as rabid and nasty is the nature of the outcomes of their faith. Their reports, as I said, always start with the same assumptions and deliver the same conclusions. Their conclusions are that government should deregulate, tariffs and concessions should drop, costs should be put on a user‐pays basis and labour costs should be reduced. It is a mantra. The Industry Commission's conclusions are the same even when all the evidence shows that allowing the private sector to operate in place of government and other services results in a cartel‐like behaviour causing massive distortion of prices, penalties for consumers, including business consumers, and extremely bad outcomes for small business, workers and rural people, and so on. The conclusions are always: remove regulation, allow market freedom, shed workers, reduce wages.

That was what the Industry Commission concluded in its report No. 40 of 1994 on the petrol industry. In the face of massive evidence, from its own inquiry, of serious market distortion and manipulation by an oligopolistic petroleum cartel, the Industry Commission decided that what was needed was more freedom for a handful of immensely powerful corporations to manipulate their franchise agents who are small business people. It never did explain how that was supposed to solve the problems. I suppose its Orani model, to which Senator Kernot has referred, said that Royal Dutch, Shell, British Petroleum and others would reinvest their expropriated profits—blithely assuming the investment would be in Australia—and that this would be extremely efficient and create a massive increase in jobs and mining exports. Ho hum. That is usually what the Industry Commission concludes. The fact that it bears no relation to reality matters not at all, it seems. It is an article of faith. If reality does not correspond to its models, reality is obviously wrong. If it has someone very stubborn arguing for reality, the second line of defence is to say, `Well, yes, things are bad because of many factors we didn't account for but they would have been worse without deregulation.' That is what I mean. There is no arguing with a faith which can reinterpret all evidence as support.

These commissions start with the assumption that competition and deregulation will solve our problems and make us well off. The terms `free market', `competition' and `deregulation' all translate as freedom for massive corporations to exercise their economic might in the market in any way they deem appropriate. The assumption is that this will automatically be competition on the basis of efficiency reflected as a lower price and that, therefore, consumers will get cheaper products, buy more and invest more. I just wonder whether the people who think this have ever read basic first year economic texts about monopolies.

According to this faith, sacked workers or workers who cannot maintain the real value of their wages and either work longer hours for the same pay or the same hours for less pay will not drag down consumption—isn't that a leap of faith?—because they will simply find better jobs because that is how the invisible hand of the market works, rather like angels or spirits. Under this faith, we cannot have unemployment because, if there is a surplus of labour, the price will simply come down, stimulating more demand. I remember hearing about that in the 1930s—not that I was here in the 1930s. All commodities work that way and labour is, of course, just a commodity. They are not human beings; no‐one gets discouraged or depressed or feels hopeless. Labour is a commodity.

In their fundamentalist vision, labour, workers, human beings are always a cost—and of course taxes should always come down, no matter what else. There is a zero positive value on employment and standard of living. Any cost in its pursuit is a pure cost, never offset by benefits. The same is true with any regulation to protect the environment or to protect any aspect of society we are foolish enough to value. These are always distortions of the market—and bad, perhaps even evil.

The market, if left alone, will always protect values. The dollar is value, and that is why the price of a thing is called a value. Economic fundy‐thinking says that value is determined automatically and accurately in the market. If people value something more, they will pay more; if they value it less, they will pay less. They do not pay anything for air, so it is obviously worthless—especially clean air. They pay little for forests and nothing for forest ecology, so they are without value. The fact that people say they value nature and environment means nothing. They do not pay for it, do they?

Necessity never existed for the Industry Commission. People do not have driving needs for food, shelter and so on. Needs are just inelasticities. The reality of being offered a choice between a cut in salary or becoming unemployed is never really considered as a social or personal cost. It is not even considered as a government cost—and that is a mistake, even on economic grounds.

The cost of losing an industry is not a cost for the Industry Commission. If an industry is so inefficient that it cannot stand up against foreign tariff subsidies, it will die, and the money will simply be invested in a more appropriate and competitive industry. Given the relative inefficiencies, the Industry Commission probably thinks we should be a nation of mine and pulp mill workers who invest heavily in Vietnam, Korea or other nations where they know how to properly exploit workers. Obviously, one of the most efficient jobs possible is to be an investment capitalist. I wonder why the unemployed have not thought of that?

Action of vested interests in taking control of a market and so having a willingness to take losses to drive competitors out of business cannot exist in an Industry Commission world. According to them, any business that does not work to maximise profits must be unsustainable. The fact that a company can afford losses for a while in a small area if they are making a profit overall and the result will be larger profits when competition is destroyed does not dawn on them. They do not seem to understand about the power of market dominance and the ability to convert that dominance, once attained, to profit. Nor do they recognise that for a global corporation virtually any nation, particularly Australia with its small population, is a minor part of the global market; nor does it consider that competition is the purest form of a win‐lose system. In a competition there are one or two winners, with the rest being a large number of losers.

Power never entered Industry Commission calculations. When market dominance is large enough, the choices that are offered are controlled, and people may have no choice about the choices they have. Entry cost rarely is considered in an Industry Commission report. The fact is that, when a market is established, it is extremely difficult for anyone to enter. Collusion and distortion by industry is rarely considered. Social considerations or government regulation is seen as a distortion. But the article of faith, the actions of companies, can never cause distortion. They are the operation of the free market. How can the market itself cause distortion?

The Industry Commission is one of the few organisations that not only backed up the Hilmer report but demanded it go further. It has unceasingly called for the shedding of jobs and the abandonment of industries. If its recommendations swung decision making, it is probably responsible for over 200,000 jobs being lost in Australia. Even when it was not responsible for the decisions made, it was an ever present voice out on the extreme economic Sahara of dryness. It could always be counted on not only to support the most extreme measures of government—at least till Mr Costello became Treasurer—but also to make disdainful noises about government not going far enough. It created the impression that the most radical economic Right policies were moderate compromise measures by comparison with the ravings of the Industry Commission.

Needless to say, I do not support this bill. I have never seen any point in the expense of the Industry Commission and its inquiries. In most cases they were not worth the paper wasted on them, much less the trees that went to make the paper. One could predict what the Industry Commission's conclusions would be—and they were always as bad or worse. One of the few exceptions I can think of was the Industry Commission report I read on public housing. It concluded that it was a good and worthwhile thing to have public housing. But the government did what one would have expected the commission to recommend and has largely divested itself of public housing and passed any responsibility to the states who simply see it as easy money for their general revenue and the housing as something to flog off in the name of efficiency and choice.

I will vote for the part of this bill that terminates the Industry Commission: schedule 1 of the repeals bill. I will vote against the transitional part: schedule 2. I will vote against replacing it with something worse by voting against the Productivity Commission bill. Worse? Yes, absolutely. The Productivity Commission looks like a deterioration of the situation.

If the Industry Commission was the far Right for the brand of economic fundamentalism under Paul Keating, the Productivity Commission seems that much worse, just as the economic fundamentalism of the Howard government seems that much worse. I am worried even by the change of name. The Industry Commission mainly targeted industry, working particularly to obliterate our shipping, manufacturing, automotive and TCF industries.

Productivity Commission? `Productivity' in the jargon of this fundy‐faith means increasing narrow economic efficiency, and there is only one way of doing that. The Industry Commission never considered technological advances in efficiency or improvements in management and coordination. It was always the `productivity of labour', which roughly translated into getting more work for less money. This meant specifically work intensification mechanisms for holding salaries down by creating insecurity amongst the labour force; short‐term contracts for workers which could be shed when not absolutely necessary without penalty to profits; and it meant transfers of costs to consumers and clients by increasing waiting times through decreasing staff—meaning that there are fewer staff and the ones who remain are always flat out.

With this sort of history of productivity and the absolute opposition of any of the worker benefits in restructuring, as outlined in the ACTU's Australia restructured, I have no positive opinion of anything called a Productivity Commission. I think it will specifically be a labour bashing and job gutting commission.

I appreciate that the ALP is attempting to modify the Productivity Commission into something not quite so odious and antithetical to the interests of workers and other human beings. I do not consider there are any real benefits of a Productivity Commission. So I do not think any but the most absolute modifications effectively throwing out the bill and starting from scratch will work.

I do not think modification will work because of the type of government we have and its perspective on labour, society and industry. I will vote against this bill because there is no reason to multiply the fundamentalist voice; there is no real need and no excuse. I hope that the Senate joins me in ridding Australia of the Productivity Commission and the Industry Commission.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I did not want to interrupt the speech by Senator Margetts but I know that standing order 187 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not read a speech.
When attention is drawn to that order, quite often senators say they are referring to copious notes. But, generally, senators do take breath, look up every now and again and extemporise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it away. What are you wasting time for?

—I think it is an important matter, Senator Conroy, but it might be hard for you to pick. I may be wrong, and the Acting Deputy President may so rule. I was wondering whether Senator Margetts would table her notes so we could have a ruling as to whether they are copious notes or a typewritten speech. It has come to my attention over the past months that, increasingly, senators are reading intricately typewritten notes—which can only be an abuse of standing order 187.

—On the point of order: I think all of us in this place are aware of the standing orders and the need to be occasionally reminded to refer to copious notes but I really think that Senator Campbell, in the interests of the smooth proceedings of the Senate, should reconsider the point of order. It is totally unnecessary and would certainly be a problem for the smooth operation of the chamber if, every time we took exception to the content of a senator's speech, they were required to table it. Frankly, I think it is a petty point of order and should not be proceeded with.

—On the point of order: Madam Acting Deputy President, I have actually spoken with both whips today to indicate that I am getting over laryngitis and I had to be prepared, because I might lose my voice, to try to incorporate the notes of my speeches. So, Senator Campbell, you can have my notes any time you like—and they do coincide with what I said—but it also happens that I had told the whips ahead of time that I might have to do that. So thank you very much for your concern.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: does it make any difference to that standing order that the parliamentary secretary enjoys the assistance of the two advisers sitting next to him, whereas the senator over here enjoys no assistance whatsoever and has to operate on her own in this chamber?

—The standing orders do advise senators that reading their speeches is unparliamentary but, over the years, we have allowed the practice of speaking from copious notes and, I think, we have allowed that there may sometimes be a circumstance that we had not anticipated. I note the comments by Senator Margetts about the possibility of losing her voice. I also make the comment that it is quite clear that a speech that is not entirely read often has a particular and attractive flavour in the Senate chamber. But I remind senators of the standing order and urge them, as much as possible, to use notes rather than written speeches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We in the government very happily agreed to incorporating a large part of Senator Mackay's speech, which was also typed. I made a point of not interrupting Senator Margetts because I did not want to be that churlish but I do appreciate—
—But you couldn't resist now.

—I thought I had been very generous at the time I raised the point of order. It is a point of order I could have raised any time during the speech by Senator Margetts, but I chose not to do that. I genuinely hope that her laryngitis gets better.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, can I say that we have heard from both Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts this evening in relation to various aspects of the Productivity Commission legislation. There seems to be, through the speeches of both Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts, a theme that takes exception to even the concept of productivity. Senator Margetts was more to the point than was Senator Kernot and said that there was some conspiratorial nature to the fact that we dared call this thing the Productivity Commission.

Senator Kernot seemed to suggest that productivity was a dirty word. I do not think Senator Margetts said that productivity was bad. Rather, in the context in which we had come up with it—this nasty bunch of dry, right‐wing ideologues who had pinned the term `productivity' onto this body—productivity was a dirty word; that if we had not done it, this might not have been the case. So Senator Margetts was to the point.

The government, for its part, believe in productivity. We believe that increasing productivity is good for Australia—good for the Australian economy and good for jobs. We do not believe that increasing productivity needs to cost jobs. In fact, what you will find if you analyse the figures is that as Australia's productivity has increased, so has employment in Australia and, in the longer term trend, it has decreased unemployment. So we stand for productivity. We think that having a commission that is dedicated to productivity and to seeking out unfair competition and trying to find ways to abolish it, particularly when it occurs in business between the private sector and the public sector, will assist. It will particularly assist small business.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say to Senator Kernot that in my time in the parliament I have found and have had brought to my attention numerous examples of extremely unfair competition between the public sector and the private sector. Anyone who stands up in this place and says that the public sector suffers a disadvantage when it is out there competing against the private sector needs to talk to some of those constituents who have come to me over the years and who are suffering from unfair competition.

In her contribution here tonight Senator Kernot also said that she would rather take the $25 million, to quote her, that was being spent on this and spend it on some social impact statements and so forth. I say to Senator Kernot, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that these measures will save the Commonwealth, and save the taxpayer through that, in the order of $22.5 million. Before Senator Kernot goes off and spends another $25 million, she is going to have to find another $22.5 million in savings. I know where Senator Margetts would get that from; she would go straight to the Department of Defence and take that money out of their budget. We know where Senator Margetts stands on that.

Perhaps Senator Kernot could find us another $22.5 million because, by defeating these measures, she will not only defeat a measure which will save the Australian taxpayer $22.5 million, but she will cost us what I regard as an important measure in implementing a key feature of the coalition's election program. My stacked advisers box has just passed me a document called A competitive Australia—the government's role in generating—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he reading from copious notes?

—No, I am quoting a policy document, Senator Conroy. You might be deaf and you might be dumb but you should not be blind. It is called A competitive Australia—the government's role in generating the conditions to make Australia a better place to do business and create jobs . Quite explicitly in this document the coalition is committed to doing just this—committed to combining those previous bodies and putting in place a productivity commission and saving over $22 million in the process.

—Senator Campbell, before you proceed any further, I just say that I do not want to be churlish and pull you up either, but I do think that, while you may not be reading your speech, to call your colleague possibly blind and deaf is getting close to being unparliamentary. I urge you to not use that kind of line in the future.

—Any reflection on one of my colleagues in that regard is withdrawn unconditionally. Senator Conroy is such a humble, quiet and unassuming character who never speaks out of turn. I would never dare imply anything but the greatest of motives to anything he did or said.

BREAK.PARA: I say through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that this is a crucial part of the coalition's policy platform. It was released back in July 1995, so it was out there in the public domain for a long time. We bring this legislation to the Senate seeking its implementation. Again, it is what we consider a core part of the coalition's reform—

TALK.START.PARA: —A core—as opposed to non-core?

—Yes, that is right—c-o-r-e. We seek its implementation. Again, we seem to be frustrated by this alliance of the Greens, the Democrats and the Labor Party. We are very keen to ensure that this election policy be implemented. Once again, we bowled the reform legislation up to the Senate and in the middle of the chamber here we have Senator Kernot saying, `We don't want productivity' and Senator Margetts saying, `This is all about lower taxes. These nasty, right-wing, ideologically driven, dry, rationalist characters—these horrible people—want lower taxes.'
—You sound like Kim Carr.
—Help me! I say to Senator Margetts that the coalition government does stand for lower taxes. We like lower taxes and we like ensuring that people pay the smallest amount of taxes they possibly can.
—And smaller government and no services.
—Yes, smaller government and much better quality service. We think that with a productivity commission we can get better advice to the government at a much lower cost.

BREAK.PARA: I turn to the argument put in Senator Sherry's contribution, which I listened to this afternoon. He talked about this competition and the advice being competitive as well—contestability and advice. I think Senator Sherry is dead right about that. It was one of the criticisms of the previous Labor government that Mr Keating, the former Prime Minister, was only getting this advice from one area and Treasury was not always giving him the best advice.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Sherry—I would be very surprised if you would disagree with me on this, if not publicly, at least privately—that I think it is fair to say that in the last decade economic advice and the sources of economic advice to government in Australia and most parts of the world has significantly increased in terms of the source of that advice. You have a whole range of private sector advisers and organisations mostly filled with ex-Treasury staff—Murphy and his mob and a few other people. It is a fact. It reinforces the argument of Senator Kernot or Senator Margetts that they are all coming from the same religion.

BREAK.PARA: The reality is that there are a lot of other organisations out there who are providing advice to government. They are not only economic organisations staffed by Treasury officials who pray at the same altar; there are also a whole range of other people who give us advice. There are a whole range of organisations which were brought into the policy process in relation to the decision on the automotive industry in Australia. As is on the public record now, the Industry Commission's recommendations did not get accepted by the government. We listened to a whole range of organisations—economic organisations, community organisations and organisations from a whole different range of places—when we got that advice.

We are saying that we need a more efficient and focused productivity commission. We need to implement the election commitment. We do not want to see yet another election commitment torn to shreds when it gets to the Senate. We would like the opportunity to implement this.
In conclusion, Senator Kernot does not like competition. She says that that is tough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said your definition of it is stupid.

—Well, it is our definition. We think competition is good. It is very good for consumers. The great example of competition in the past 12 months has been the competition in the home loan market. That is a classic example. You do not need to go to Chris Murphy or ORANI or any of these people to get a model of competition.

BREAK.PARA: There are plenty of examples where competition works, but the greatest example is what has happened to customers of Australia with the competition that Aussie Home Loans have brought into the banks. Of course, with the implementation of the Wallis committee recommendations there will be a lot more competition out there which will flow through not only to home owners and people with overdrafts but also to small businesses. Of course, the other example is telecommunications, where we have had literally overnight a tumbling of telecommunications charges, which has helped households right across Australia.

The Democrats do not like competition; they do not like productivity. When an Industry Commission report predicted that $20 billion would be saved from competition policy, Senator Kernot said, `But the reality is that in the end they will save only $1 billion or $2 billion.' All I can say is that a lot of people out there would like to make a $1 billion or $2 billion—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about faulty modelling.
—If faulty modelling produces a result with a $1 billion to $2 billion saving to consumers in Australia, I think most consumers—
—A $21 billion error.
—I do not accept any of your argument. The bottom line of all your arguments is that at the absolute minimum we have $1 billion to $2 billion worth of savings and—
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I was wondering whether we could ask Senator Campbell to speak to notes.
—There is no point of order, Senator Margetts, but humour never goes astray.

—I have only ever read one speech in this place. It was my maiden speech. It was extremely boring to read and extremely boring to listen to, and I vowed I would never do it again, and I shall not. For the record, when I made that speech and most of the others while I was sitting over there, I did not have any advisers, and the advisers will advise you right now that I do not listen to them too much.
—Oh! You're not going to get promoted.

—Well, they write all their summing‐up speeches before they even listen to the debate. I think they should listen to the debate. That does sum‐up the debate. I do genuinely thank senators for their contributions to the debate. It is an important debate to have, but I think ultimately the benefits of good advice coming from a focused Productivity Commission, the restructuring of which will save Australian taxpayers another $22 million, do commend themselves to the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: We would hope that this piece of legislation will go through the Senate without amendment and that, if anything, any amendments that are accepted will improve the legislation. If the amendments to be moved particularly by Senator Kernot and the Greens were successful, the legislation would be emasculated. The government is not interested in that. We do want the opportunity to implement this election policy. It is vital to the government that we get an opportunity to implement our policies and the Senate does not stand, because of a blind attraction to an outmoded ideology, in the way of a government elected with one of the largest mandates in Australian political history implementing policy which is there to assist small businesses, Australian enterprise but, most importantly, those people in Australia who do not have access to the labour market at the moment.

We want a more efficient, more effective and more productive private sector in Australia. We want a private sector that can be sure that it is competing fairly, that it does not have a government intervening in the marketplace and stealing business from the private sector. We want that—not for some ideological objective, but because we would like to see more Australians with the chance to join in the paid work force, and to ensure that more businesses and enterprises are being set up in Australia and have the chance to compete successfully internationally.

That is what we want to achieve: higher employment, growth in the Australian economy, a more productive Australian economy. Those people in the Senate who would stand in the way of the government reaching that objective by stopping this important piece of legislation, a crucial part of our electoral mandate, do so because they are clinging to some ideological objective which I think has now been defeated in all parts of the world. Not even Tony Blair and certainly Bill Clinton would stand between us and this piece of legislation. I ask the Senate to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the debate has concluded with the minister's remarks, but I seek leave of the Senate to make an observation as to the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do apologise for being unavoidably detained and not being able to enter this debate at the appropriate time. I am concerned about part (3) of that amendment. I am inclined to support parts (1), (2) and (4). I believe part (3) has a pejorative overtone, which I feel I cannot accept. I know there is no opportunity for me, unless by leave, to move to take out part (3) of the amendment to the second reading, but the Senate has my view on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Question put.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 be now read a second time.

BREAK.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (line 5) to page 3 (line 11), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(2) Clause 3, page 3 (after line 11), at the end of the clause, add:
(2) For the purposes of this Act:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Chair may be referred to as the Chair, Chairperson, Chairman or Chairwoman or by any other such term as the person occupying the office so chooses; and
(b) the Deputy Chair may be referred to as the Deputy Chair, Deputy Chairperson, Deputy Chairman or Deputy Chairwoman or by any other such term as the person occupying the office so chooses.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) If a person occupying either of the offices mentioned in subsection (2) does not make known his or her choice of term, the person may be referred to by whichever of the following terms that a person addressing that person considers appropriate, as the case requires:

PARA.TAB: (a) Chair or Deputy Chair;
(b) Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson;
(c) Chairman or Deputy Chairman;
(d) Chairwoman or Deputy Chairwoman.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 27, page 18 (lines 4 to 12), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(4) Clause 29, page 18 (line 19), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".
(5) Clause 30, page 18 (line 22), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".
(6) Clause 33, page 20 (lines 1 to 3), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(7) Clause 34, page 20 (line 5), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".
(8) Clause 35, page 20 (lines 7 to 20), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(9) Clause 36, page 20 (line 21) to page 21 (line 25), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(10) Clause 42, page 26 (lines 2 to 4), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(11) Clause 43, page 26 (lines 5 to 17), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(12) Clause 44, page 26 (line 18) to page 27 (line 14), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(13) Clause 46, page 28 (lines 3 to 7), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(14) Clause 46, page 28 (line 5), omit "Chairman's", substitute "Chair's".
(15) Clause 47, page 28 (line 8) to page 29 (line 7), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(16) Clause 48, page 30 (line 7), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".
(17) Clause 49, page 30 (lines 10 to 17), omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(18) Clause 52, page 32 (line 19), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".
(19) Clause 53, page 33 (lines 6 to 23),, omit "Chairman" (wherever occurring), substitute "Chair".
(20) Clause 54, page 33 (line 27), omit "Chairman", substitute "Chair".

It should be noted that items 8 and 11 are in conflict with opposition amendments 11 and 12. The amendments before the committee go to the heart of the comments made by Senator Kernot during her speech on the second reading stage. They refer to our view, which was clearly expressed by Senator Kernot, as to how the Productivity Commission should be established and how it should operate.

I wish to speak only to the amendments to be moved in my name during this committee stage. These amendments are the first in a series to be moved by the Australian Democrats whenever the government seeks to insert the exclusive use of the term `chairman' into legislation. They are very simple amendments. They give the person holding the office concerned the right to choose his or her title. They give a person the right to be known as the chair, chairperson, chairman or chairwoman.

These amendments are about choice. Given how often we are told that choice is a concept dear to the hearts of the coalition, we might have expected such great libertarians to support such amendments. My belief is that they will not support the amendments, but I hope that they will.

The coalition will not support the amendments because in this, as in so many other areas, they are not about broadening choice, they are about limiting it. Few things demonstrate that more clearly than this determination to shut the door on inclusive language and to shove down all our throats the desire that a person shall always be known as chairman, irrespective of his or her gender, irrespective of his or her wishes and irrespective of how demeaning, belittling and marginalising that might be to many Australian women.

We can stand here for hours and debate the origins of the word `chairman', but we all know that in Australia in 1997 it is not an inclusive word. What it did or did not mean in Latin is hardly relevant. We know what it means in 1997 and we know that the vast majority of women chairing organisations in 1997 do not see themselves as chairmen, do not call themselves chairmen and do not want to go through life being called chairmen.

There are obviously some women who do want to be called chairmen, and that is their prerogative. There are apparently any number of coalition women MPs and senators who are happy to accept their master's injunctions that they call themselves chairmen as well. But, contrary to the view of some parliamentarians, this is 1997 not 1947, the year of my birth, and most women are not so happy to toe some man's line and they can certainly see no reason why they should be forced to toe that line. What if the holders of these positions were to be called chairwomen, irrespective of their gender? Would all the men out there chairing corporations and organisations roll over and happily call themselves chairwomen?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think people would support you.

—I have had no indication from the government that they are going to support me. I believe you would be hard‐pressed to find a single one, me included. For the benefit of Hansard I should indicate that Senator Harradine thought that people as a whole would support me, but I have not heard it.
—You are hearing it from me.

—I am glad to hear it. But here is the government asking its female counterparts to accept being compelled to call themselves chairmen, apparently on the sole ground that the Latin root for the word is not gender based. Language is a very potent force of both oppression and change. How we use language sends messages about what sort of society we are. What message does it send to Australian women when their national government does not stop whingeing about the clumsiness or political correctness of the word `chairperson' but actually goes out and writes into legislation its own officially sanctioned term of chairman? What does that say, if not that our national government considers most of these positions are and should remain the province of men? The American feminist Gloria Steinem said:

SPEECH.PARA: New words and phrases are one organic measure of change. They capture transformations of perception, and sometimes of reality itself.

That is why we started replacing terms like `policeman' with `police officer', that is why we started using the generic terms of `chair' and `chairperson', because reality was changing, because women were filling these positions and because we no longer wanted to imply that the positions themselves belonged exclusively to men.

We can all point to extreme or ridiculous examples of so‐called politically correct language. That is a pretty cheap and easy shot to take, but it is not one of these examples. This is about an assumption in our language which has changed naturally as reality has changed and which the government now wants to reverse not by force of argument but through force of law.

Personally, I do not care if people want to call themselves chairs, or chairmen, or chairpersons or chairwomen. I do not care if they want to call themselves the grand poo‐bah or the grand wizard. But I believe very strongly, firstly, that they should be able to make that choice of title for themselves and, secondly, that government should not be in the business of sanctioning one gender ahead of the other through the official authorisation of particular terms or words. Governments are supposed to be leaders. But this action is not the action of a leader; it is a backward step and one which reflects the agenda of those in the coalition—it is not everybody in the coalition—who long for the good old days when men were men and women were women who stayed at home and did not want to be chairpersons.

I cannot understand why there has not been a much stronger fight against both that agenda and this particular step from coalition women MPs and senators. I find it very hard to believe that this is a move which sits comfortably with women senators such as Senator Vanstone, or Senator Payne or Senator Coonan, for example. I find it hard to believe they are overjoyed at such a small‐minded approach which is designed to lead over time to every chairing position within Commonwealth legislation being referred to as chairman. This is of course a completely unnecessary thing to do. It is not required for good government. It is not required to improve services or make organisations work more efficiently. It is nothing more than a petty, pathetically small‐minded and blatantly sexist measure and it is one which the Democrats reject completely.

Madam Chair, I have taken some time to put this case because I want to forewarn the government that it is the intention of the Democrats to move such amendments to get rid of this obsession of calling everybody chairman every time a bill emerges with that word in it. So you have to face up to the fact that you are going to be called to account on that and have to go to a division every single time that you produce such a statement. Thank you, Madam Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, it will probably not surprise you to hear that I will be supporting this amendment wholeheartedly. Several months ago, when a male Deputy President was in the chair, I deliberately referred to him as madam chair. I wanted to do that because so many people argue that language is irrel evant and that often women—and I am really pleased that Senator Murray is moving this amendment—are making a big thing about language. I wanted to see at the time what would happen when you actually called a man in that position by a term which refers to a woman. The interesting thing was that the first person to call a point of order, if I recall correctly, was Senator Bob Collins. He jumped up in outrage and said something about the fact that Senator Colston was not wearing a skirt or a dress.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that was really interesting, because I have never heard that point of order called before when a woman has been referred to as chairman. Nobody has stood up and said, `She has not got certain parts of the anatomy which relate to a man.' It is interesting, isn't it, that people should actually take offence, as if it is an insult that they have been referred to in a term which relates to a female. Yet those of us in the community who do take offence—yes, who do take offence at being marginalised and made invisible by the language—are considered to be petty in bringing this up, not by all people but by some people who persist in trying to change language but then tell us that we should not take it as seriously as we do.

Language is important; you only have to find out how people feel about the way language is used around them and to them to know how important it is. Despite the people from the Australian Labor Party and the government who have jumped up at times, I hope that commonsense will prevail and that a step in the right direction of choice will be taken in the use of language in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will be supporting the amendments that have been moved with respect to the gender reference of a chair. We will be pleased to support any such amendments to this Productivity Commission package of bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 3 (lines 2 to 5), omit the definition of industry , substitute:

industry means industry of any kind (including any business or activity relating to goods or services), and a reference to industry is a reference to a particular industry or part of an industry or a group or groups of particular interests.

This amendment proposes to adjust the definition of `industry' in clause 3 of the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 to that which is consistent with Labor's preferred model of making the Productivity Commission a specific reference body rather than a more general reference body. This is consistent with the theme of concern and, indeed, deep suspicion and scepticism that we have with the government's reorganisation of the Bureau of Industry Economics, the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the Industry Commission into this Productivity Commission. The consistent theme that runs through our amendments is that the Productivity Commission, if it is to exist, should be very sharply focused in a variety of ways—much more sharply focused than the government is proposing.

The amendment contracts the definition of `industry' from one which includes Australian industry in general to one which confines the scope for reference by the Productivity Commission to particular industries or parts of industries. We believe that this will allow the commission to still focus on specific issues within industries, which should allow greater emphasis on practical considerations—I emphasise that word `practical'—as opposed to an overly theoretical approach which could arise from a much more generalist reference, which is the course the government appears to wish to take.

I note that Senator Campbell referred earlier to the Liberal‐National Party election commitment. We believe—if indeed it was necessary to look for justification for our approach—that this is entirely consistent with Senator Campbell's argument which he put earlier. A general approach is not to see the end of the Industry Commission and its rebirth as a Productivity Commission but to see that rebirth remodelled to a very significant extent.

This amendment of ours is particularly important. It is one of a significant number of amendments. Certainly, it is one of six or seven amendments that, frankly, we see as being bottom line improvements that need to be made to the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Australian Democrats will support Labor's amendment No. 1 to the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition government is quite concerned about the limiting effect of the definition of `industry' as proposed by the Australian Labor Party in its amendment No. 1 to the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 . We believe that it limits it beyond the definition which is in both the Industry Commission Act and the PC Bill. We believe that by excluding `industry' in general, it could therefore restrict the nature of industry references and the economy‐wide focus of the Productivity Commission.
