SPEECH.PARA: As an example, we believe that the regional adjustment and the charitable organisations reviews under the previous government would be problematic with this wording. We do not believe that it should be narrowed in this way. In fact, I think it is contradictory to the sentiment that I heard flowing through the speeches of the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) and Senator Margetts, who said that we should be taking into account social, environmental and other community factors. It limits the sorts of references that can be done in that area.

We regard this as a potentially very significant amendment. It is one the government could not live with because we think it is too restrictive. We heard arguments during the second reading stage from, I think, all senators in the debate that there seemed to be a monopoly and a narrowing of the focus of the Productivity Commission under the whole scheme. Yet this amendment, which is the first main amendment in the committee stage, specifically seeks to narrow the focus of the commission to industry in the narrower sense of the word.

BREAK.PARA: The government is committed to ensuring the Productivity Commission has a broad remit; that it can look into a whole range of matters and that it can inquire into things like charitable organisations and regional adjustment and a range of other matters. The advice that we have is that this amendment would limit it. That would be highly undesirable. The government could not live with this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell is broadly correct in the sense that in our amendment No. 1 we are intending to limit, to some extent, the activity of the Productivity Commission. I do not accept his assertion in respect of the foreshadowed amendments from the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats, which Labor will be supporting, about a focus on social and environmental considerations. Indeed, we see that as entirely consistent with the amendment, which we will get to soon, relating to the policy guidelines to be issued for the commission.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the broad theme that I outlined earlier—the squashing together, if you like, of the old Industry Commission, BIE and EPAC—we think it is entirely appropriate that the focus of the Productivity Commission should be sharpened to specific industries or part of an industry or a group of particular interests. That certainly gives plenty of scope for activity for the Productivity Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position of the Greens on these bills has been made quite clear. I believe that this definitional change does make it clearer and less likely that the Productivity Commission will be able to do something like a slash and burn non‐government organisation, which I do not really think should be its role anyway. I do not think charities and non‐government organisations should fit into this definition. The minister himself said he would like it to include charities; I do not know how wide that must mean it to be. If you are going to deal with industry, deal with industry rather than trying to find ways of beating over the head those organisations which operate under different values.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of other amendments I will support, depending of course on what I hear in the chamber, but on this one I am not sure that changing the definition of `industry' will achieve what the opposition really wants. What it might do is leave Treasury unchallenged. The concern that I, the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens have—and I believe, if they could speak, that probably a number of the government would have—about this measure is that the diversity of economic advice that is currently given to the government will be seriously affected if this legislation goes through as it is. As has been said by speaker after speaker, it will result in the Treasury being virtually the sole organisation upon which the government will rely for economic and industry advice.

SPEECH.PARA: People can say what they like—and often do say what they like—about the Industry Commission but the Industry Commission, on a number of occasions, has quite strongly in its reports taken to task the sort of philosophy that you would expect to emanate from Treasury. They have been quite independent on occasions. All of us around this chamber who are familiar with Industry Commission reports would agree that the Industry Commission has, on occasion, taken to task—not by name—the sorts of viewpoints that are expressed by Treasury.

My concern about this amendment is that it will severely limit the functions of the new commission and thus affect the ability of the commission to express its views on industry as a whole or on areas; for example, regional areas, which the minister has mentioned. So I am inclined to vote against a change of definition and therefore against the amendment moved—amendment No. 1 on page 366.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a brief comment in respect to Senator Harradine's contribution. I could understand your position if one was to assume that the culture of the old Industry Commission, EPAC and BIE was to be carried forward into the reconstituted Productivity Commission. Unfortunately, certainly on the evidence that I have seen to date, that is unlikely; in fact I am sure it is not going to happen. After the appearance before the Senate estimates committee by Mr Kerr—I do not want to malign him personally in any sense because he is the person who has represented the Productivity Commission, albeit before it has been created, and the Industry Commission—Labor is not confident that the sort of culture you refer to, Senator Harradine, will continue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had advice from a range of people who have consulted with us—including people from the welfare sector; the trade union movement, particularly the ACTU; and some former employees who have lost their jobs, although they have not spoken to us out of any sense of bitterness or frustration at having lost their jobs—and they are not confident. I can think of one particular employee who has given us very valuable evidence and guidance on this legislation. We are not confident that that culture for which we have some sympathy would, with respect to Senator Harradine, continue. For that reason, and for the reasons I have advanced earlier, we believe it is appropriate to narrow the industry focus in regard to the definition that the Productivity Commission will be allowed to inquire into.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to raise a matter with the parliamentary secretary: with respect to this question that is currently before us, what is the meaning of `industry'? If the amendment by the opposition were to pass, where would the advice come from? Where would the government be seeking advice in respect of industry policy, if in fact the commission was precluded from accepting general references and was confined to what is contained in the opposition's amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first point to reiterate is that we do not want this narrowing. We think this commission, which will be independent, should have a broad charter. In fact, as I was listening to Senator Sherry I have been reading through the debate on the establishment of the Industry Commission back in November 1989. Peter Morris actually went to this matter of the definitions clauses and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The definitions clauses include a broad definition of industry which is intended to reflect the broadened charter for the commission and the widest possible scope for its inquiries relating to industries.
He makes the point about it being subject to Commonwealth power, of course, and in his concluding sentence he said:

The commission's economy‐wide perspective, its broad charter and public inquiry process will play a key role in promoting policies at both government and business levels to improve the competitiveness and dynamism of Australian industry. The bill provides for an effective and broad ranging institution to serve the needs of parliament, the people and government.
Of course, tonight we have heard of many people who do not agree with everything the Industry Commission has come up with since November 1989.

To more specifically answer the question, the government would of course rely on advice, as it does now, from a range of different sources, and clearly not only the industry commission. We would get advice from other departments of government. To reiterate, we just cannot see the merit in trying to limit the role of this body in this particular way. All it can possibly do is narrow things and give it less opportunity to do its work, which we believe is important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in response to the issue that Senator Harradine has raised, we see that there is ample scope for government to receive advice from a variety of sources. Senator Campbell has referred to government departments. There are Senate reference committees that do very good work. There are private sector think tanks—all too many of them to the right of centre—and universities. There are a range of other organisations in our society which have produced and will produce extremely effective, comprehensive reports on a vast range of issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Our fundamental fear is that compression of the two organisations into the Productivity Commission will refocus many of the provisions for its establishment—and we will be getting to further amendments later. It will refocus, driven essentially by a Treasury agenda, because it is the Treasurer (Mr Costello) who has driven this reconstruction—or destruction, in the case of a number of the organisations that we are dealing with.

We are very concerned about that refocusing that is to occur and emerge from this Productivity Commission. With all of the resources of Treasury, which are enormous, it is certainly the overwhelmingly dominant economic advisory organisation in this country. Those Treasury officials watching the debate may be somewhat concerned, but I have no doubt that they will have an enormous influence through the Treasurer. I am sure they will be advising the Treasurer as to the terms of reference, the industries to inquiry into, and it will have a much more Treasury centred focus, and that is of major concern to the Labor opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder, for the benefit of some of those participating in and listening to this debate, if I should remind senators that it is our understanding that the only Industry Commission report that has really differed from the Treasury line is the R&D report. Treasury won the day, rejected it and still cut the concession. We should also bear in mind that the most valuable advice to government has consistently come from private task forces. Of those, the most recent we can mention are those led by people such as Mortimer, Goldsworthy or the MTIA people. Those have always been available to government and will continue to be available to it.

SPEECH.PARA: But from within government there has been very limited contrary advice to Treasury, and it is our opinion that the Industry Commission can be characterised, by and large, as an echo of Treasury—Treasury in stereo. We would much prefer Treasury to speak with one loud and unconfused voice as opposed to disseminating it through various speakers and getting a muffled version of it coming back to us. I suggest that this amendment of Labor's does go at least some way to trying to deal with that problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the minister might like to comment on what has just been said by the honourable senator. As I understand it, on a number of occasions the Industry Commission has delivered statements that are quite contrary to the viewpoint of Treasury. The one that comes to mind is in the area of user‐pays. If you have a look at some of the reports of the Industry Commission, you will see that it takes quite a different view to Treasury's on that particular matter. One matter that comes to mind concerns the fees to be charged by AQIS for the inspection of meat for export. I would assume and I would be prepared to state—though if you asked me for chapter and verse, I could not say that off the top of my head—that the Industry Commission would not support a wholesale user‐pays approach in that particular regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make the point very briefly and simply that obviously we cannot do anything about the BIE, unfortunately. I believe it was good to have that group within the Prime Minister and Cabinet area. EPAC also did a good job over a period of time—it came up with some very good reports. Unfortunately, in a way the government has pre‐empted what the parliament can do about this matter because it has gone ahead with its program. It can say that it took the matter to the people, but it ought to wait until the parliament has decided these matters.

On this particular point, I firmly believe that a number of the persons within the commission will in fact hold views that are not endorsed by Treasury. That is not a bad thing. On this occasion, I will be voting against the amendment but in general I am supporting the amendments that are being put forward by the opposition.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 6, page 4 (line 7) to page 5 (line 8), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6 Functions of Commission

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The functions of the Commission are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to hold inquiries and make reports to the Minister in respect of such matters relating to industry development and produc tivity as are referred to it by the Minister; and
(b) to do anything incidental to those functions.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In subsection (1):

TAB.TAB: matters relating to industry development and productivity include legislative or administrative action taken, or to be taken, by the Commonwealth or a State or Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the functions of the commission. The bill we have before us proposes to significantly increase the functions of the Productivity Commission relative to the old Industry Commission. There are some very important additional functions, which include: to provide secretariat services and research services to government bodies as directed by the minister; to receive and investigate complaints on competitive neutrality issues; to provide advice to the minister additional to that flowing from the reference; and to undertake research on its own initiative.

Labor does not support this proposed extension of functions. The Productivity Commission should be a reference‐based research body: that is, the minister tasks the Productivity Commission to investigate certain matters and the commission then produces reports on the matters referred to it. These additional powers—and they are massive ones—are unnecessary or incongruous with the core function.

As for the proposal to make the Productivity Commission the investigation body for complaints on competitive neutrality grounds, we consider this to be clearly a function outside the normal role of a research body. To investigate complaints about competitive neutrality issues is an important function, but the proper Commonwealth body to undertake this function is clearly the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission or its successor body, and I understand there will be some statement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) tomorrow in respect of this matter. We certainly do not believe that investigating complaints about competitive neutrality issues is an area for the Productivity Commission.

BREAK.PARA: I will me moving separate amendments to division 2 of part 4 of the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 and to the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 to transfer these powers to the ACCC. In addition, the Labor amendment will broaden the focus from industry to industry development. This is designed to ensure that the Productivity Commission is concerned with developing industry in Australia, not merely with looking at industries. I will conclude my remarks at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that that amendment put up by the opposition will conflict with our following amendment but, Senator Sherry, we will support your amendment. It is our view that your amendment will seek to reduce the scope of the Productivity Commission from some omnipotent and self‐starting ideological warrior, tilting at whatever windmills it can find, and limit it to a tighter reference based inquiry body. So we support that clearer and narrower role.

—I will also be supporting the opposition's amendment. I will not, however, be supporting their amendment to move competitive neutrality issues to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. I would not support that being given to a body like that at all. Honourable senators already know that I believe that the ACCC is out of control in terms of its power, size and functions and that it is out of control of the democratic parliamentary process. The last thing that I would want to do is to give it more things to eat up than it currently has.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, for reasons similar to those given in the debate on the previous amendment moved by Senator Sherry on behalf of the opposition, is again strongly opposed to the narrowing of the functions of the Productivity Commission. Again, I point out to the Senate that the Prime Minister made very clear the coalition's policy on this matter when he announced this policy initiative. He said:

BREAK.PARA: I am particularly keen to increase public scrutiny of Australia's productive performance and to emphasise our commitment to a more competitive and productive Australia. When we win Government we will merge the functions of the Industry Commission, EPAC and the Bureau of Industry Economics in a single entity which will be renamed the Productivity Commission.
He also noted:
I will ask the Productivity Commission to benchmark microeconomic reform initiatives . . .
and the Productivity Commission—
. . . will be required to identify best international practice and activity and disseminate the results throughout the industry and the public sector.
We regard this as a very important area for the Productivity Commission to take action in.

We can have criticism from the Greens and the Democrats about how horrendous this micro‐economic reform of the Australian economy is, about what a horrendous concept improving productivity is and how nasty competition is, but what the Prime Minister said when he was the Leader of the Opposition is that we should benchmark these things and that we should not just accept the gospel of these nasty right wing ideologue dry economic rationalists who control the world through the conspiracy. He said that we should actually benchmark these things; that we should look at these things in a sensible, independent way.

These amendments again seek to narrow what the Productivity Commission can do. We do not want that narrowing. We want the Productivity Commission to have the power to undertake a broad range of functions. The object of the bill is to try to bring three bodies together into a Productivity Commission with a broad remit. Why you would seek to destroy that by narrowing not only what the commission can look into but also how it can do it—only on reference—makes my mind boggle.

I strongly say to the Democrats and to Senator Harradine, in particular, that I would like them to reconsider their views. You may as well knock the whole bill out if you are going to hobble it and put blinkers on it to the extent that this amendment particularly does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell's mind may boggle. Certainly, we find the functions of the commission—

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on a matter which I hope senators will read and take an interest in. On 4 August this year National Missing Persons Week was launched and there was a breakfast in the Great Hall which was attended by police involved in the area and a number of people who had suffered the loss of a person from their family. It was a very moving occasion. They spoke about the numbers of people who go missing, how soon some of them are found and how long it is before others are found—perhaps never.

SPEECH.PARA: The highlight of the morning was an address by Maree Dawes, who told us her own personal story. I was quite taken aback when in the first couple of sentences of her speech she said, identifying the times, `And I became the daughter of a missing person.' My first reaction was that she had perhaps got it wrong. I expected her to say, `I became the mother of a missing person.' But that was not the case. Mrs Dawes became the daughter of a missing person. And her mother did not have Alzheimer's disease; people with Alzheimer's disease who wander off are generally found quite soon. It was a very moving story about the impact of a woman who had been active with her family, within her community, loved by her grandchildren, et cetera, who has just not been seen since. Mrs Dawes also dealt with the legal implications of this situation which were faced by the family.

I do not want to take up the time of the Senate tonight in going through the speech. But it was a very moving account from someone who was articulate enough to be able to convey to the audience exactly what it meant. Senator Lundy was also present and also wishes tonight to refer to this speech of Maree Dawes. With the consent of the Senate, I would like the speech to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
MISSING PERSONS WEEK 1997 NATIONAL LAUNCH
PARLIAMENT HOUSE, CANBERRA
AUGUST 4, 1997
Address by Maree Dawes

Distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen. Let me take this opportunity of thanking the National Missing Persons Unit for allowing families the opportunity of being represented at this, the first National Launch of Missing Persons Week.
Two years two months and four days ago my life changed in a way I could never have imagined. I became the daughter of a missing person.

A mother who was well, mentally and physically, a mother who was devoted to her family, not just her children and grandchildren but to her extended family, brother and sister, nieces and nephews and friends, friendships that in some instances go back for 45 years. For all of us life can never be the same.
The pain is never ending because there is no resolution. Every day I look at her photograph and ask `where are you—what happened?'
Why did this happen to a kind gentle women whose contribution to the community was expansive. A lady who was known for her generosity. A lady who was loved by all who knew her.
The answer is the phenomena of missing persons knows no age, social, economic or cultural boundaries. It can happen to any family at any time, anywhere.

It must be remembered that this is not solely a domestic issue. For families who have a missing loved one overseas the task of searching is far more difficult. The difficulties of communication because of distance. Laws of the country involved that make it almost impossible to obtain information.

When we talk of missing persons it is important to acknowledge those families separated by war, political and religious strife. Families torn apart by circumstances way beyond their control. Brothers and sisters who have not seen one another for 50 years. Husbands and wives separated and never able to be reunited. Children who have been denied the opportunity of knowing one or both parents.
For those led behind we are catapulted on a roller coast ride of emotion.
. Initially the feelings of disbelief and shock are numbing. This happens to other people. It doesn't happen to me.
. As the numbness begins to subside the fear is almost overwhelming—Is it suicide, murder or have they simply shot through? It is the not knowing that hurts.
. Then comes the anger—Why have they done this to me?
. As the days drift into weeks there is the frustration—Where do I start to look? I remember well constantly telling my brother "there must be something we have forgotten!"
. The feelings of guilt. Is it my fault? As the weeks drift by and there are no answers we all ask ourselves "could I have done more?"

. When there are no answers we look to lay blame—it must be someone's fault. Families often reflect this need to blame someone in the form of anger with the Police—it is simply too painful to blame ourselves. The Police are professionals, they understand but sometimes that blame is reflected on a partner or another family member. This can be enormously damaging to family relationships.

. Initially there are lots of people around, family, friends and of course the Police are in constant contact searching for that vital piece of information that will give them the lead they need. But as the days turn to weeks and the weeks become months the expectation is that you will "get on with it". Friends don't know what to say and so they stop calling in and the phone stops ringing and you are left with the pain—the desperate need to know. Are they alive or are they dead? The feeling of isolation can be overwhelming. I remember only a couple of months back I had two mums in my car—both had sons missing. One son missing for six months the other 16 years. They both talked of the loneliness of their pain, of how members of their families would not allow them to talk about their sons—it was as if their sons had simply never existed. We need to educate the community—we need to give families permission to not only feel their pain but to express it an open and honest ways

. The healing process can never really begin because there is no resolution. The rituals associated with the death of a loved one are denied us. The law requires us to pretend that time stands still. The house must remain unattended, the car idle in the garage. What do you do about life insurance and superannuation. What does a spouse do about their joint pension entitlements, how do parents deal with their Wills. Money left to missing children by loving grandparents sits in trust unclaimed.
In response to the financial and legal issues raised by families at the Homeless and Missing Persons Seminar in 1996 the Human Rights Commissioner said:

". . . One of the major issues that needs to be appreciated is the simple lack of recognition of this as an issue—as being a problem and of it being a human rights problem. A human rights problem for those who have gone missing and a human rights problem for those who have lost them. . . "
We have a long way to go. On behalf of all families with missing loved ones I beg those of you here today who are in a position to make the necessary changes to do so.

If a person is missing by choice then that is their right but as parents, brothers, sisters, sons and daughters we need to know if they are alive. If they are dead we need to bury them—to say our goodbyes and deal with our grief. It is the not knowing that is so hard.

It is a source of enormous frustration to families that the Police are often hampered in their investigations because of the Privacy Laws. We, the families, acknowledge and accept the right of any individual to choose to seek a new life, to remain removed from their family for whatever reason.

However we believe that we have the right to be told our loved one is alive, however they choose at this time not to be in contact. Then at least we know what we are dealing with and the path forward is easier.

Only those with missing loved ones can know what it feels like to wake to the news on the clock radio and hear the words "A body was found". The stomach does a back flip, the heart starts to pound and so you wait for further bulletins. Is it male or female, young or old? Is this my loved one.

There is much that needs to be done to assist the families of missing persons. The establishment of the NMPU was a major step forward. It must not stop there. The need for a Missing Persons Committee, representative of all the appropriate agencies working in the field, together with the establishment of family support groups in each State is essential. Government must somehow find the funding to implement this coordinated approach.
I know these are tough times financially but for those of you with the power to put funds on the table I would ask you to talk with us—try for just one day to stand in our shoes and feel our pain.
As Inspector Mick Howe said in a recent interview we are the "Secondary Victims"
In closing I would remind you all that missing persons is not just a police responsibility. It is a community issue and we need to respond to it with a broad based community approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I would like to add my comments to your contribution on the issue of National Missing Persons Week which was held in early August and also, in doing so, to mention the work of the National Missing Persons Unit. This unit was established in December 1995, and is funded by the Commonwealth government for the four-year period following 1995. It is housed here in Canberra and its work deserves recognition, given that its contribution to society is made by no less than just three, four or perhaps five officers. The work done by this unit services the communities in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: As we heard from Madam President, the emotional circumstances surrounding a person going missing within one's life are quite devastating. I would like to quote a very brief excerpt from the speech of Maree Dawes. It relates to the issues of privacy—and herein lies an implication for us, as legislators, to look at the laws relating to privacy. I think Maree Dawes sums it up very succinctly, when she says:

It is a source of enormous frustration to families that the Police are often hampered in their investigations because of the Privacy Laws. We, the families, acknowledge and accept the right of any individual to choose to seek a new life, to remain removed from their family for whatever reason.

However we believe that we have the right to be told our loved one is alive, however they choose at this time not to be in contact. Then at least we know what we are dealing with and the path forward is easier.

This issue presents a grave conflict to people such as myself who believe wholeheartedly in a true regime of privacy for individuals in Australia. However, there is then the plea of Maree Dawes on behalf of people in her situation with their need to know of the fate of their loved one. The use of information contained within the bureaucracy to advise them one way or the other can do a great deal to address their concern and their need to know about the fate of their loved one.

BREAK.PARA: So I would say in this contribution: let us recognise the work of this particular unit which contributes greatly to the needs of people in times of emotional distress; and also let us recognise the individual devastation wrought upon those in our society who are touched by a missing person.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Diana, Princess of Wales Missing Persons Women and Sport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, both your point and that made by Senator Lundy are worthy of comment and in some ways are a preamble to what I want to start my contribution with this evening. First of all, Madam Speaker, you mentioned the pain of children who lose a mother, and I wanted tonight to take the opportunity to make a personal statement of my shock and sadness at the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps many things can be said about this woman—I think, a very special woman—but there are two things that stand out for me. One is the pictures of her being able to hold and touch people with AIDS at a time when the world was terrified of this disease. With that very simple gesture, she gave an example and courage and heart to thousands of people. One only has to remember what happened to a family with a child with AIDS in northern New South Wales, as I recall it, and how that family was hounded out of society by fear and ignorance. I think Diana's action in embracing a child, as I recollect it, with AIDS and also shaking the hand of an adult with AIDS sent a very splendid message which said that it is perfectly possible to live lovingly with people who do have that disease.

The second point I remember about Diana was the absolute priority she gave to her role as mother. Perhaps the saddest part of her very untimely death is that those two lads of hers will now be without a mother. No doubt they will have people who will care for them. But it is quite clear that she was a particularly important person in their lives, and she valued so importantly that role. Having worked for many years with children and mothers who were getting out of kilter with each other, I have always placed great store by that role of mother. I think in some ways that might be the saddest part of Diana's death—that all of us feel for those young men, boys, who now have to go into the world without her frontrunning and, in particular, loving them.

The point Senator Lundy makes about privacy is very important. I can say that this came up once in an estimates hearing. It was a particularly fascinating time in estimates; Senator Richardson was the minister—and it might surprise people that Senators Walters, Peter Baume and Rosemary Crowley were all of the same view. The Social Security Department which, in the name of privacy, would not inform parents of where their children might be caused Minister Richardson to say that this was something that needed to be addressed.

What was proposed—and I do not know whether it ever was properly implemented—was that people should be able to be told that their children are safe. The child's right to privacy—for there to be no indication given of where they were, and so on—should be protected. But at the same time, there was a recognition that it is right for parents who might be anguishing about a child to be given the assurance that they are safe. Even though it may be that nothing further can be said, and that may not be satisfactory, it is some way to deal with the tension Senator Lundy raised—although I am not sure that it would solve the particular case she mentioned.

Having spoken on such serious matters, I want to take a few minutes now not to be flippant at all but to turn to another matter: the disappointment I feel about the current government's failure to continue to develop the previous Labor government's initiatives of promoting women in sport. I have had the pleasure of attending two grand finals in the last couple of weeks. I went to watch the netball final between the Adelaide Thunderbirds and the Melbourne Phoenix, and last Saturday I watched the women's basketball final between the Adelaide Lightning and the Sydney Flames. I might say that it is something I should never attend because both teams I was there to support lost.

BREAK.PARA: But in both games we saw a level of sporting excellence that I believe is still largely unknown to and unrecognised by Australians because of the very insufficient coverage of women's sport. Anyone watching those games would know just how fit and fantastic our women athletes are, whether they are netballers, basketballers or athletes of any sort. So I would draw attention to those games. Certainly there is increased media coverage. Thank goodness for the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mainly by the ABC.

—Most of the television coverage comes by kind favour of the ABC. It shares its film with some of our pay TV carriers. In particular, there was some newspaper copy—minimal, but certainly a bit of an improvement on what it was in 1984‐85 when I first reported to government on women's sport in the media. Even so, one would have to say the coverage in last weekend's papers was anything but sufficient for the excellence of the game.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite interesting to know how well women's basketball is doing in the United States. They are in the process of establishing a significant women's league. It is also interesting to note that one Australian player, Michelle Timms, is hugely successful and popular—and possibly the No. 1 women's basketballer in the world. I understand that she was rated as No. 5—perhaps that was in the recent games. She has done a huge amount, with her own skills and ability, to promote women's sport.

It is a pity that last year the Prime Minister's women in sport awards just did not happen—and there is no accounting for why. We have not been told that there was a saving to be made or a decision that we would not proceed with them. It is a terrible disappointment when something of that sort that was enabling, with the coverage of such an event, the achievements of women in sport—across a whole variety of sports—to get some acknowledgment and celebration.

It is also very disappointing to me that since the death of Margaret Pewtress, who was head of the women's sports unit, there has been no replacement woman in that position. It is not sufficient that there be more women on the Sports Commission; there is a position and I believe and argue that there is still a long way to go before women and sporting coverage of women's sporting achievements are anything like equal. It is far too early to be retreating from those small initiatives that had been put in place to encourage the development of women in sport and the variety of media coverages of their achievements.

I am told that the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, Warwick Smith, was amazed at the recent basketball night awards for the most valuable player. I do have to say that Adelaide Lightning may have lost but at least we produced the most valuable player, Rachel Sporn, who gave a speech, as the captain of the losing team of the Lightning versus Flames match, that anybody and everybody should have access to as a speech of great grace. It is certainly my line that you cannot be a championship team if you have not beaten a team of champions. I would certainly say that is true of both the netball and basketball finals.

Minister Smith was reported as being amazed at the capabilities of these players not only to perform brilliantly but also—as I understand it—to talk; to make good speeches. One wonders what Mr Smith has been hearing footballers say. I am glad that he thinks women can speak beautifully at the end of a sporting achievement and I sincerely hope that Minister Smith who, not too long ago released a report on the insufficiency of media coverage for women, will—

TALK.START.PARA: —But he has done nothing about it.

—To this point he has done nothing about it but I would certainly urge him to pick up on that. Finally, I would like to say that it was interesting to note that Trish Fallon, the most valuable player for the Sydney Flames and part of the winning team the other night, was reported as being—and she agrees—about twelve weeks pregnant and Jackie Delaney, who was a member of the losing team in the netball final, was also pregnant and at about the same stage. This is causing a lot of people to be shocked and horrified but those of us who have been pregnant know that women who are pregnant are not enfeebled, not pathological and not suffering a sickness. They are as fit and as able as they must necessarily be to protect the next generation. Certainly what we see in women's sport are models for our daughters as well as our sons of just how fabulous, fantastic and fit our women in sport are. I think it does a disservice to the Australian community that that is not more widely acknowledged and celebrated.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Youth Forum Privacy Legislation Diana, Princess of Wales

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to discuss the issue of young people in politics. In particular, I would like to refer to a conference that took place last weekend, 29 to 31 August, in Old Parliament House: the inaugural Australian Youth Forum. It involved more than 350 young Australians from all over the country and aged between 16 and 21. On Sunday there was a luncheon held in the Old Parliament House and a number of politicians were present. I acknowledge the presence here tonight of Senator Bill Heffernan—who is getting rather excited in the corner, thinking I would not mention him—and Senator Kate Lundy. There were a number of other federal colleagues there: Dr Brendan Nelson, Mr Bob McMullan and Senator Marise Payne. So there was cross‐party representation at that luncheon. It was a summary luncheon, designed to give politicians the opportunity to hear first‐hand the types of discussions that had taken place over the preceding two days. The topics covered ranged from youth suicide, self‐esteem, racism, youth rights, education, employment, entertainment, Australia's future, drugs and youth homelessness.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge all members of the parliament—Senator Lundy and I have given notice of a motion on this today—to read the summary recommendations and respond, regardless of their party background. It was a truly motivational lunch. I assume that the colleagues in the chamber felt that invigoration and the inspiration that came from those young people. They were genuinely motivated and excited; not just active and informed citizens. There was a real sense, through motivational speakers as well as a genuine valuing of those young people's input, that they could make a difference and effect change.

I guess the overwhelming recommendation and message that some of us received on Sunday was still the sense that young people feel that politicians are not responding adequately or seriously to the concerns of young people. They want very much—certainly the delegates at this conference wanted—more opportunities for young people to be involved in the decision making processes of this country. This is clear from reading some of the comments by delegates. Perhaps I should refer to some of the comments. One of the delegates, Aaron Fowler, said:
I think it's high time the Government of today started to realise that the youth of Australia should not only be seen but be heard!
Ali Duggan said:

I would like the people in power in this country eg—politicians, to listen to what we say this weekend. These will be a lot of great ideas that come out of this forum this weekend. These ideas should be taken seriously and noted down. Hopefully everyone will be able to put these ideas into action so that this weekend can be successful.
Jenny's vision for the future was to:
salvage the environment, employment, no racism, drug abuse down, the 16 yr. vote (way for youth!) rights and suicide is gone man!

So you can see, Madam President, from some of these comments, the range of topics that were discussed. I strongly felt that a lot of young people at that conference yesterday countered some of the negative images perpetuated by some decision makers, some politicians and some mainstream media. They certainly countered some of those negative impressions. They did not talk about being given power or being given permission to act. They talked about empowering themselves and each other and acting on the rights or grasping the rights to which they are entitled. They were clearly conscious of the changing position of young people in our society—you could argue, the erosion of young people's rights in our society—the changing nature of access to education at all levels and the vital connection between unemployment and self‐ esteem and, of course, unemployment and poverty.

The willingness of these young people to embrace change and to work for a brighter, fairer and, I note, greener future, was inspiring and I know this will be commented upon in future adjournment debates by colleagues such as Senator Lundy. I congratulate the organisers, the sponsors and the facilitators of this conference. I congratulate Here for life for their emotional and financial support and, of course, the primary organiser, J.J. Kahla. I got the impression that this guy stops at nothing. This was clearly a goal and a dream that he had and he had every intention of turning it into reality. He had the idea that 350 young people from around Australia would meet in the nation's capital, and they did, with marvellous great success.

You can tell that this event was an inspiring one for me—to see young people claim power and working for goals such as accessible education and a sustainable economy. It filled me with hope, as did their recommendation that more young people should be in this place. I note that it came on the heels, if you like, of a week of heated debate in this place, in particular, last week's urgency debate on privacy, which the Democrats considered a matter of importance. It is a debate that has been touched on this evening.

The demeaning things said to me in that debate do not really affect me personally. In many respects, I think I am becoming an experienced enough politician, despite my age, which seems to bother some politicians in this place so much, to not take the abuse personally. But the language of Senator Abetz and Senator Chapman last week—likening me to a dog on a leash and calling me a kid—sends a strong message to young voters in this community and young people in this country that they are not welcome in this chamber and they will, if they wish to contribute to the political life of this nation, have to put up with insulting and demeaning stereotypes and insults on a daily basis.

Young people, in their despair over employment opportunities, how to pay for their education and how to have some hope in today's cruel and often anti-youth culture, need representation almost more so than any other group in our community and society. Their voting patterns suggest that they do not have a lot of faith in the old party structures or in politicians generally.

I do not often make personal reflections but in this case I was stunned by some of the language used last week by Senators Abetz and Chapman. They would do well to see that the language that they use almost on a daily basis in this chamber and elsewhere plays no small part in the cynicism and the disillusionment that young people have with politics. Never witty and never wise, they are only abusive and narrowly focused on party one‐upmanship. The comments are anti-youth and it betrays generational unease, a fear and importance that young voters pick up, despise and laugh at. Yet such senators as these dare to say at times that young people are our future. We must be wary of that hypocrisy.

I wish to acknowledge Senator Lundy's poignant comments about privacy tonight, a subject which Senator Crowley also referred to. Obviously, privacy is a particularly relevant issue this week. I suggest that a matter such as that would be well debated and discussed in the Senate committee to do with privacy, not only to do with the private sector but perhaps journalism and public life generally.

I know that it has been a unique day in this place as members and senators have reflected on the terrible tragedy that took place yesterday in Paris. I can only add my sentiments to those of Senator Crowley and my support for the motion passed earlier this day and express the grief that many Australians, young and old, monarchist or republican, feel about the loss of this young and modern woman, Diana, Princess of Wales, a woman—I hope people will forgive me paraphrasing Portia in Merchant of Venice—who `shined for her good deeds in a naughty world'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday saw the election in the Northern Territory of the eighth term of office for the Country Liberal Party since the fully elected Legislative Assembly came into being in 1974. That was a very important election. It is very important that it is the eighth consecutive win for a very successful political party.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to comment tonight on some aspects of both the campaign and the potential that it now offers the Northern Territory for the next four years under a government to be led by Chief Minister Shane Stone. Mr Stone and 24 other Country Liberal Party candidates maintained a very aggressive, very blunt and very factual campaign to the electorate of the Northern Territory. They are to be congratulated on the excellent result that they achieved in all 25 electorates. At this stage it appears from the counting that the new Stone government will be at least 16 members, possibly 18, with an outside chance of even 19. That of course leaves the Australian Labor Party with only six or seven members in the Northern Territory parliament. That is important.

I also congratulate Suzanne Cavanagh, the President of the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, and the hundreds of party members and hundreds of territorians who threw their weight behind the support of what was a very credible and competent campaign that was also built on—this must be recognised—the Country Liberal Party's ability to pre-select candidates which identify with the particular electorates and issues of an important part of Australia. It is well known that the Northern Territory has only one per cent of the population of Australia but, equally important, its success is measured by the fact that it now produces two per cent of the export earnings of Australia.

The body politic of the Northern Territory is an important issue. The fact that the Country Liberal Party was able to maintain a campaign of professionalism and community involvement is extremely important. That campaign compared markedly with the campaign that was run very doggedly through mistaken advertising by the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party imported into the campaign tactics reminiscent of the United States of America, particularly in referring to individual candidates as `pigs' and importing into the campaign a number of past has-been politicians, such as Mr Whitlam, Mr Melham and former leaders in the Northern Territory, Terry Smith and Brian Ede—none of whom had any relevance to this contemporary campaign.

It is important to recognise that the Northern Territory is uniquely different in national politics. It is a very mobile community. Probably 30 or 40 per cent of the voters at this election were not in the Northern Territory four or five years ago. The mobility and the youth of the Northern Territory is equally important when we look at issues such defence, lifestyle, our relationship with Asia and how that impacts on government policies completely in the electorate.

I commented on the fact that this identification with the electorate is probably one of the most important issues. In relation to the results that have been achieved, the swings were marked in both Labor and Country Liberal Party seats, but I draw attention very particularly to the swing of 16 per cent in the seat of Arnhem, in Arnhem Land. Whilst the Country Liberal Party probably will not win that seat, that is a very significant swing in that electorate. In the seat of Victoria River, which the Country Liberal Party won at the last election with Mr Tim Baldwin, there was a further 10 per cent swing in an Aboriginal constituency. In the seat of MacDonnell, the seat centred to the west of Alice Springs and which includes the area out to Ayers Rock and a number of Aboriginal communities, the swing was 18 per cent. John Elferink is to be congratulated on that very special result in this election.

This proves that Aboriginal people have walked away from their past reliance on the very heavy‐handed politics of the Australian Labor Party, particularly where they have continually thrown money at problems without gauging and properly assessing the outcomes and effects. Aboriginal people are now very competent in and very capable of making their own political judgments, as they have done at this election. I draw attention to the success of community government throughout the Northern Territory in Aboriginal communities, an initiative of the Northern Territory government which is now gaining a groundswell of Aboriginal momentum and that will see changes in the future to structures such as land councils, to ATSIC and to many other areas where Aboriginal people need to look at the structural defects in many of the Labor‐imposed previous institutional arrangements put around them. The Country Liberal Party return gives them this opportunity.

The Labor Party and many others on the Left also made in this election campaign accusations that issues of racism had surfaced. I would like to counter that very deliberately by saying that certainly issues that affected Aboriginal people were put on the table very clearly, and Aboriginal people and the Northern Territory community made their own judgment, particularly in the area of financial accountability, where the Labor Party just let loose and did not have any adequate controls. Those issues should be and are properly being addressed both by this federal government and also by the Northern Territory government.

When it comes to the issue of development, which underpins the economy of any community, it is important that land policies be addressed. Whether it is Aboriginal land rights, native title, Mabo or Wik—all of those issues again were properly adjudicated on, this time in a number of those seats, by Aboriginal people, who very strongly endorsed the policies of the Country Liberal Party rather than those of the Australian Labor Party which have failed the Aboriginal constituency and failed the Northern Territory in its economic development so strongly.

It was an important election last Saturday. Shane Stone is to be congratulated not only for the result but also because of the confidence that he imbues, the relationships that he has built with the Howard government and how that augurs well for the development of a north-south railway and for statehood, the vision that he takes forward into the next four years, and the recognition that this can be done by proper professionalism and whilst recognising the unique lifestyle of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On the front page of the Australian on 25 August one found an article which attacked both the RSL and its National President, Digger James—a man known to many in this chamber as a man of great integrity and great courage and a great Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this was not the first time that the Australian has run this article. It would be the third or fourth time that the Australian has rehashed—and grossly inaccurately rehashed—this same story. I wonder: what are the motives of the Australian in doing so? I certainly understand the motives of the people who purport to be an oppressed minority within the RSL. But their public facade and their claims are quite contrary to the facts. I believe it is important that the facts about this case go on the record.

In December 1994, a small group of people, who featured, as I said, on the front page of the Australian on 24 August, took the RSL to the Federal Court claiming that the RSL was anti-democratic and oppressive. Of course, in taking the matter to court, they also made great play of that matter in the media. But in the 2½ years that have transpired between then and now, these people have done nothing to test their case in court. They have done nothing to bring the facts before the court, to let the court adjudicate on these matters. What they have done is left this complaint sitting in the Federal Court and gone to the media time and time again suggesting that the RSL was anti-democratic and that the RSL was shortly to be rapped over the knuckles by the Federal Court.

But if these people had any integrity, if they valued the reputation of the RSL itself, then they would have taken the case to the court and not to the media. What they have indulged in is not a trial in the justice system; it is a trial in the media, where the Australian seems to be the judge, the prosecutor and the executioner. That is gravely tragic. It is tragic for the RSL and it is tragic for the executive of the RSL who do so much good work for veterans in this country. That is the truth.

These wild allegations were put before the court but were never tested. These people made no effort to bring the case on. They have procrastinated, they have delayed, they have used every possible ruse to attempt to avoid bringing their litigation on. The reason for that is very simple: the material they have tabled in court probably does not even support their spurious allegations.

The fact is that, since that case went to the Federal Court, Digger James has been re-elected a number of times as the National President of the RSL. If Digger James were some sort of tyrannical monster, as they try to portray, that would not have happened. But he has the confidence of the national organisation. That is what these people cannot live with; that is what they cannot accept.

Is it the case that this is, in fact, a small group fighting for the underdog? Quite the contrary. The underdog in this case is Digger James; the underdog in this case is the RSL, which has had its reputation slurred in the media and, yet, has not had the opportunity to answer it either in the media or in the court.

My understanding is that the RSL's national executive would love the opportunity to have these allegations contested in court. But that opportunity has not been given to them by the complainants because the complainants want the case to sit in the court file but to never see the light of day in a court room. While it sits in a court file they can continue to go to the media and slur the integrity of people like Mr James and others who serve on the national executive.

It is interesting to note that one of the men who is a complainant in this case, I understand, has made such a nuisance of himself that the RSL has had to provide Australia Post with a written directive not to allow him to continue his unauthorised collection of national and state RSL mail from the post office. If this is not a clear indication that there is a campaign of harassment against the RSL's national executive and against its president, I do not know what is.

I am gravely upset that the Australian has time and time again sought to slur this great Queenslander and this great Australian and sought to slur the RSL. If the Australian is really interested in the truth, if the Australian is really interested in reporting the facts, it would report the fact that these complainants have made no effort to bring their case to court. If the Australian was really interested in the underdog, if the Australian was really interested in ensuring that there was a fair and a democratic system, why haven't Digger James and the RSL been accorded the same opportunity to put their case as the Australian has accorded to this small, disgruntled group of people over and over again?

As I said, I can draw my own conclusions about the motivation of this small, disgruntled group of people, but I cannot understand how the Australian—a paper which purports to be interested in truth and integrity could allow this sham to continue. I believe it is incumbent upon them to apologise to Digger James and to put the other side of the story—a story which will reflect, I believe, quite well on both Digger James and the RSL national executive. It is about time the Australian started to praise this organisation for the fine work it does instead of attempting to tear it down in the ruthless and unscrupulous fashion in which it has done to date.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 2 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the August 1996 Australian Institute of Criminology report, prepared by an expert working group for the Minister in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre, entitled Indicators of Aggressive Behaviour, which identifies the key risk factors for aggressive and self-destructive behaviour to be: having a history of violent behaviour; being male; being a young adult; having experienced difficulties in childhood, including inadequate parenting, troubled relationships within the family, and low levels of school achievement; having problems of psychotropic substance abuse, especially problematic alcohol use; having severe mental illness the symptoms of which are not being adequately identified or controlled through therapeutic regimes; and being in situations, including poverty and unemployment, which may be conducive to self-directed or interpersonal violence:
(1) What social program and funding action has the Minister taken with regard to the report.

(2) Is there a coordinated plan or program which addresses the issue of violence in young adult males; if so, can details be provided of funding and staffing arrangements at the level of State and Federal Governments; if there is no coordination why not.
(3) Which programs consistent with the aims of addressing the above risk factors have been considered by Government departments but have not been funded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Many of the issues raised in the report, Indicators of Aggressive Behaviour , are already being addressed through a range of Commonwealth programs including:

PARA.TAB: The National Campaign Against Violence and Crime, The National Mental Health Strategy; The National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy; The National Child Abuse Prevention Strategy; The National Drug Strategy; The National Policy for Children and Young People. and work on nation-wide control of firearms.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) To provide a complete answer to this question across all jurisdictions would require considerable time and resources and I am not prepared to ask my Department to divert them at this time.

Insofar as my Department is concerned, while there is no overall plan or program which specifically addresses violence in young men, it is a major component in the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy and the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Emotional and Social Well Being (Mental Health) Action Plan. The Government has committed $31 million to the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy, over four years (1995/96-1998/99) to support the development and uptake of best practice initiatives and service delivery for at risk youth, research, education and training for professionals, and increased access to counselling and telephone support services; and $20 million to the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Emotional and Social Well Being (Mental Health) Action Plan over four years (1996/971999/2000) to improve training and support to mental health workers and to strengthen the role of community level workers in dealing with the complex alcohol, violence and family breakdown problems which affects some Indigenous communities.

Violence in young males is being addressed within the injury prevention component of the five National Health Priority Areas which have been agreed by all the State and Territory Health Ministers, and are coordinated through the National Health Priority Committee.

Furthermore, as one of the sponsors of the Second National Men's Health Conference, the Government (through my Department) is fostering debate on issues relevant to violence in young males. This Conference will discuss a broad range of issues including men's health and health risk behaviour, emotional and mental health and suicide and injury in young men.
In addition, the following programs in my Department provide assistance to this target group:

PARA.TAB: $4.3 million has been provided over the years 1996-97 and 1997-98 for child abuse prevention initiatives focusing on parenting education;

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has provided $8.3 million to fund 26 pilot projects under the Youth Homelessness Pilot Program. Pilot projects will test innovative early intervention strategies to assist young people at risk of homelessness to re-engage in family, work, education, training and life in the community. Emphasis is on identifying early home leaving and developing family relations approaches which will support young people and their families in the reconciliation process.

Commonwealth funding for the Emergency Relief Program has been increased in the 1997-98 Budget to $23.5 million. The Emergency Relief Program provides financial and other assistance to individuals and families who are in short-term financial crisis. The major client groups are single parents with children (including people escaping domestic violence), people on unemployment benefits and people with disabilities.

The Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP) is a joint Commonwealth and States/Territories program providing transitional supported accommodation and associated services to assist homeless people to achieve greater independence and self-reliance.

The National Alcohol Action Plan recognises the link between alcohol and crime, in particular violence. It outlines actions being undertaken by the Commonwealth, State/Territory government health departments, State/Territory police services, non-government organisations and the alcohol industry to reduce the harms associated with the misuse of alcohol.
The Action Plan includes a description of activities to increase police and community awareness of alcohol as a factor in a range of issues such as violence and crime.

These programs do not, however, focus exclusively on violence in young men but address aspects of young men's lives. This holistic approach means it is not possible to break down staffing arrangements for elements of the program.
(3) As I have stated previously I will answer only in respect to my Department.

Strategies which are based on sound evidence and have been subjected to overall policy and financial considerations will be recognised by the programs which have already been referred to in the above answers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 14 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Did the Minister and/or his department invite the Commonwealth Ombudsman to examine the handling of access to information for solicitors representing recipients of pituitary hormones implicated in the rare fatal brain disorder Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD), in their litigation against the Commonwealth; (b) when did the department contact the Ombudsman to make the request that the Ombudsman examine its procedures in the matter; (c) what were the reasons given to the Ombudsman for the invitation; (d) has the Ombudsman provided the department with a written report; if so, can a copy of the report be provided; (e) was the Ombudsman or an officer from the Ombudsman's office satisfied with departmental procedure in the provision of documents to the litigants, the department's freedom of information procedures and any other matter the Ombudsman was requested to examine.

(2) (a) Was an officer of the Public Health Litigation Group of the department expressing the official view of the Minister when he informed Senator Harradine's office that all necessary documents had been provided to the litigants' solicitors; (b) is the Minister aware of the statement by Ms Karen Weeks of the legal firm Macedone Christie Willis Solari Partners, which represents some of the pituitary hormone recipients, denying that they had received all of the Allars Inquiry documents.

(3) With reference to the fact that the officer of the Public Health Litigation Group of the Minister's department informed Senator Harradine's office that the pituitary hormone recipients' claims for damages were `not allowable under Australian law': can a copy be provided of the opinion on which this statement is based.
(4) Can a copy be provided of any advice that it is unlikely there will be further CJD-related deaths in Australia.
(5) Has any donor giving materials in Australia, whether blood or blood plasma, tissue, organs or any other body part, since donating, died of CJD.

(6) (a) Is the Minister aware of criticism that the Commonwealth Government's offer of compensation for recipients on being diagnosed with CJD is flawed, as no such diagnosis can currently be made unless, and until, the recipient is dead and their brain is available for autopsy; (b) is the Minister aware of the joint statement by Professor C Mims, Emeritus Professor of Microbiology, Guy's Hospital, London and Dr P McCullagh, Senior Fellow, John Curtin School of Medical research, dated 22 April 1997, responding to the Minister's press release of 4 April 1997; (c) what is the Minister's response to this medical opinion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following amended answer to part 2(b) of the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (b) The Minister is aware of representations by Ms Weeks. On 22 May 1997 the Australian Government Solicitor's Office in Melbourne responded on behalf of the Minister.

On 26 May 1997, the plaintiff's application with respect to access to certain documents was by consent stood over generally with liberty for the matter to be restored to the Court list on 7 days notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 25 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much Commonwealth money has been allocated for National Women's Health programs
for the 1996‐97 financial year: (a) nationally; and (b) for each State.
(2) What was the expenditure in the 2 previous years for the National Women's Health Program.
(3) Please list all projects that were funded under the Women's Health Program and provide a brief description of each project.
(4) How were the funds allocated for public health divided between the different programs, including Women's Health Program and family planning.
(5) What was the allocation for the 1995‐96 financial year in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Minister for Health and Family Services allocated $182,000 from Bill 1 in the 1996‐97 financial year for national activities under the National Women's Health Program.
(b) The following amounts were allocated under Bill 2 to each State and Territory for the 1996‐97 financial year.
(3) Please see attached lists of all projects approved for funding during the second phase of the National Women's Health Program (1993/94—1996/97).

(4) For 1996/97, the Public Health program funding was consolidated into a one-line appropriation under both Bill 1 and Bill 2 (except for the new policy items, which were grouped under a separate one-line appropriation in Bill 2 in the first year). This replaced the previous approach of some 17 individual appropriations.
Total Public Health funding for 1996/97 was $226.24 million, of which $131.84 million was

allocated to the States/Territories under Bill 2. The 1996/97 distribution of these funds to each State/Territory was based on the individual agreements for each program that were already in place under Bill 1. The $94.4 million national component was divided between a number of specific national public health such as HIV/AIDS, Hepatitis C and substance abuse through to activities under the National Women's Health Program and the Family Planning Program.
The distribution of the 1996/97 Public Health Bill 1 appropriations were determined and approved by the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Michael Wooldridge, in September 1996.
