QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What food business are not covered by the Australian Food Standards Code.
(2) Are there any food businesses which are not covered by the code.
(3) What is "international best practice" as it relates to the code.
(4) On what data, analysis, facts, etcetera, does the Minister rely to draw the conclusion that self-regulatory codes of practice are demonstrably more effective than regulation.
(5) Will the proposed food hygiene standard replace existing regulatory measures.
(6) What regulatory measures will the proposed food hygiene standard replace.
(7) What evidence supports the Minister's contention that Australia has a reputation for the supply of clean, safe food.
(8) What evidence does the Minister have to support the contention that the proposed food hygiene standard will protect Australia's reputation as a supplier of clean, safe food.
(9) Is Australia's reputation of a supplier of clean, safe food likely to be harmed by outbreaks of food contamination.
(10) Do outbreaks of food contamination in Australia have an economic impact on Australian food businesses.
(11) Will a self-regulatory food standard ensure and maintain the existing reputation for the supply of clean, safe food in Australia.
(12) What is the projected cost to business of introducing the Food Hygiene Standard.
(13) Will small businesses be disadvantaged by compliance costs of introducing the standard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Food Standards Code sets standards for the composition and labelling of food. No food business is covered by the Code.
(2) The Food Standards Code sets standards for the composition and labelling of food. No food business is covered by the Code.

(3) In developing and amending all food standards be they for composition, labelling or food hygiene, ANZFA seeks to promote consistency between domestic and international standards. Wherever possible ANZFA seeks to follow internationally accepted guidelines such as those specified by the Codex Alimentarius Commission.

(4) The Minister is not of the view that self-regulatory codes of practice are demonstratably more effective than regulation. As an example, the proposed food hygiene standards, when adopted by States and Territories will become enforceable regulations, not self-regulatory codes of practice.
(5) Yes, but not immediately. The current prescriptive regulations will be gradually removed during the transition period for implementation of the new hygiene standards.

(6) The proposed food hygiene standards will replace a disparate array of State and Territory regulations. In some jurisdictions parts of these are outdated and inappropriate for modern food handling processes and practices.

(7) Approximately 19,000,000,000 meals are consumed every year in Australia and an extremely small proportion of these meals result in illness. The reputation of the food industry, both domestically and internationally, as well as associated industries such as tourism, are reliant on this ability to consistently make safe food.

(8) The food hygiene standards proposed by ANZFA are a move to performance based regulations designed to prevent potential food contamination. The proposed standards are in keeping with international experience which has shown that this form of standard is more efficacious in reducing food contamination.
(9) Yes.
(11) The food hygiene standards proposed by ANZFA are not self-regulatory.
(12) A regulatory impact analysis is being developed. ANZFA will seek ways to minimise imposts on business, particularly small business and the standard be introduced on a staged basis.

(13) Small business in the food sector currently have to bear the costs of complying with current prescriptive hygiene regulations, many of which do not necessarily promote safe food. A move to less prescriptive outcomes-based standards will facilitate the production and sale of safe food.

The complexity of food safety programs will be related to the size and nature of the business. Small business will have less complex food safety programs than bigger business, with smaller compliance costs.

ANZFA will co-ordinate the development of food industry guidelines with each of the food industry sectors, and State and Territory governments. These food industry guidelines will provide valuable and highly relevant information to small business in the development of food safety programs which are based on best practice of their whole industry sector.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 25 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) receive a request from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to undertake a full public health risk assessment of the proposed importation of cooked chicken meat from Thailand, the United States and Denmark.
(2) When did work commence on that assessment process.
(3)Did ANZFA officers conduct the assessment or was the task performed by consultants.
(4) What was the cost of the consultancy.
(5) What were the qualifications and experience of the officers or consultants who undertook the work.
(6) Have any interim reports been provided to AQIS; if so: (a) when were those reports completed; (b) when were they provided to AQIS; and (c) what was the AQIS response.
(7) Were any of these reports made available to any other individuals or organisations: if so (a) who received copies of the reports; and (b) why were they provided.
(8) Can copies of the these interim reports be provided.
(9) Have these interim reports been subjected to public scrutiny or peer review, as is required for quarantine risk assessment processes; if so, can details of those processes be provided.
(10) Will the final public health risk assessment report be subjected to both peer review and public scrutiny before ANZFA makes a final recommendation to AQIS; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A formal request was received from AQIS on 5 September 1994 to do a risk assessment rather than a full public health risk assessment. The ANZFA risk assessments are done in the context of the Imported Food Control Act (IFCA) and are secondary to the quarantine assessment. In effect, ANZFA, is asked, given that this product may be allowed into Australia, what kind of risk management strategies will be necessary. ANZFA advises on appropriate surveillance categories and testing regimes but banning a product is not an option within the scope of the IFCA.
(2)In July 1994.
(3) ANZFA officers conducted the assessment.
(5) All staff contributing to the work have appropriate tertiary qualifications, with extensive experience in the IFIP program including undertaking risk assessments.

(6) One interim report was provided to AQIS. (a) The interim report was completed on 7 September 1994; (b) The interim report was provided to AQIS on 7 September 1994; and (c) AQIS responded by summarising the report in the AQIS Policy Memorandum 96/32, which was circulated for comment on 7 June 1996.
(7) The interim report was summarised in AQIS Policy Memorandum 96/32 and made available to all interested parties. The report was not made available separately from the AQIS document.

(8) Yes, a copy of the correspondence to AQIS, dated 7 September 1994 can be provided. In summary, the report concluded that cooked chicken meat will be subject to the highest level of surveillance in the Imported Food Inspection Program for bacterial contamination by Salmonella spp, Listeria monocytogenes and Campylobacter spp. Testing for antibiotic residues and organochlorine/organophosphate residues was also discussed.

(9) The interim report has been subjected to public scrutiny as part of the AQIS Policy Memorandum 96/32 which was circulated to interested parties. All ANZFA risk assessment reports are peer reviewed internally by the various scientific discipline groups represented within the organisation. All risk assessments dealing with microbological matters are reviewed by the microbiological discipline group, assessments dealing with toxicological matters are reviewed by the safety assessment discipline group and so on. The final report is currently being externally peer reviewed by the CSIRO.

(10) The final risk assessment will be subject to peer review before ANZFA makes a final recommendation to AQIS. The final recommendation to AQIS will be available to the public but will not undergo public comment independently of the AQIS processes.
The final recommendation to AQIS will be available to the public but there will not be an opportunity for public comment except through the normal channels of AQIS seeking comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 27 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that during the approval process for the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) loan to Lihir Gold the then Minister for the Environment recommended that a number of conditions be imposed on the loan and that this recommendation was accepted.

(2) Is the Minister aware that, as a result of this recommendation, EFIC has received from Lihir Gold a number of reports including one report commissioned from Dames and Moore and one from a Papua New Guinean consultant, which examine a range of issues relevant to the recommendations of the Minister for the Environment.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the Environment Protection Group (EPG), which provided the recommendations to the Minister for the Environment, has been unable to obtain a copy of these reports from EFIC and therefore is unable to ascertain whether the recommendations made by the EPG, then Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, and the Minister have been implemented.
(4) Will the Minister direct EFIC to release copies of any reports received by EFIC which are relevant to the recommendations of the EPG and the Minister for the Environment; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) provided political risk insurance to a syndicate of banks which made a loan in relation to the development of the Lihir project. I am aware that the owner of the mine and the mine manager gave EFIC undertakings which relate to the environmental conditions recommended by the then Minister for the Environment.

(2) I am aware that EFIC has received an environment management review report from independent consultants Dames and Moore, not from Lihir Gold. EFIC has also received a draft report from another consultant (not from Papua New Guinea) on social impacts of the mine.
(3) I am not aware of any attempts by the Environment Protection Group to obtain the report from EFIC.
(4) No. As the matters contained in the reports are classed as commercial in confidence, disclosure is prohibited under the EFIC Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Contracting and Corruption in Foreign Aid

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much foreign aid goes into agency agreements, in order that Australian companies might secure overseas contracts generally, and in Asia particularly?

(2) (a) How many of those contracts are for projects in Indonesia; (b) what is the total amount of money paid to Indonesian agencies; and (c) what proportion of these agencies are owned and/or controlled by the Suharto family?
(3) What provisions are being taken by the Government in its efforts to stem bribery and corruption of government officials and their business representatives, in overseas contractual negotiations?

(4) Does the Government definition of `bribery' being used in its measures to address the United Nations Declaration against Bribery and Corruption in International Commercial Transactions encompass monies paid to agencies, rather than individuals, to assist in the procurement of a large infrastructure contract overseas; if not (a) why not; (b) how then does the Government expect to make inroads to stemming bribery, especially the expectation of overseas countries, particularly those in Asia, that any contract `comes at a price'; and (c) does the Government really consider that this price should be paid from overseas aid and development money.

(5) With reference to the review of Australia's overseas aid program chaired by Mr Paul Simons: what is the Government's intent regarding the recommendation made in the resultant report, One Clear Objective, that Australia should untie its aid program from Australian suppliers.

(6) With reference to the Government's announcement in the 1997‐98 Budget that the Australian Development Scholarship Scheme will replace both the Australian Sponsored Training Scholarships and the Australian Development Cooperation Scholarships, which will be integrated into the country program framework; will these programs continue to be managed by private contractors selected through competitive tender.
(7) What provisions are there for transparency of contracts, including the disclosure of the amount paid to agencies by AusAID, and the level of scholarship received by participants.
(8) How many students qualify for such scholarships and from which countries.

(9) With reference to a recent claim by a group of Philippine students who were studying at the University of Technology in Queensland that GRM International (manager of the university) was making huge profits at their expense, in that the company was receiving $55 per day for each student in the course, yet the students themselves were receiving only $33: can details of the amount of money awarded to the management contractors, GRM International, be provided along with an explanation as to the difference in the allowance paid to them and that paid to the students.
(10) Does the Government consider this to be a reasonable profit margin for a private contractor to make from Australia's aid budget.
(11) What is the relationship between AusAID and the private contractors, in this case GRM International.

12) (a) By what process does the Government evaluate the program delivery and the operations of the contractor: and (b) does it take student feedback into consideration in its overall assessment of the evaluation of the administration of the scholarships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following response was provided by EFIC in its role as AusAID's managing agent for DIFF projects.
Agency costs can be legitimate component costs of an export contract, costs incurred in the ordinary course of business.

Before the awarding of the contract, local agents can assist with bid preparation and contract negotiations. During project implementation, agency costs can relate to facilitating customs clearance, arranging delivery of goods, obtaining permits necessary to undertake works, etc.

Securing of the overseas contracts takes place through commercial negotiations prior to aid/Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) finance becoming available. The local agent would normally be involved in these negotiations between the exporter and the recipient government.

With the commercial contract in place, EFIC negotiates with the recipient government a loan agreement under which EFIC finance (incorporating aid funds) is provided to enable the borrowing government's implementation agencies to fulfil the payment obligations in the contracts negotiated with the Australian companies.

Some of the contractual payment obligations to be financed under the loan include the cost to Australian companies of employing local agents. Those costs are identified by the exporter to AusAID and EFIC at the time the application for the mixed credit loan is made.

Approximately $30 million of aid is going to such agency expenses for mixed credit projects in Asia totalling $1,374 million for which funds are currently being disbursed. This draws on information provided by Australian companies at the time of their application for aid/EFIC funding and is calculated on the basis that aid funds account for 35 per cent of the loan value, with 65 per cent covered by EFIC.
(2) (a) See (1) above. Fourteen current mixed credit projects totalling A$634 million are being undertaken in Indonesia and include payments to local agents.

(2) (b) The aid portion of EFIC's finance covering such agency expenses for these projects in Indonesia is approximately A$26 million, about four per cent of aggregate project value for these DIFF projects, based on information provided by Australian companies at time of application.
(2) (c) Not known to EFIC or AusAID. Australian companies are not required to provide information on the ownership of agents used in Indonesia when mixed credit financing is sought.

(3) In response to an OECD (Development Assistance Committee) recommendation, the Government has introduced an anti‐bribery and corruption clause for AusAID contracts. This prohibits any payments which could be construed as illegal or corrupt, and allows for contract termination in such circumstances.

EFIC advises that it is a requirement that in its application to EFIC, an exporter must declare the amount of agency fee likely to be payable under the contract. In addition, on every loan drawdown, an exporter is required to declare to EFIC the amount of any agency fee paid and its details. Alternatively, the exporter must confirm that agency fees paid are in the ordinary course of business and readily identifiable in its books.

EFIC is not involved in contractual negotiation, which is a commercial matter between the exporter and the buyer. EFIC does not determine if: (i) government officials and/or their business representatives are at all involved in any of the aid‐supported projects; or (ii) if they are involved, the extent of their involvement and the benefits accruing to them.

(4) The anti‐corruption clause applies to AusAID contracts whether with an individual or a firm. All such contracts are generally awarded through an open tender process on the basis of technical merit and value for money. Through contract provisions and financial management, AusAID has in place a sound basis to prevent illegal payments.

The Government supports the UN Declaration on Bribery and Corruption in International Commercial Transactions. It considers this matter to be a serious international issue and that any action is most effective if taken on a multilateral basis. In conjunction with other OECD members, the Government will implement appropriate measures to combat bribery of government officials.

(5) As outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the launch of the Simons report on 2 May 1997, there is a two‐step process to respond to the report. The first step was a three‐month period of public comment on the report which ended on 31 July 1997. The second step will be an analysis of the report in the light of comments received from the Australian community and partner Governments. The Government is currently in that second stage. As yet, no decisions have been made on any of the Simons report recommendations, including those relating to untying the aid program. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has indicated that he intends to announce the Government's response to the report before the end of this year.

(6) Both the Australian Sponsored Training Scholarship Scheme (ASTAS) and the Australian Development Cooperation Scholarship Scheme (ADCOS) were managed by AusAID. The Australian Development Scholarship Scheme, which commenced on 1 July 1997, has been contracted by AusAID to Australian universities and training institutions. Contracts have been awarded to the 46 universities and institutions who were able to demonstrate willingness and ability to meet AusAID technical requirements at an acceptable price.
(7) The estimated annual value of AusAID contracts with each university and training institution is publicly advised in accordance with standard Commonwealth requirements.
Scholarship entitlements for participating students are paid as per rates published in a fixed and publicly available schedule. These conditions apply to all AusAID students.

(8) As at 31 March 1997, some 5,440 students were studying under Australian Development Scholarships. Scholarships are awarded on the basis of academic merit and the partner country's development needs. Forty five countries are currently eligible for Australian Development Scholarships. These are: Bangladesh, Bhutan, Botswana, Cambodia, China, Cook Islands, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Fiji, French Polynesia, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Kiribati, Laos, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mauritius, Micronesia, Mongolia, Mozambique, Namibia, Nauru, Nepal, New Caledonia, Niue, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Seychelles, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Swaziland, Tanzania, Thailand, Tokelau, Tonga, Tuvalu, Uganda, Vanuatu, Vietnam, Western Samoa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

9) The Government has committed $26.5m over five years to the Philippines Project in Basic Education known as PROBE. GRM International won the contract through a competitive bidding process. AusAID signed a contract for the Project on 4 January 1996 with a consortium led by GRM International in association with Queensland University of Technology. The contract provides for the consortium to deliver a range of services, including the training in Australia of several hundred Filipino trainees over a five year period. In June 1997, sixty‐nine Filipino trainees completed a six months Teacher Education Fellowship Course at Queensland University of Technology.

Under the terms of their contract, GRM International are required to provide suitable accommodation for PROBE trainees undertaking training in Australia. In addition, the trainees were entitled to receive a per diem of $33.01 to cover food and incidental costs. This amount was paid to the trainees. The cost of these services is included in the total amount for GRM International to deliver a range of services required under the contract. Neither GRM International's bid nor the PROBE contract make any reference to an amount of $55.00.

(10) AusAID conducts its selection process for consultancy services in accordance with Commonwealth Purchasing Guidelines. An open and competitive bidding process was used to select the PROBE contractor. The contract was awarded to GRM International on the basis of value for money using a weighting system based on 70 percent for technical merit and 30 percent for price. The use of market forces and commercial realities encourages contractors to price their bids competitively and promotes the selection by AusAID of efficient contractors.

(11) GRM International is one of a number of private consulting firms contracted by AusAID to deliver the aid program. AusAID has a contractual relationship with GRM for a number of current aid projects including PROBE.

12) (a) AusAID regularly undertakes post‐project evaluations. AusAID's Contractor Performance Assessment System (CPAS) is also used to evaluate a contractor's ongoing performance. In addition a contractor's performance on the ground is usually monitored by in‐country AusAID staff (where present), visits by A‐based AusAID staff, the conduct of project reviews and the use of technical advisory group (TAG) visits. Contractors are obliged to report on a regular basis to AusAID and payments are made against the achievement of milestones specified in the contract.

(12) (b) AusAID's on‐going monitoring arrangements during a project's implementation usually bring to light any problems with a contractor's performance. In the case of the PROBE trainees' complaints about accommodation, AusAID arranged for two senior Philippines Government officials to inspect their accommodation. They considered the accommodation to be very satisfactory. There was also in place a system of house wardens reporting to a group leader appointed by the Philippines Government to bring to the contractor's attention any problems being experienced by the trainees. The house wardens and the group leader expressed satisfaction with the arrangements made by the contractor for the trainees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government Members Secretariat provide both layout and content material for the Dunkley Small Business Report , dated May 1997, which was subsequently distributed by the Member for Dunkley, Mr Billson.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 16 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Can a copy of all reports, including reports from air crew and air traffic controllers, provided to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation concerning Air New Zealand flight 31, which departed Brisbane at 11.40 am on 6 July 1997, be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has advised that its investigation into this incident has not been completed. A copy of its investigation report, and any other publicly available documents associated with the investigation, will be provided to Senator Collins as soon as the investigation has been completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How many people have been taken off social security allowances through increased compliance measures in the 1995‐96 and 1996‐97 financial years and what are the expected figures for the 1997‐98 financial year; and (b) what is the breakdown by: (i) name of allowance, (ii) age group, (iii) amount of people affected in each sub‐group, and (iv) savings.

(2) (a) How many people have had their social security allowances reduced through increased compliance measures in the 1995‐96 and 1996‐97 financial years and what are the expected figures for the 1997‐98 financial year; and (b) what is the breakdown by: (i) name of allowance, (ii) age group, (iii) amount of people affected in each sub‐group, and (iv) savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Please refer to the attached tables outlining the Department's compliance activity for 1995‐96 and 1996‐97 to 31 March 1997. Information by age group is unavailable.

The information for the last quarter of 1996‐97 is still being finalised and figures for the financial year as a whole will be provided when available. It is difficult to estimate the expected effect of compliance measures in 1997‐98 due to the complexity in quantifying the impact of voluntary compliance on review outcomes. As the Government takes a stronger stand on compliance matters, through, for example the new activity test arrangements, it is expected that more customers will voluntarily comply with their notification obligations.
Review Results for the Department of Social Security by Program, 1995‐96

ROW.ENTRY: Assistance to Sole Parents and their Dependent Children

ANSWER.PARA: 1 Reductions exclude Cancellations.
2 Savings to Fortnightly Outlays resulting from Rate Reductions or Cancellations.
3 Job Search Allowance includes Newstart Allowance.
Review Results for the Department of Social Security by Program, 1996‐97 to 31 March 1997

ROW.ENTRY: Assistance to Sole Parents and their Dependent Children

ANSWER.PARA: 1 Reductions exclude Cancellations.
2 Savings to Fortnightly Outlays resulting from Rate Reductions or Cancellations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the Minister's office in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.
(3) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(4) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: Prime Minister's Office, Senator Minchin's Office, Senator Herron's Office and Senator Newman's Office

(1) $75,094.00. This compares to a figure of $182,519.65 for the last 12 months in office of the former Prime Minister and his Ministers Assisting (Mr Johns and Mr Tickner) and his Parliamentary Secretary (Dr Theophanous).
(2) Media Monitors; Rehame Australia; Warburton Media; Crolls Press Clips.
Department and Portfolio Agencies (excluding ATSIC)
(4) Media Monitors; Rehame Australia; Political Reference Service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for the Environment: Media Monitoring Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the Minister's office in the 1996-97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.
(3) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996-97 financial year.
(4) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Media monitoring services for the Office of the Minister for the Environment and the Office of the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government are a part of, and not readily separable from, media monitoring services contracted by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. The cost of media monitoring for the Department in 1996/97 was $88,094.
(2) Media Monitors.
(3) The total cost for the Department and Agencies within the Environment, Sport and Territories Portfolio in 1996/97 was $171,566.
(4) Media Monitors, Specialised Press Agency and North Queensland Media Information Network.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Media Monitoring Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the Minister's office in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.
(3) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(4) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Media Monitors, and Rehame Australia Monitoring Service
(4) Media Monitors, Milestones, Rehame Australia Monitoring Service, and Emmanuel Stefanou & Associates.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government: Media Monitoring Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera provided to the Minister's office in the 1996-97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $588 was spent on transcription services for the Office of the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government in 1996/97.

In respect of other media monitoring services for the Office of the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and the Office of the Minister for the Environment, these are a part of, and not readily separable from, media monitoring services contracted by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. The cost of media monitoring for the Department in 1996/97 was $88,094.
(2) Rehame Australia and Media Monitors.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bangladeshi Military Personnel: Training in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How many Bangladeshi military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(2) (a) How many Bangladeshi military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in Bangladesh in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

(3) (a) How many Thai military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(4) (a) How many Thai military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in Thailand in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

(5) (a) How many Papua New Guinean (PNG) military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(6) (a) How many PNG military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in Papua New Guinea in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

(7) (a) How many Malaysian military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(8) (a) How many Malaysian military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in Malaysia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

(9) (a) How many Philippine military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(10) (a) How many Philippine military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in the Philippines in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

(11) (a) How many Indonesian military personnel have been trained in Australia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained; and (d) which military college or institution provided that training.

(12) (a) How many Indonesian military personnel have been trained by Australian personnel in Indonesia in the 1996‐97 financial year and what is the projected figure for the 1997‐98 financial year; (b) what is the nature of the training of the personnel; and (c) what are the names and positions of the personnel trained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 to 12) The nature of training provided to Bangladeshi, South East Asian and Papua New Guinean military personnel falls into the following broad areas: professional military skills; technical skills; officer development; management; language training; and training techniques. I do not intend to discuss the details of individual personnel trained by the Australian Defence Force (ADF).

Data for the training provided to Bangladeshi, Thai, Papua New Guinean, Malaysian, Philippine and Indonesian military personnel by the ADF in Australia, and in the countries concerned, is given in the following tables.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mr Reginald Faulkner: Parliament House Security Pass

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Which Members or Senators sponsored the successful application for a Parliament House photographic pass issued in 1995 to a Mr Reginald
Faulkner of International Lobbyists Pty Ltd, Sydney, New South Wales.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reid, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A Parliament House photographic security pass was issued to Mr Reginald Faulkner on 21 August 1995. The issue of the photographic pass was sponsored by Mr A J Abbott MP and Mr P M Ruddock MP.
